*The Liezi·Heavenly Portents* says: “Master Liezi lived in the gardens of Zheng for forty years, yet no one recognized him. The lord of the state and his ministers and grandees regarded him as one of the common folk.” Is this not a model of harmonizing radiance and blending with dust?

In ancient times, the Old Ancestor served as the Keeper of the Pillars in Zhou, Master Guanyin was the magistrate of Hangu Pass, Ge Hong was the magistrate of Goulou, and Master Jingyang was the magistrate of Jingyang—these were true immortals who harmonized their radiance within officialdom. Junping told fortunes, Qi Nian herded sheep, Master Hu sold medicine, Master Cuixu mended barrels, and Sun Simiao practiced medicine—these were true immortals who harmonized their radiance through crafts.

In the past, my teacher, Master Tianzhi, traveled to Hangao and encountered Master Li Zuhanxu at the Eastern Sacred Mountain Temple in Xi’an. At the time, Master Li was concealing himself among fortune-tellers, mingling with the crowd of character analysts to divine fortunes for others. Master Tianzhi stayed at the inn of Brother Ke for over a year, never revealing his true nature, and was regarded by all as an ordinary paper merchant. All these are exemplars of profound sameness, the wondrous function of Master Hu’s “hidden virtue and subtle mechanism,” serving as models for later generations.

An ancient saying goes: “When the Dao rises a foot, demons rise ten feet.” The onset of demonic obstacles is largely due to self-display inviting misfortune. Therefore, concealing one’s traces, veiling one’s light, and practicing in secret are essential conduct after attaining the elixir.

The subtlety of harmonizing radiance and blending with dust lies in appearing the same while functioning differently, hence “harmonizing but not drifting.” Not drifting means not being turned by any circumstance. Dwelling among different kinds yet not assimilating with them; dwelling amid sounds and sights yet not being stained by them; dwelling in honor yet not priding oneself on it. Though entering all dharmas, one is not bound by any—this is called appearing the same while functioning differently.

*The Precious Mirror Samadhi of the Cave School* says: “Snow in a silver bowl, a heron hidden in the bright moon—though resembling, they are not the same; when blended, one knows where to abide.”

Master Caoshan Jiji established three kinds of “falling,” referring to “falling into resemblance” and “falling into following,” which precisely capture the profound subtlety of harmonizing radiance and blending with dust. Yet without penetrating the ultimate barrier, one cannot easily attain this realm.

**Appendix: Master Wang’s Teachings**

Furthermore, after the student attains the elixir, they become “one who has gained the One and is thus numinous,” possessing a foundation of eternal attainment. Even if misfortune strikes, their spirit has its own master, and their qi cannot be invaded or dispersed. They may reincarnate and seize another’s body to complete their work. However, as the student’s practice deepens, they must be ever more cautious in worldly affairs, for “when the Dao rises a foot, demons rise ten feet.” The path of the golden elixir most provokes the envy of beings. The ancient saying about “three encounters with heavenly punishment” is truly due to self-display inviting misfortune, not actual heavenly punishment.

When, in the future, the practice reaches the stage of rejuvenation, all worldly affairs and human sentiments will gradually conclude, and one will retreat to a tranquil state. If confronted with worldly clamor, respond with feigned foolishness and deafness—this is the most wondrous method. As the elixir texts say: “Blend with the world and harmonize your light, adapting to square or round in response to circumstances.” This point is truly crucial and must be carefully heeded when the time comes.

**43. The Timeline of Dao Cultivation**

As the ancients said: “Those who skillfully cultivate the Dao accomplish it in a thousand days.”

“It is also said: ‘Three years of diligence, ten thousand kalpas of bliss.’ In the early Qing dynasty, a woman from Guangling practiced the Dao for three years and passed away in seated meditation, leaving behind a gatha that read:

*In stillness, nothing stirs,
Repeatedly toying with emptiness.
When earth ages and heaven decays,
Amid the flight of the hun and the loss of the po,
A master opens the lineage of the Dao,
Yet no method awakens the deluded.
Suddenly, emptiness shatters—
The evening sun remains red as ever.*

Another disciple of Lü Zu, Zhang Zhennu, left her household and secluded herself for cultivation. After just over two years, she achieved liberation through the corpse.

*The Kinship of the Three* states: ‘It is like standing a pole to see its shadow, or calling into a valley to hear its echo’—truly no exaggeration. Among the disciples of Master Ke, there was one named Sun Jifu, nearly sixty years of age. Upon receiving his master’s transmission, he practiced day and night with unwavering diligence. In just three months, the foundation of his elixir was laid; after another six months, he reverted to a youthful body. From the initial commencement of practice to completing the Great Celestial Cycle, only nine months had passed. Thereafter, ten months of nurturing the embryo allowed him to attain the ‘mind-generated body,’ achieving effortless liberation. As for the final stage of returning to emptiness, it may take as little as two or three years, or as long as eight or nine, to reach the state of the original, empty essence.

Thus, with wholehearted devotion to the Dao, one may attain accomplishment in three years and perfect realization in nine. As recorded in *Marvelous Encounters in the Sea and Mountains* in *The Grass Hut’s Own Record*: ‘Two years after Master Zhong’s departure, I resided in the Zhongnan Mountains, diligently refining the Golden Elixir of the Nine Returns. After nine cycles, the work was complete, and in ten months, my spirit was whole.’ This shows that Lü Zu completed the Great Return and attained the perfection of the embryo within two years. Furthermore, *Records of Immortal Traces* states that Lü Zu, from the age of sixty-nine to seventy-three, completed the Great Dao of returning to emptiness. This further confirms that Lü Zu’s cultivation spanned only seven years.

*Zhuangzi*’s ‘Parables’ records: ‘Yan Chengzi You said to Dongguo Zi Qi: “Since I heard your teachings, in one year I became rustic; in two, I followed; in three, I penetrated; in four, I harmonized with things; in five, they came to me; in six, spirits entered; in seven, heaven was accomplished; in eight, I knew neither death nor life; in nine, I attained the great mystery.”’ Liezi, too, described his own cultivation and realization, which took nine years to transform. Examining the ancients and verifying with recent evidence, those who cultivate the Dao with diligence may, within three to nine years, attain the supreme state of spirit.

For those burdened with demanding duties, the key lies in stealing moments of leisure amid busyness to regulate the spirit and breath. As the ancient worthies said: ‘Steal leisure amid busyness to refine the external medicine.’ This precisely conveys the essence. If daytime offers no opportunity for practice, one may cultivate during sleep at night. Fall asleep with mind and breath interdependent, and upon waking, resume the practice. Alternating between sleep and practice throughout the night brings the return of spring to the world, yielding no small benefit. This is the method of ‘using sleep to preserve the true,’ a path that follows in the footsteps of the immortal Chen Tuan of Huashan, and aligns with the sage Confucius’ wisdom of ‘entering rest at dusk.’ Truly, it is the sole cultivation method for those entangled in worldly affairs.

**44. The Benefits of Learning the Dao**

Zhou Dunyi of the Song dynasty wrote in *The Comprehensive Book*: ‘In the realm of heaven and earth, the most revered is the Dao, the most noble is virtue, and the rarest is humanity. Among humans, the rarest is one who embodies the Dao and virtue.’ The Old Sage said: ‘Thus, though one may establish the Son of Heaven and appoint the Three Dukes, even offering large jades preceded by teams of four horses, it is not as good as sitting and advancing in this Dao.’ Mañjuśrī Bodhisattva declared: ‘If one sits in stillness for a single moment, it surpasses building pagodas of the seven treasures as numerous as the Ganges’ sands. Though those pagodas will eventually crumble to dust, a single thought of stillness attains right awakening.’ Layman Pang said: ‘The world cherishes treasures, but I value a single instant. Gold in abundance disturbs the mind, while stillness reveals the true nature of suchness.’ He also said: ‘The supreme matter in the world is nothing stronger than cultivating the Dao. If one awakens to the principle of non-arising, the three realms naturally vanish.’ The Perfected One of Purple Yang stated: ‘Merely coveting profit, rank, and glory, one fails to notice the gradual withering of the body. I ask: though gold be piled as high as mountains, can impermanence be bought to not come?’

All glory, wealth, and honor vanish in an instant, belonging to the impermanent. Only the learning of the Dao transcends the forging of yin and yang, liberates from the suffering of the cycle of birth and death, and eternally enjoys the bliss of non-action and true purity—unmatched by any worldly fame or achievement. Thus, the ancients said: ‘Three years of diligence, ten thousand kalpas of bliss.’ Even for beginners, the practice brings serenity to body and mind, harmony to the breath, regulates life, reduces suffering, halts worldly toil, eradicates chronic ailments, saves on medical expenses, and cuts costs for clothing and food (when qi is full, one does not crave food; when qi is sufficient, one does not fear the cold). It yields the effects of peace, longevity, and carefree ease, with all meridians flowing smoothly and the body and mind light and vigorous. The self-enjoyment far surpasses that of ordinary people.

In recent times, as the world’s population grows and prices rise, life becomes increasingly arduous. Without turning toward emptiness to harness the primordial yang qi of the void and supplement material insufficiencies, enhancing human health, it is difficult to find an appropriate remedy. For while material supplements material, material will eventually be exhausted. Only the void is boundless, and true qi inexhaustible. As long as a single breath remains, one can regulate the breath and concentrate the spirit, returning externally and reverting internally. It requires only willingness, not expense. Thus, this Dao is accessible to all, regardless of poverty or wealth, wisdom or folly, age or youth. All may engage in cultivation according to their capacity, gaining benefits that regulate life’s deficiencies and reduce spiritual suffering. Truly, nothing is more fitting than this.”

Minerals are the treasures of the earth; primordial yang qi is the treasure of heaven, the treasure of the void. Earth’s treasures are finite, while heaven’s treasures are infinite. Earth’s treasures can only nourish the physical body, whereas heaven’s treasures nourish both the physical body and the wisdom-life of the Dharma-body. Those Western scholars who study science and mining, developing the earth’s treasures—how can they compare to the ancient sages of the East, who studied the Dao and thus unlocked the far subtler treasures of the void? The Old Sage said: “Only the Dao is good at lending and completing.” What is this lending? It is the bestowal of the primordial One Qi. The master who so generously lends is none other than the void before one’s very eyes, near and effortless. If we can rest our breathing at the heart of the void, entering the state of profound obscurity, this master will naturally lend us the primordial One Qi. It makes the weak strong, the ordinary sagely, the foolish wise, the sick healed, the withered flourishing, the feeble robust, the blocked unobstructed, the cold clothed, and the hungry fed—fulfilling every wish. The method is utterly simple and easy; its effects are divinely swift. Even the foolish and unworthy can know and practice it—is this not a matter of resolving all with one stroke, universally and equally? True Man Sanfeng said: “When one nurtures spirit and qi, spirit becomes the master that gathers qi. Gather one part qi, and you gain one part treasure; gather ten parts qi, and you gain ten parts treasure. Qi is so precious that in the world, even a hundred taels of gold or jade cannot exchange for a single part.” Thus, the study of qi-transformation in the Mystery School has always unfolded before the seamless pagoda, woven within the cave of emptiness, dwelled in the palace of the Void King, and rested beneath the shadowless tree—gathering primordial yang and assembling the precelestial. Harnessing the true One Qi to defend and nourish body and mind, transforming mortal bones, dissolving the yin of consciousness, instantly ceasing worldly toil, transcending life and death, and forever avoiding the three calamities, it is the teaching that awakens the latent potential of the Chinese people. It can resolve present hardships and eternally preserve boundless ease—why would one not strive to practice it?

Master Qianxu’s *Profound Insight into the Dao De Jing* says in verse:
At the hundred-fathom shoal, he casts his line alone;
No need to seek the ferry to the Peach Blossom Spring.
When the dragon in the sea’s depths stirs to wake,
A night of wind and thunder brings spring to the earth.

**45. Subtle Analogies of Fire-Timing**
*Zhuangzi* inherits the profound and subtle essence of the Old Sage’s double mystery, unlocking the wonders of the Dao without being bound by conventional forms. In this collection, I have repeatedly distilled its essentials. Here, I gather ten subtle analogies of fire-timing for those who study the *Nanhua Jing* to explore deeply.

**1. The Butcher Carving an Ox**
The *Essentials of Nurturing Life* says: When Cook Ding carved an ox for Lord Wenhui, wherever his hand touched, his shoulder leaned, his foot stepped, or his knee pressed, the sounds were crisp and resonant. His blade moved with a *huo* sound, all in perfect rhythm, matching the dance of *Sanglin* and the cadence of *Jingshou*. Lord Wenhui exclaimed: “Ah! Excellent!”

“Has your skill truly reached such heights?” Cook Ding laid down his blade and replied: “What your servant delights in is the Dao—progress beyond mere skill. When I first began carving oxen, all I saw was the ox itself. After three years, I no longer saw the whole ox. Now, I meet it with my spirit rather than my eyes; my senses halt while my spirit moves. I follow the natural grain, cleave the great gaps, guide the blade through the great hollows, and rely on what is inherently so. I have never touched the tendons or ligaments, much less the great bones. A good cook changes his blade every year—he cuts. An ordinary cook changes it every month—he hacks. My blade has lasted nineteen years, carving thousands of oxen, yet its edge is as if newly whetted. The joints have spaces, and the blade has no thickness. With what has no thickness entering where there is space, there is ample room for the blade to play. Thus, after nineteen years, my blade remains as if newly whetted. Nevertheless, whenever I encounter a complex joint, I see the difficulty, grow cautious, focus my gaze, slow my movements, and move the blade with utmost subtlety—until the ox falls apart like earth crumbling to the ground. Then I stand, blade in hand, look around, and savor the moment with full satisfaction before wiping the blade clean and putting it away.” Lord Wenhui said: “Excellent! From Cook Ding’s words, I have learned how to nurture life.”

This passage subtly illustrates the fire-timing of the celestial cycle. The ox is an analogy for the physical body, and the blade’s edge represents the razor-sharp union of heart and breath. At the outset of practice, one cannot yet attain emptiness and spontaneity; the sense of the body remains, and movement is hindered—hence, “all I saw was the ox itself.” Once skill is perfected, body and mind are both forgotten, and the physical body becomes empty—thus, “I no longer saw the whole ox.” The meridians and channels of the human body are often obstructed; when practice reaches great stillness, the external primordial true yang surges through, opening the hundred vessels, and the qi circulates, irrigating above and below. One must follow its natural movement without contrivance. If the true qi ascends along the Governor Vessel and encounters obstruction midway, one may gently employ the *xun* wind to stir it. “Move the blade with utmost subtlety, and the ox falls apart”—this is the original stillness maintained externally. Such is the subtlety of “cleaving the gaps and guiding through the hollows.” The lines “meet it with my spirit rather than my eyes; my senses halt while my spirit moves; I follow the natural grain” reveal that when fire-timing reaches extreme purity and spontaneity, nothing is directed by the self; all is governed by the primordial spirit—this is what is meant by “let it be the master while I am the guest.” The four characters “spirit meets, spirit moves” are most profound, for the true primordial state admits no contrivance. Even the slightest intentional arrangement would no longer be “spirit moving.” Thus, the Perfected One of Purple Yang said: “There is a natural true fire-timing,” and also: “Simply rest the spirit and breath, and follow what is natural.” The Dao of Heaven operates the sun and moon in emptiness; the method of the Elixir observes the Dao of Heaven and likewise operates in emptiness. Cook Ding merely used a blade without thickness to enter the spaces of the joints, causing the ox to fall apart like earth crumbling—this, too, is the subtlety of emptiness. Emptiness and spontaneity are the master keys of fire-timing. The Classic states: “The wonder of spontaneity lies in knowing, yet its source of wonder lies in unknowing.” Thus, knowing yet being without knowledge is the ultimate principle of spontaneity.

**2. The Hunchback Catching Cicadas**
The *Attaining Life* chapter says: Confucius traveled to Chu and, passing through a forest, saw a hunchback (an old man with a bent back) catching cicadas as easily as if picking them up. Confucius asked: “Is your skill so refined? Or do you have a method?” The man replied: “I have a method.”

In the fifth or sixth month, if I stack two pellets and they fall, I miss by a mere fraction; if I stack three and they do not fall, I miss one in ten; if I stack five and they do not fall, it is as effortless as picking them up. My stance is as steady as a withered stump, my arm as still as a dead tree’s branch. Though heaven and earth are vast and the myriad things manifold, I attend only to the cicada’s wings. I neither turn nor sway, nor do I let the myriad things distract me from the cicada’s wings—how could I fail to catch them?”

Confucius turned to his disciples and said: “When the mind is undivided, it coalesces into spirit—is this not what the hunchbacked elder means?” This passage reveals the subtlety of fire-timing, which lies in mastery through naturalness, entering the realm of divine transformation. It belongs to the primordial, not something that can be achieved by deliberate effort or contrivance in the postnatal realm.

“The mind undivided coalesces into spirit”—these two lines are the crux. To coalesce into spirit is to seem as though acted upon by divine illumination, beyond the reach of human effort.

**3. The Ferryman Steering the Boat**
The *Attaining Life* chapter states: Yan Hui asked Confucius, “I once crossed the abyssal depths of Shangshen. The ferryman steered the boat as if by magic. I asked him: ‘Can one learn to steer a boat?’ He replied: ‘Yes. Those skilled at swimming can learn quickly. As for divers, they can handle a boat the first time they see one.’ I pressed him further, but he would not explain. May I ask what this means?”

Confucius said: “Those skilled at swimming can learn quickly because they have forgotten the water. As for divers who can handle a boat the first time they see one—it is because they see the depths as though they were dry land, and a capsized boat as no different from a cart rolling backward. Though a thousand overturnings and reversals unfold before them, they do not enter their minds. Where could they find no leisure?”

This passage reveals that the crucial fire-phase lies in the word "forgetting"—forgetting leads to transformation. Once transformed and in communion, it is as the *Book of Changes* says of the Kun hexagram: "Without practice, there is nothing unprofitable," just as the diver (one who dwells at the water’s bottom) can steer a boat the first time he sees one. When mind and breath interdepend, one can cross the great sea of birth and death—this is the supreme Dharma-boat. To steer this boat, one must reach the state of mutual forgetting, only then entering the realm of transformation. When the forgetting of concentration reaches its extreme, responses and actions all abide in samadhi, yet this does not hinder handling affairs. Whether in concentration or not, one does not know; whether acting or not, nothing obstructs—just like the diver steering the boat.

Ah, how wondrous!

---

Four: *Ziqing Carves a Ju*
The "Attaining Life" chapter of the *Zhuangzi* states: "Ziqing carved wood into a *ju* (a musical instrument). When the *ju* was finished, those who saw it marveled as if it were the work of ghosts or spirits. The Lord of Lu saw it and asked, ‘What technique did you use to make it?’ Ziqing replied, ‘I am but a craftsman—what technique could I possess? Yet there is one thing...’"

When I prepare to carve a *ju*, I never dare expend my *qi*, but must fast to quiet my mind. After fasting for three days, I no longer dare entertain thoughts of rewards, ranks, or emoluments. After five days, I no longer dare entertain thoughts of praise or blame, skill or clumsiness. After seven days, I suddenly forget that I possess four limbs and a physical form. At this time, I am no longer aware of the court or state; my skill becomes concentrated, and external distractions dissolve. Only then do I enter the mountain forests to observe the natural forms and structures of trees—perfect in their inherent nature. Only then does the *ju* appear before me; only then do I set my hand to it—otherwise, I would not proceed. Thus, it is by aligning the heavenly with the heavenly that the instrument seems to partake of the numinous. Is this not the reason?"

This passage hinges on the fasting of the mind and sitting in forgetfulness. As inner cultivation deepens, external distractions dissipate; *qi* becomes abundant and spirit whole. In movement, it follows the course of heaven; in stillness, it abides in profound silence. Aligning with the natural rhythm without calculation or deliberation—this is what is meant by "aligning the heavenly with the heavenly." In this way, one merges imperceptibly with the great transformation, far beyond the reach of thought and measure.

Five: *Ji Sheng Raises Fighting Cocks*
The "Attaining Life" chapter of the *Zhuangzi* states: Ji Shengzi was raising fighting cocks for the king. After ten days, the king asked, "Are the cocks ready?" He replied, "Not yet. They are still hollow and arrogant, relying on their *qi*." After another ten days, the king asked again, and he replied, "Not yet. They still respond to shadows and movements." After another ten days, the king asked again, and he replied, "Not yet. Their gaze is still fierce, and their *qi* remains excessive." After another ten days, the king asked again, and he replied, "Nearly so. Though other cocks may crow, they show no change. They appear like wooden cocks—their *virtue* is complete. No other cock dares respond; they turn and flee instead."

This passage in the *Zhuangzi* originally derives from the *Liezi*.

The image of the wooden cock is one of facing phenomena without attachment, motionless as wood, with the firing process perfectly complete and all emotions extinguished. As the Perfected One of Purple Yang said: "Body and mind are still and unmoving." And the Perfected One of Qing’an said: "Nature is still, emotions are empty, and the mind does not stir." Both express this very meaning. Only upon reaching such a state may one safely practice the seven-day Great Celestial Circuit without peril.

Layman Pang said:
*"Simply be without mind toward the myriad things,
What harm if the myriad things constantly encircle you?
The iron ox fears not the lion’s roar,
Just as the wooden man meets flowers and birds.
The wooden man’s essence is itself without emotion,
Flowers and birds encountering him are not startled.
When mind and realm are thus, this alone suffices—
Why worry the bodhi Dao will not be attained?"*

The wooden man of the Chan school and the wooden cock of the Mystery school may be said to be without peer yet perfectly paired, encompassing and resonating with one another—both embodying the wondrous principle of forgetting scheming and stilling thoughts, of suchness and immovability.

When Ancestor Lü was refining the Great Return on Mount Zhongnan, demonic lights appeared ten times, yet his mind remained unmoved. This is proof that Ancestor Lü’s firing process had truly reached the level of the wooden cock. Thus, Master Yuchan said: "Facing phenomena without mind is the Great Return." At this stage of the firing process, one can only exclaim: "Behold, perfection!"

---

**VI. Lü’s Treading of Water**

The "Attaining Life" chapter states: Confucius observed the Lü Liang waterfall, where the torrent plunged thirty *ren* and its froth surged forty *li*, a place where soft-shelled turtles, alligators, fish, and turtles could not swim. He saw a man swimming there and, thinking him in distress and seeking death, sent his disciples downstream to rescue him. After several hundred paces, the man emerged, his hair unbound, singing as he strolled beneath the embankment.

Confucius followed and questioned him, saying: "I took you for a ghost, but upon closer inspection, you are a man. May I ask if there is a Dao to treading water?"
The man replied: "No, I have no Dao. I begin with my origins, grow with my nature, and complete with my destiny. I enter with the swirling waters and emerge with the rushing currents, following the Way of water without imposing my own will—this is how I tread it."
Confucius asked: "What do you mean by beginning with origins, growing with nature, and completing with destiny?"
The man said: "I was born on the hills and am at ease on the hills—this is my origin. I grew up in water and am at ease in water—this is my nature. I do not know why I am thus, yet I am thus—this is my destiny."

This chapter on the firing process reveals the character of *ān* (ease). In ease, one follows the natural course of one’s nature without admixture of artifice or pretense. In ease, one moves with unhurried leisure, free from the slightest trace of calculation. In ease, body and mind are both forgotten, merging completely with the surroundings—thus, there is no obstruction. As for the phrase, *"I do not know why I am thus, yet I am thus,"* here the subtlety is exhausted and effort forgotten, beyond all description.

Lu Fanghu said: "This resembles the analogy of the diver steering a boat. The water that swirls inward is called *qí*, and the water that surges outward is called *gǔ*. It speaks of water having its own constant course; if one follows it in rising and sinking without imposing one’s own will, one may attain fulfillment. *'Born on the hills and at ease on the hills; growing up in water and at ease in water'*—simply observe the character *ān* (ease). All is in accord with nature, and one does not know why it is so. This is the meaning of acting according to one’s station without seeking elsewhere, finding contentment in every circumstance. Here, amid perilous undertakings, is casually revealed a teaching of dwelling in ease. Wondrous! Wondrous indeed!"

"Now, according to my examination, the *Xugua Zhuan* of the *Book of Changes* states: *'After return comes peace; thus it is followed by "Peace."*’ Mencius said: *'When Yu guided the waters, he followed their course without interference.'* When the firing process reaches the state of emptiness and spontaneity, yet one knows not how it is so—like Zhang and Shen steering a boat, following their course without interference—then the wonder defies all description.

The old fisherman is at ease in water and treads upon water; the Daoist must be at ease in emptiness and tread upon emptiness, merging with the void. Then body and mind are unimpeded: treading water as if it were land, treading land as if it were water, entering metal and stone, ascending into empty space—all is effortless.

7. Dongye Excels at Driving
The *Chapter on Attaining Life* states: Dongye Ji presented his driving skills to Duke Zhuang of Song. His advances and retreats aligned with the plumb line, his left and right turns matched the compass. The Duke believed no decorative pattern could surpass this and had him trace a hundred hooks before returning. Yan He encountered him and, entering the court, said: *'Ji’s horses are about to fail.'* The Duke remained silent and did not respond. Soon after, the horses indeed failed and returned. The Duke asked: *'How did you know?'* He replied: *'Their strength was exhausted, yet he still demanded more—hence I said they would fail.'* This passage likewise illustrates the firing process of spontaneity."

Straight as the plumb line, round as the compass, weaving and turning with the marvel of brocade’s reversible patterns. For mastery begets skill, and in driving one ascends to the divine. The *Book of Changes* states: *"Refine principle to the utmost, that it may be applied."* Is this not profoundly so? A hundred hooks and back—the horses’ strength could not endure, hence their failure. Yet this was not Dongye Ji’s fault; rather, it demonstrates that use must not be exhausted, for exhaustion leads to failure.

8. Gongchui’s Turning Craft
The *Chapter on Attaining Life* states: Gongchui’s turning surpassed compass and square (盖 here means "to exceed." It refers to his hands’ rotation alone, his skill surpassing the tools, reaching the pinnacle of precision). His fingers merged with the object, his mind unburdened by deliberation, so his spirit was unified and unshackled. Forget the feet, for the shoes fit perfectly; forget the waist, for the belt sits comfortably. To forget right and wrong is the mind’s ease; neither inwardly altered nor outwardly swayed is the ease of timely action. To begin with ease and never depart from it is the ease of forgetting ease.

Lu Fanghu said: *"This speaks of the marvel of pure spontaneity. Observe how he discusses ‘merging’—this is what the sages call ‘following the heart’s desire without overstepping the bounds.’ Gongchui shaped vessels without compass or square, merely rotating the object by hand to form perfect circles. The mention of ‘square’ merely completes the phrase. At that moment, his fingers merged with the object, his mind entirely unengaged—hence the words: ‘not deliberating with the mind.’ Though he did not deliberate, his mind was nonetheless present, simply unified and unconstrained. Had his focus been divided even slightly, even mastery would not have sufficed to form the circle. In learning, nothing is more feared than a divided mind or an overactive one. A divided mind leads to distraction and lack of precision; an overactive mind clings to things and fails to merge. Only the unified and unshackled can enter the marvelous. In *Zhuangzi*, even the most refined passages, every word and phrase, conceal profound meaning."*

I say: Gongchui’s firing process had entered the realm of transformation, yet it still drew strength from the word "forgetting." The firing process of returning cinnabar is the same—only when one attains Gongchui’s spontaneity can one reach the wondrous realm of the primordial, entering divine transformation. This is what the ancients meant by: *"With no intent toward Chan, there is nothing that is not Chan."*

9. Liezi Practices Archery
The *Chapter on Tian Zifang* states: Lie Yukou shot for Bo Hunwu Ren, drawing the bow to its fullest and placing a cup of water on his elbow. He loosed the arrows, and each successive shaft fitted into the nock of the previous one. At that moment, he was like a wooden figure. Bo Hunwu Ren said: *"This is the archery of archery, not the archery of non-archery. Let us ascend a high mountain, tread upon perilous rocks, and stand at the edge of a hundred-fathom abyss—could you shoot then?"* Thereupon, Wu Ren climbed the high mountain, trod upon the perilous rocks, stood at the edge of the hundred-fathom abyss, his back turned and hesitant, with two-tenths of his feet hanging over the edge. He beckoned Yukou forward. Yukou prostrated himself on the ground, sweat streaming to his heels. Bo Hunwu Ren said: *"The perfected person gazes above into the azure sky, delves below into the yellow springs, roams to the eight limits, yet their spirit and qi remain unchanged. Now you tremble with fear in your eyes—your aim is already imperiled!"*

This chapter on *huohou* (firing times) demonstrates the stabilization of spirit in profound tranquility, where external phenomena do not intrude and both emotions and perceptions are forgotten. Only then can one gather the great elixir and perform the seven-day completion of the grand celestial cycle.

When Liezi trembled in fear, it was evident that his human heart had not yet perished. The "archery of non-archery" is the forgetting of achievement. To enter the state of effortless operation—this is the highest level of *huohou*.

**10. The Painter’s Unfettered Posture**
The *Tian Zifang* chapter of the *Zhuangzi* states: The Lord of Song wished to have a painting made, and all the painters arrived. They received his bow, stood at attention, moistened their brushes, and ground their ink—half of them remained outside. One painter arrived late, strolling leisurely without haste. He received the bow but did not stand; instead, he went to his lodging. The lord sent someone to observe him, and there he was, stripped of his robes, sitting cross-legged and bare. The lord said: *"This is the true painter."*

The commentary explains: His leisurely stroll without haste was walking meditation, what the Perfected One of Double Yang called: *"Let your feet go wherever they will; let your spirit always follow the qi."* Sitting cross-legged and stripped of robes—this was also seated meditation. Calming the spirit and regulating the breath, he had no concern for painting, yet the painting was already complete. How wondrous!

Zhuangzi’s writings truly convey the Dao, and here they contain a distinct Chan mechanism—stillness, stillness, no need for words. The other painters, moistening brushes and grinding ink, were all entangled in the workings of the discriminating mind. Even if they produced a fine painting, it would be but a dead thing. Better to sit cross-legged, stripped of robes, concentrating the spirit and regulating the breath, utterly unmoving—a naturally living arhat. The intent precedes the painting; the body itself preaches the Dharma. No wonder the Lord of Song called him the *"true painter."* This is also a veiled metaphor.

The above ten passages describe varying depths of *huohou*. What must be noted is that most contain the principle of *"concealing the spirit and guarding the qi"* and the practice of *"preserving the spirit and nurturing the nature."* Gradually, when body and mind become unmoving and one forgets both self and environment, one enters the wondrous realm of spiritual transformation. Only then can one achieve perfect freedom and respond with effortless mastery.

**46. The Secret of Subduing Demons**
In *Journey to the West*, among all the demonic beings, the Red Boy possesses the greatest divine powers and the strongest magical abilities—this represents the postnatal deviant fire. Later, the Bodhisattva Guanyin cast down three rings and subdued him. Though called three rings, there were in fact only two: above, *Qian* (Heaven), below, *Kun* (Earth), with the central emptiness as the third—a state where the heart and breath are placed externally, relying on true emptiness. Merely casting down these three rings subdues all demonic beings. Their immense efficacy can thus be imagined.

Whenever postnatal impurities stir or heavenly demons arise, one need only externally unite heart and breath. When true emptiness is attained, all will be at peace. This *"Samadhi of Subduing Demons through the Great Void"* is the most transcendent method.

**Excerpt from Master Wang’s Record (from the *Secret Record of Alchemical Instructions by the Body-Realized Mountain Man*):**
In *Journey to the West*, the Red Boy represents the postnatal deviant fire, the false yang on both sides of the *Li* trigram. The Black Wind Demon represents postnatal yin essence, the false yang on both sides of the *Kan* trigram. When these two wield their powers, they nearly kill Sun Wukong—how formidable! Without Guanyin’s single ring cast down, they could not be subdued. But once you enter the external emptiness, the Black Wind Demon naturally vanishes, and the Red Boy transforms into Sudhana, ceasing his mischief.

**47. The Wondrous Realm of Harmonious Equilibrium**
When the firing times of heaven and humanity align without error, various transformations arise in the physical body, which can be broadly summarized in the term *"harmonious equilibrium."* As Master Cui’s *Mirror for Ingesting the Medicine* states: *"The prenatal qi, the postnatal breath—those who attain them are ever as if intoxicated."* The *Preface to the Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* says: *"The pores rise like one just bathed; the bones and channels are as if in deep slumber; the spirit and essence unite like lovers in joy; the hun and po cling like mother and child."* This is one example of the realm of harmonious equilibrium.

However, one must understand that as practice advances, the wondrous realm of harmonious equilibrium also changes accordingly. There is the harmonious equilibrium of the minor celestial cycle, the grand celestial cycle, the seven-day completion of the grand celestial cycle, and the harmonious equilibrium during the nurturing of the embryo—these cannot be generalized.

Focusing on the minor celestial cycle: when the entire body is supremely soft and blissful, this transforms into a state of numbness throughout. Numbness is the profound realm of harmonious equilibrium, and there is an even deeper state beyond it. At this stage, one must verify it with great samadhi.

Wang Qiyun’s *Five Degrees of Harmonious Equilibrium* states: *"Harmonious equilibrium relies entirely on fire to refine the qi, and its effects manifest in five degrees. After three to five years of unshaken stillness, one may suddenly feel a qi ascending to the heart, hearing the sounds of wind, rain, and thunder, with the four limbs and all channels flowing—this is the harmonious equilibrium of ministerial qi, not yet the true Dao. Or after three to five years, one may suddenly hear the sounds of fierce winds, thunderous roars, and war drums, rising to Kunlun and descending to the knees, tasting the five flavors, the tongue producing sweet fluids, the eyes radiating light, and the nose flowing with jade-like essence—this is the harmonious equilibrium of the bladder’s citizen qi. The adept advances further, and other effects appear. After another three to five years, one may again hear the sounds of wind, rain, and thunder, with the hot qi of the elixir field spiraling upward, gradually ascending. This qi travels from behind the kidneys to Caoxi, rising to Kunlun. Sweet fluids are again produced, ascending like ghee to anoint the crown, descending like ambrosia to sprinkle the heart. The eyes flash with lightning-like brilliance—this is the flying golden essence behind the elbows."*

The adept who proceeds to this stage and advances further will encounter yet other signs of progress. Should they dwell in stillness for three to five years, they may hear within the roar of thunder and the sound of tearing silk in the abdomen. The qi resides behind the kidneys, striking the Weilu acupoint, passing through the Jade Pillar Gate, piercing the Niwan Palace and the Kunlun summit. The sound resembles a fierce wind tearing at the earth, while the surging qi descends like a cold spring. This is the Mysterious Pearl descending into the Elixir Palace, where at times the azure sky appears, or moonlight, or white snow, arrayed in the void. Sometimes dragons and tigers intertwine in harmony, or the sun and moon exchange palaces. Though such transformations occur, the adept presses onward, and after another two or three years, new signs emerge, arising from the Supreme Unity, the Primordial Sovereign. The Supreme Unity is the northern Ren and Gui waters, ascending to the Niwan Palace and descending to the Yongquan point. Again, the ears hear the clash of a thousand battle drums and the rumble of ten thousand thunderclaps, like a fierce wind tearing at the earth—this is the great ocean’s release, a thorough ascent and descent, all ablaze with crimson. The fire of the celestial cycle ignites, and the entire body, from head to toe, aches as if the bones are shattered and the sinews pierced. The four limbs and hundred vessels flow without obstruction, the bones seeming to break apart. One may lose awareness for three to five days, reopening the primordial chaos to reestablish heaven and earth. This is the fire of the celestial cycle, the harmony of heaven and earth, the exchange of sun and moon palaces, the transformation of mulberry fields into vast seas. At this stage of practice, ascension is certain—this is the end returning to the beginning, the changing of bones and drawing out of sinews, the Great Harmony.

Master Qiyun’s discourse may be cross-referenced with Zhang Sanfeng’s *On the Verification of Returning*. The final stage he describes corresponds to the seven-day completion of the great celestial cycle, which Sanfeng elucidates in even greater detail, serving as the definitive guide for the return in the Mysterious School.

---

**48. The Wondrous Workings of Spontaneity**

*The Mirror of Entering the Medicine* states: "Only with utmost sincerity does one follow spontaneity."
*The Kinship of the Three* says: "What spontaneity does is not the path of deceit or falsehood."
*The Scripture of Yin Conformity* states: "Thus the sage knows the Dao of spontaneity cannot be violated and thereby masters it."
*The Scripture of Great Penetration* says: "Suchness is spontaneous, boundless and without limit."
*The Jade Pivot Scripture* states: "Heaven and earth move by their mechanism, causing people to remain unaware—this is called spontaneity. If they are made to know what they do not know, this too is called spontaneity. The wonder of spontaneity, though wondrous in knowing, arises from what is not known."

Master Xuanjing says: "Not knowing is the forgetting of the heart-mind. All worldly arts and skills, without the utmost application of the heart-mind, cannot attain wonder. The methods beyond the world, without the utmost forgetting of the heart-mind, cannot achieve transformation. Thus the Dao’s method lies in spontaneity—this is the wondrous function of forgetting mechanism, responding without intention, constantly functioning yet constantly absent, difficult to exhaust in words."

Wang Yiqing says: "Spontaneity is that which nothing can make so, and nothing can make otherwise." Thus spontaneity is divine wonder. The divine is that which is divine without one knowing how it is so; the wondrous is that which is wondrous without one knowing how it is so. At its utmost, it cannot be described in words or fathomed by thought. One knows *that* it is so but not *why* it is so; one names *that* which is named but not *why* it is named—where then does the name of spontaneity reside?

The former master said: "The scriptures state: The dual-cultivation practice lies entirely in the fire timing. Huo Yun says: The fire timing follows each stage, all depending on spontaneity. To know spontaneity is to know the twofold heaven and earth, the fourfold yin and yang—this too is spontaneous."

Master Qianxu says: "Spontaneity has a deeper meaning. My teacher instructed me: To follow spontaneity is not to yield to it." I say: When a practitioner’s effort reaches the state of spontaneity, every movement and stillness perfectly aligns with the heart of heaven, allowing no room for the slightest contrivance. If one employs the heart-mind to arrange things, they depart far from spontaneity.

Some may ask: The ancient sages said, "The Dao models itself on spontaneity." Yet the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* states: "Pure awareness is luminous, neither caused nor conditioned, neither spontaneous nor non-spontaneous, neither non-spontaneous nor non-non-spontaneous, free from all affirmations and negations, free from all characteristics, free from all dharmas." This seems to contradict the ancient sages—how can they be reconciled?

I answer: The *Śūraṅgama* refutes the spontaneity of external paths, which is yielding to spontaneity. The spontaneity of the ancient sages is following spontaneity. When attachments are broken, all dharmas are perfectly fused, all suchness is one continuum. The spoken causes and conditions and spontaneity do not depart from the essence and function of self-nature—what hindrance is there?

---

**49. The Essentials of Great Samādhi**

Great samādhi is the interdependence of heart-mind and breath, where external breathing ceases, and spirit and qi settle into stillness. After prolonged samādhi, body and heart-mind become utterly quiescent, forgetting form, forgetting appearance, forgetting things, forgetting concerns. At this time, the primordial true yang penetrates the physical body, cleansing, irrigating, steaming, and nourishing the constructive and defensive qi, permeating the skin and marrow without exception. It renews the old and transforms the coarse into the wondrous—this is called "refining the form in true emptiness."

Thus, for every degree the body and heart-mind attain stillness, emptiness advances by one degree, and primordial true yang advances by one degree. If body and heart-mind attain ten degrees of emptiness, primordial true yang advances by ten degrees. This refinement of qi must be founded upon great samādhi.

Furthermore, for every degree the body and heart-mind attain emptiness, the consciousness-spirit is transformed by one degree. As the consciousness-spirit is transformed by one degree, the primordial spirit manifests by one degree, increasing brightness and dispelling darkness. When the consciousness-spirit is fully transformed, the primordial spirit is fully revealed.

Thus it is said: "When the heart-mind dies, the spirit lives"—this is the essential principle of refining the spirit, and it too must be founded upon great samādhi.

Moreover, when body and heart-mind attain the utmost emptiness and stillness, the form merges with the void, the six directions all become heart-mind, the six harmonies all become body. Pervading and embracing all, fusing without bound, one may manifest responsive transformations at will, with every thought instantly realized. One may simultaneously enter countless buddha-lands, displaying boundless spiritual powers—this is the final stage of "returning to emptiness and merging with the Dao," and it too must be founded upon great samādhi.

The essence of great samādhi is fully expounded in the *Zhuangzi*. As it states: "Fish are born of water, humans are born of the Dao. Those born of water thrive by carving out ponds; those born of the Dao attain birth in samādhi without effort." It also says: "When the cosmos is at peace and settled, celestial radiance arises." And: "Abide in great samādhi." And: "The spirit that arises from instability is not borne by the Dao." Thus, the marvel of attaining the Dao may be encompassed in the single word *samādhi*.

The *Zhuangzi*’s "Human World" chapter states: "Gazing upon that emptiness, the empty chamber generates brightness. Auspiciousness abides in stillness—if one does not abide, this is called sitting while galloping." The esoteric commentary explains: *Que* means emptiness. At the moment of utmost emptiness and profound stillness, when inner and outer are both void, at the cusp of midnight, between the waning and waxing moons, when all sounds are hushed—this is the time of "gazing upon that emptiness." When the empty chamber generates brightness, the first yang returns, and the primordial qi arrives at the palace. *Zhi zhi* refers to great samādhi. To be constantly moving yet constantly still is most auspicious, like a bright mirror reflecting images—responding to things without attachment, illuminating yet still, stillness and illumination as one, movement and stillness undivided. Is this not "auspiciousness abiding in stillness"? If qi stirs while the spirit scatters, one cannot summon the primordial.

The *Great Cavern Sutra* states: "Samādhi and harmony are like clear awareness." And: "At the inception of samādhi, breath is unified; in great harmony, a thousandfold peace. In great samādhi, the true is complete; in wondrous practice, the numinous is communicated." The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* states: "When samādhi reaches its peak, clarity arises; when clarity reaches its peak, awakening is fulfilled." These all describe the phenomenon of wisdom emerging from long samādhi and clarity arising from long stillness.

Li Daochun’s *Zhonghe Collection* presents a pure and correct vision. Upon reading his poems, I find he repeatedly reveals the essentials of great samādhi, displaying a unique insight among alchemical texts. He writes:
*"When body and heart-mind attain stillness,
Congeal the spirit and secure qi and essence.
The body at ease transcends the leaky,
The heart-mind still verifies the unborn."*
And:
*"When body and heart-mind are still, the mysterious teaching flows.
Essence, qi, and spirit empty, naturally merge."*
And:
*"Refining mercury and smelting lead have no fixed time—
The adept must seek them within samādhi."*
And:
*"Attaining the Dao was never difficult—
The work lies solely within samādhi."*
And:
*"Medicinal substances are gathered only from the formless;
The great elixir is wholly forged within samādhi."*
And:
*"Abiding in stillness, unmoving, one accords with the true constant.
Dissolving all yin, yang naturally returns."*
And:
*"The great elixir’s nine returns and seven reversals—
The adept must seek them within samādhi."*
And:
*"If you can maintain samādhi at the proper time,
You will know that noon is the third watch."*
And:
*"When the tide rises, water overflows the banks;
When the wind stills, the river’s heart is free of waves.
Nature still, emotions empty, the heart-mind unmoving—
Sitting without dullness or distraction, sleeping without demons."*

Observe: the phrase *"nature still, emotions empty"* is the true culmination of great samādhi. When refinement reaches this point, no matter what transformations arise in the physical body, all remain utterly still, like the great void. At this stage of the firing process, one may be said to have entered the hall and ascended the chamber. Thus the *Yongjia Song of Realizing the Dao* states: *"Even if an iron wheel spins atop your head, samādhi and wisdom remain perfectly bright, never lost."*

Longmeizi, the true heir of Bai Ziqing, composed the *Poems on Verifying the Golden Elixir*. Lu Zuqianxu wrote a commentary to elucidate them, and the poems also reveal the essentials of stillness and samādhi, as in:
*"Only when stillness reaches its extreme does movement arise—
This is the boundless becoming bounded.
The primordial qi originally emerges from the void;
The two modes must be trusted to revolve within samādhi."*

Qianxu’s commentary states: "Yuanduzi said: The primordial qi arises from the formless. Thus it is said: *The primordial qi originally emerges from the void.* Immortals steal this true mechanism—gathering it in movement, refining it in stillness. Thus the revolving of heaven and earth, the movement of sun and moon, all proceed from samādhi. The word *samādhi* is most pivotal; the beginning and end of alchemical attainment lie solely within it. If one is not settled at the outset, thoughts and circumstances will not fade, and one cannot properly approach the task of tending the furnace and gathering the medicine. If one is not settled at the end, the firing process will not be harmonized, and one cannot achieve the work of liberating the spirit and transforming the embryo. Thus it is said: *The two modes must be trusted to revolve within samādhi.*"

The poem further states:
*"To discern the cauldron’s lead, one must settle within;
When yang fire flees, it is spread below.
Without meeting a true master’s direct instruction,
Where will you resolve the mysterious pivot?"*

Qianxu’s commentary explains: "The qi of the medicinal substances in the cauldron is subtle. To discern it, one must unify the will, settle the thoughts, attain great samādhi of the six senses, and forget both circumstances and emotions. Only then can one gather it without error. When the yang fire arrives, one spreads it below to welcome it. This requires the true teachings of a true master to practice." Since the words of the Eastern School’s founding patriarch are thus, the Western School’s transmission, which takes *"great samādhi and true emptiness"* as the secret essentials of elixir-making, is all the more credible and attested.

Thus, Master Wang once said: "The methods of the elixir all return to a single word—*ding* (定, samādhi/settling). This is what is called the Way of utmost simplicity and ease." Yet though this be so, to attain true *ding*, one must forget both body and mind, still all emotions and circumstances. Without a measure of bitter effort, how could *ding* be so easily spoken of?

The *Zhuangzi*’s "Knowledge Wanders North" chapter states: "Guangyao asked Wu You, ‘Master, do you exist? Or do you not exist?’ Wu You did not respond. (These five characters are missing in the received text and have been supplied from the *Huainanzi* to complete the meaning.) Guangyao, unable to obtain an answer, observed Wu You’s appearance: it was profound and empty. He gazed at him all day but saw nothing, listened but heard nothing, grasped but could not seize him. Guangyao said, ‘This is perfection! Who could attain such a state? I can attain non-being from being, yet I cannot attain non-being from non-being. How could one reach this from non-existence?’" This passage from the *Zhuangzi* depicts the state of *"great samādhi and true emptiness"* with divine subtlety. When one is asked and Wu You does not respond, and the practitioner abides in *ding*, even after seven days of completing the great celestial cycle of firing times, such phenomena may arise. Thus, Cao Wenyi’s *Song of the Great Way* says: "To apply effort in such leisurely stillness—how could it compare to calmly cultivating great *ding*?"

**Fifty. The Wondrous Function of Killing Life**
The *Zhuangzi* states: "Those who kill life do not die; those who give life do not live." Master An of Lingyan said: "One must know that within killing lies liberation, and within living hides the mechanism. Neither buddhas nor patriarchs can fathom it." Layman Pang said: "To protect life, one must use killing; only when killing is complete can one dwell in peace. Grasping the meaning within, an iron boat floats upon the water." Pure Yang said: "That which lives does not live; that which dies does not die. To kill life after it has arisen, and to learn death before dying—this is long life." A monk asked Caoshan: "Is not a śramaṇa one who possesses great compassion?" Caoshan replied: "Yes." "If the six thieves suddenly arrive, what then?" Caoshan said: "One must also possess great compassion." The monk asked: "How does one possess great compassion?" Caoshan said: "With a single sword, sweep them all away." The monk asked: "After they are swept away, what then?" Caoshan said: "Only then is harmony attained."

Long ago, Chan Master Shigong, before leaving the household, entered the mountains to hunt. Passing by Master Mazu’s hermitage, Mazu asked him: "Why not shoot yourself?" The purport of "shooting oneself" is the secret purport of killing life. "Those who kill life do not die"—this is the wondrous function of the heart dying and the spirit living. Reviving after absolute cessation, attaining life within death—both Chan and Daoist schools are thus. In the Daoist school, when the heart and breath interdepend, this is the sword of wisdom. When the six thieves arrive, sever them in two with a single blade, leaving no residual attachment. Externally, when breath and qi attain great *ding*, and internally, when not a single thought arises in the center, with inner and outer purity and emptiness—this is the moment of "harmony."

Whenever practicing the work, if one becomes aware of any phenomenon in the body, swiftly turn outward to interdepend, without the slightest attachment—this is the wondrous secret of killing life. With prolonged practice, when one becomes aware of any phenomenon in the body, one will naturally and effortlessly depart from the physical form and settle outside, thus forever eliminating the maladies of seminal and qi leakage.

Thus, one who truly kills life can truly attain long life. This is the function of reversing the flow, entering the unshakable ground, transcending the ordinary to realize the real—what Chan calls "cutting off the flow." When the flow of life and death is severed, is this not liberation? This is the wondrous realization of non-birth and the wondrous fruit of long life. Without the wondrous mechanism of cutting off the flow and killing life, how could one attain stillness?

One might object: "You are a scholar of the Daoist school—how can you recklessly advocate killing life? Now you even teach others to kill life. What is the meaning of this?" I reply: "Previously, I spoke of killing life in the conventional sense—merely knowing how to slaughter living beings to nourish this physical form, which only increases karmic conditions and offers no benefit to the Way. This should be abandoned. Here, I speak of killing life by reversing the flow—emptying this physical form and heart, severing the flow of life-and-death thoughts, and emerging from the five skandhas. This is the work of transcending the ordinary and entering sagehood. The difference between following the current and reversing it is as vast as heaven and earth—how can they be mentioned in the same breath?"

Should a beginner inquire, "What method should one adopt to attain the state of 'killing to the utmost and dwelling in tranquility'?" I would answer: "At all hours of the day and night, whenever the slightest wandering thought, stray念, or desire arises, swiftly turn outward to unite mind and breath. During practice, if the slightest stirring of external yang, or sensations of softness, pleasure, numbness, or pulsation occur, the moment you become aware, immediately depart from the body and unite mind and breath externally. When this union becomes effortless, inner and outer naturally harmonize, the six thieves vanish, and body and mind become light and vigorous—this is the secret to 'killing to the utmost and dwelling in tranquility,' the essential principle of refining the self."

51. The Profound Meaning of Thrift and Restraint
The ancient sage said: "In governing people and serving Heaven, nothing surpasses thrift. Only through thrift can one return early; early return is called accumulating virtue. With accumulated virtue, there is nothing one cannot overcome; with nothing one cannot overcome, none can fathom one’s limits. When none can fathom one’s limits, one may possess the state. Having the mother of the state, one may endure long—this is the Dao of deep roots and firm stems, the Way of long life and enduring vision."

Here, "thrift" does not mean stinginess or withholding, but rather not being swept away by things, the state of the six roots being free from leakage. Leakage is the meaning of "dissipation." The eye, drawn by forms, is led astray; the ear, by sounds, is led astray; the nose, by fragrances, is led astray. Everywhere, one follows the flow of the six dusts, and with movement within, essence is shaken. When essence is exhausted and spirit departs, life follows—thus the ancient sage said: "Were I to have even a little knowledge, in walking the great Dao, I would fear dissipation above all."

Non-leakage is the meaning of "thrift." When the six roots are firmly stabilized and do not follow the six dusts—sounds, forms, and the rest—spirit and qi settle and overflow, the Great Harmony fills and abounds, and brightness endures day and night—this is called "early return." The Way of long life and enduring vision lies precisely here. Thus, the *Cantong Qi* says:
*"The three treasures—ear, eye, and mouth—
Close and seal, do not let them open.
The true person hides in the deep abyss,
Floating and wandering, guarding the compass within."*
And again:
*"Depart from qi, receive the camp and guard,
Kan ceases to use hearing,
Dui unites without speech,
Rare words follow the primal chaos.
When these three are secured,
Relax the body in an empty chamber,
Entrust the will to emptiness,
Take no-thought as the constant."*
And again:
*"Firmly seal their meetings,
Strive to make them complete and strong."*
And again:
*"Close and seal the Dui,
Fortify the numinous root,
The three lights sink into obscurity,
Warmly nurture the child-pearl."*
And again:
*"Can one be careless?
The first principle of governance
Is to grasp the subtle and secret."*
All these are the workings of the word "thrift." In sum, thrift is the wondrous principle of concentrating spirit and securing qi, the six roots firmly stabilized, not chasing after the six dusts. As the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says: "Reverse the flow to perfect unity, the six functions cease." *Zhuangzi* says: "Be cautious within, close off without." The *Book of Changes* says: "Guard against evil and preserve sincerity." *The Analects* says: "Look not at what is contrary to ritual; listen not to what is contrary to ritual; speak not what is contrary to ritual; make no movement that is contrary to ritual." All these express the meaning of "thrift." The Wondrous Orthodox Perfected One said: "Within seeing and hearing, cut off seeing and hearing—this is called the great rest." This is the supreme secret of the word "thrift," encompassing boundless wondrous meanings without remainder.

52. Verification in the Dao of the Elixir
Verification in the Dao of the Elixir may be divided into two aspects: first, verification in the physical body; second, verification in the Dharma-body. As for verification in the physical body, the patriarchs Zhengyang, Ziyang, Cuixu, Sanfeng, and Qiyun have spoken of it in detail. The *Cantong Qi* says:
*"Golden sand enters the five viscera,
Mist scatters like wind and rain,
Steaming and reaching the four limbs,
The complexion becomes joyful and lustrous.
White hair all turns black,
Fallen teeth return to their places.
The old man becomes a youth again,
The aged woman becomes a maiden."*

"Transforming the form to escape worldly calamities—this is called the Perfected Person."

Chen Cuixu said:
*"After ten months of toil and hardship,
Gradually gathering, gradually congealing,
Now the whole body is white blood,
And the four limbs no longer know cold or heat."*

He also said:
*"After a year of practice,
The six pulses cease, and qi returns to its root.
A newborn infant dwells in the cinnabar field,
Its form and appearance just like mine."*

In the *Four Hundred Words Preface* by Ziyang, it is written:
*"When cultivation reaches this stage, wind stirs in the Mud Pill Palace, the moon shines in the Crimson Palace, fire blazes in the Cinnabar Field, and the waves of the Grain Sea settle. The spine moves like a wheel, the four limbs are as steadfast as mountains, the pores feel as if just risen from a bath, and the bones and channels are as deeply relaxed as in sound sleep. The spirit is as joyful as a reunion of lovers, and the hun and po souls are as inseparable as mother and child—this is the true realm, not mere metaphor. Refined by method, it gathers without scattering; tempered by measure, it solidifies ever more firmly. The hun soul is stored, the po soul extinguished; essence congeals, spirit coagulates. With a single intent of harmonious balance, the skin and flesh become radiant and clear. Day by day, hour by hour, it gradually congeals and gathers, transforming the formless into form, coalescing into the Sacred Embryo. Once the embryo’s qi has congealed, the Infant manifests; the Mystic Pearl takes shape, and the Supreme Unity embraces the True."*

Master Sanfeng’s *Essential Mysteries* reveals various verifications of the method, all trustworthy and attested. His *On the Verification of Returning and Restoration* describes the seven-day completion of the Great Heavenly Circuit in particular detail—among ten thousand volumes of elixir texts, only this one exposes the secret. Truly, it is the great treasure of the Mystic Tradition and the hidden repository of elixir practitioners.

In general, the essence of the elixir method lies in emptying and stilling the self to attract the arrival of primordial true yang. The deeper the degree of emptiness and stillness, the more abundant the coming of true yang—like a teacup: only by increasing its emptiness can one add more water. As true yang grows ever fuller, the original spirit flourishes, and the power of concentration strengthens. Thus, when refining essence into qi is complete, azure hair regrows, and the skin emits light. Advancing further, red blood turns white, the pupils become square, and the sinews, teeth, blood, and marrow—all undergo transformation, each renewing the old cauldron. At night, sleep is soundless; in labor, one does not tire. Eventually, qi transforms into spirit, eliminating sleep and food; wisdom’s light shines inwardly, and external realms dissolve into emptiness. All this flows naturally, requiring no forced arrangement.

As for verification in the Dharma-body, elixir texts speak of it only briefly. In my view, what the elixir method values is the Dharma-body, not the physical body. Therefore, from the very beginning, one must depart from the physical body, resting the mind and breath outside the body until great samadhi is attained. Even samadhi is established externally, using its power to subdue delusion and eliminate desire, and employing wisdom to shatter ignorance. One turns birth-and-death into nirvana, transforms affliction into unshakable wisdom, breaks through the five aggregates to emerge from the five turbidities, and eradicates habitual tendencies of views and thoughts without remainder. The true nature becomes perfectly luminous, pervading the Dharma-realm, with the Dao’s capacities fully realized—every thought instantly fulfilled. Thus, verification in the Dharma-body is even more precious than that in the physical body.

As the Perfected Ziyang said:
*"Deep in the night, the moon shines bright,
Heaven and earth become a single mirror."*

Li Qing’an wrote:
*"I ask: what is the verification of completing the work?
The moon’s radiance encircles heaven and earth."*

Master Sanfeng said:
*"Activate the samadhi fire of the Heavenly Circuit,
Tempering true emptiness to return to the Great Void."*

He also said:
*"Constantly apply the work,
The bright moon hangs in the sky, glowing red above the crown,
Illuminating one’s own master."*

And again:
*"The mind and the sun-moon share a great radiance,
I and heaven-and-earth are inner and outer.
Shattering emptiness is no trifling matter,
Gathering the six directions into a single millet grain."*

All these illustrate the verification in the Dharma-body. The verification of the Dharma-body takes samadhi and wisdom as its foundation.

*Zhuangzi* states:
*"The Great Unity flows through it; great samadhi upholds it."*
And:
*"The empty chamber generates brightness; auspiciousness abides in stillness."*
And:
*"Follow the ears and eyes in inward communication, while transcending the mind’s knowledge."*

This precisely reveals the image of great samadhi—profoundly still—and wisdom—perfectly luminous.

The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*’s section on breaking through the five aggregates describes the stages one must traverse in samadhi.

---

**53. The Classic of Nurturing Life**

In *Zhuangzi*’s "Gengsang Chu" chapter, Nanrong Chu inquired of Laozi about the classic of nurturing life. Laozi said:
*"The classic of nurturing life—can you embrace the One? Can you not lose it? Can you know good and ill fortune without divination? Can you stop? Can you cease? Can you abandon others and seek within yourself? Can you be carefree? Can you be unconstrained? Can you be like a child? A child cries all day without hoarseness—such is the perfection of harmony; clenches its fists all day without stiffness—such is the sharing of its power; gazes all day without blinking—its focus is not external. It walks without knowing where it goes, dwells without knowing what it does, flowing with things and moving with the waves. This is the classic of nurturing life."*

Nanrong Chu said: *"Then is this the virtue of the Perfected Person?"*
Laozi replied: *"No."*

This is what is called "melting like ice and thawing like frost."

The Perfected Person shares sustenance with others upon the earth and shares joy with them under heaven. They do not entangle themselves with the gains and losses of others, nor do they conspire in strangeness, nor scheme together, nor engage in affairs. They come and go with carefree ease. This is the classic of nurturing life.

The commentary states: *Jing* (經) means the constant Dao. This chapter reveals the essentials of the Way of nurturing life: "embracing the One without separation, and uniting one’s virtue with that of an infant." To "embrace the One" is to harmonize the heart with the breath, where the two luminaries meet and merge into one, refining the *qi* to achieve softness, just like the state of an infant. "To stop" means to be still—concentrating the spirit and entering the *qi*-cavern, so the heart attains stability. "To cease" means to rest. As the ancients said: "Suddenly severing the ten thousand conditions, transcending the stream of life and death." Severing conditions is the crucial step in entering the Dao. "Carefree" means being unburdened by worldly dust. "Unconstrained" means being without knowledge. The following passage specifically illustrates the infant’s essence of harmony and softness, its virtue of unknowing and unawareness. "Walking without knowing where it goes, dwelling without knowing what it does"—this fully demonstrates the wonder of forgetting things and self, responding without intention. To nurture life is to reach the state of primordial chaos and unite one’s virtue with that of an infant, so that the spirit is whole and the *qi* is gathered. "Flowing with things and moving with the waves"—the phrase *wei yi* (委蛇) is most profound, meaning to neither grasp nor reject things beyond their form. When matters arise, respond; when they depart, do not cling, like the reflection of light on waves—universally responsive yet without intention, following events without attachment. The virtue of an infant is without intention or emotion, neither resisting nor refusing, hence it is said: "It gazes all day without blinking, cries all day without hoarseness, clenches its fists all day without stiffness." "The Perfected Person shares sustenance with others upon the earth and shares joy with them under heaven"—this means the heart and breath depend on each other, summoning the true *yang* of heaven and earth, drinking harmony to nourish life, delighting in heaven and accepting fate. Simply entering the samadhi of self-reception, they do not concern themselves with the gains and losses of others, returning to the great void in primordial chaos. "Coming and going with carefree ease"—this is uniting with the virtue of heaven, and the classic of nurturing life is complete.

The formula states:
*Empty, still, tranquil, and detached,
Heart and breath unite as one.
Externally, harmonize with heaven’s harmony,
Awakening the life-force within.
Life-force without end,
Life too knows no bounds.
This is nurturing life,
And thus attaining longevity.
The mysterious origin of *qi*-transformation—
This is the supreme attainment.*

**54. The Wonder of Living Burial**
Linji Chan Master said: "In other schools, they cremate the dead; here, we bury the living." Master Chongyang said: "A living dead man, ah, a living dead man! Burying the four illusions is the cause. Sleeping soundly in the tomb, utterly free—shattering empty space, trampling the dust to pieces." He also said: "A living dead man, ah, a living dead man! Attaining death in life is the true cause. In the tomb, tranquil and empty—true emptiness—cutting off the worldly dust of the mortal realm." Again, he said: "A living dead man, ah, a living dead man! In emptiness upon emptiness lies the cause of emptiness. In the tomb, the true scene of emptiness—awakening to emptiness, no longer making dust."

Someone asked: "In the mysterious origin of cultivating the true, nothing is more wondrous than living death and living burial. Where does one perform this living burial?"

The answer: The empty space itself is the place of living burial. Preserve the spirit in the void, uniting it with the breath, directly entering the realm of great samadhi. After one round of living burial, attaining life within death, naturally spring arises beyond the kalpas, withered trees bloom anew. At that time, there will be boundless self-reception and endless life-force, as it is said: "Only after this great death does one now live." Thus it is said: "Having been born, kill life; before dying, learn to die—then you will attain longevity." Master Sanfeng said: "At this moment, the breath ceases as in a small death, merging into one—this is the complete truth." Wang Qixuan said: "When the fire of the celestial cycle ignites, the whole body, from top to bottom, aches—piercing the bones, penetrating the sinews. The *qi* flows through the four limbs and hundreds of channels, the bones as if shattered. One may lose consciousness for three to five days, reopening the primordial chaos, reestablishing heaven and earth. This is the fire-time of the celestial cycle. When the work reaches this point, one will surely ascend." The ancients had the metaphor of "one coffin, two corpses"—this is the wondrous metaphor for the spirit and breath both stabilizing in the void. When the work reaches the point where body and mind are utterly still and unmoving, then the meaning of living burial is attained.

The formula states:
*The fire-time of the celestial cycle,
Crushing the body to dust.
Three days in primordial chaos,
Dying and reviving.
Reestablishing the fetal womb,
Recreating heaven and earth.
The wondrous Dao of the mysterious origin—
Far beyond ordinary sentiments.
The wise trust and cultivate,
Surely attaining longevity.*

**55. The Land of Virtue and the Dao**
In the *Zhuangzi*, "Mountain Trees" chapter, it is said: Zhuangzi was walking in the mountains when he saw a large tree with luxuriant branches and leaves. A woodcutter stopped beside it but did not fell it. Asking the reason, Zhuangzi was told: "It is of no use." Zhuangzi said: "This tree, by being useless, has fulfilled its natural lifespan!" Later, the Master left the mountains and lodged at the home of an old friend. The friend, delighted, ordered a servant to kill a goose and cook it. The servant asked: "One can cackle, the other cannot—which should we kill?" The host said: "Kill the one that cannot cackle." The next day, a disciple asked Zhuangzi: "Yesterday, the tree in the mountains, by being useless, fulfilled its natural lifespan; today, the host’s goose, by being useless, died. Where will the Master position himself?" Zhuangzi laughed and said: "I will position myself between usefulness and uselessness."

Between usefulness and uselessness—this is but an approximation, not the truth, and thus one remains entangled in burdens. Yet if one rides the Dao and virtue, drifting freely, it is not so. Without praise or blame, now a dragon, now a serpent, one transforms with the times, never clinging to a single form. Rising and falling, one takes harmony as the measure, drifting among the ancestor of the ten thousand things. Treating things as things yet not being treated as a thing by them—how then could one be burdened?

This is the method of the Yellow Emperor and Shennong. As for the nature of the ten thousand things and the transmission of human relations, it is not so. Union leads to separation, completion to destruction; sharpness invites defeat, honor invites criticism, action incurs loss, worth invites schemes, and worthlessness invites deceit. How can one ever be certain?

Alas! Disciples, take heed—only in the realm of Dao and virtue can this be so.

---

The *Zhuangzi*’s parable here reveals how worldly affairs are like hooks and files: union and separation, completion and destruction, worth and worthlessness, schemes and deceits—none can escape entanglement. Only by drifting beyond the realm of images and the Emperor, where mind and subtle breath merge in wondrous harmony, where dragon and serpent alike transform, where nature and destiny are cultivated in tandem, where rising and falling unite in harmony, where wondrous being and true emptiness interpenetrate, where the primordial harmony fuses—only by returning to the subtle and formless, transcending the five aggregates, and forever leaving birth and death behind can one attain carefree ease and transcend death without reliance. Thus, to escape the suffering of rebirth and the burden of life and death, there is nothing but the diligent cultivation of the supreme Dao.

---

**56. The Joy of Distancing from Dust**

The *Zhuangzi*’s "Mountain Trees" chapter states: Prince Shao of the Market South called upon the Lord of Lu, who wore a troubled expression. Prince Shao asked: "My lord, why do you appear so troubled?"

The Lord of Lu replied: "I have studied the Way of the former kings and cultivated the undertakings of my predecessors. I revere the spirits, honor the worthy, and practice these virtues without the slightest lapse. Yet I cannot escape misfortune—this is why I am troubled."

Prince Shao said: "My lord, your method of avoiding misfortune is too shallow! The sleek fox and the patterned leopard dwell in the mountains and forests, crouch in rocky caves, and remain still. They move by night and rest by day, ever vigilant. Though hungry and thirsty, they still keep their distance from rivers and lakes while seeking food, ever composed. Yet they cannot escape the snares and traps—what crime have they committed? Their pelts are their calamity."
