Here the Lord of Lu alone is not your pelt? I wish for you to flay your form and shed your skin, to cleanse your heart and cast off desire, then wander in the wilds where no man dwells.

In the southern lands of Yue there is a city called the Realm of Establishing Virtue. Its people are simple and unadorned, with few selfish desires. They know how to work but not how to hoard; they give without seeking repayment. They do not know where propriety is born, nor where ritual is led. Reckless and unconstrained in their actions, they tread the great square of the Dao. Their lives are joyful, their deaths are burials.

I wish for you to abandon your state and forsake custom, then walk alongside the Dao as your companion."

The Lord said: "That path is distant and perilous, with rivers and mountains in between. I have no boat or carriage—what can be done?"

Prince Shao replied: "Do not be rigid in form, do not linger in place—take this as your carriage."

The Lord said: "That path is secluded and remote, with no one there. With whom shall I be neighbors? I have no provisions, no food—how can I reach it?"

Prince Shao replied: "Lessen your expenditures, reduce your desires—though you have no provisions, you will have enough. Cross the river and float upon the sea. Gaze upon it and you will not see its shores; the farther you go, the less you will know its end. Those who see you off will turn back from the shore, and you will be far from here. Thus, those who possess others are burdened; those who are seen by others are troubled. Therefore, Yao neither possessed others nor was seen by them. I wish to remove your burdens, dispel your troubles, and wander alone with the Dao in the boundless realm."

Liu Xuxi said: "How profound, Master! You wander beyond the dust of the world, describing all you see with vivid clarity. You prepare carriages and provisions to send him off—whether as illusion or immortality, it is as it is. Reading to the point where they turn back from the shore, one feels the lightness of casting off old sandals. Is this not the pinnacle of discourse on the land of virtue and the artistry of writing?"

Lu Fanghu’s *Nanhua Fumo* states: "The entire passage speaks as if scratching an itch through a boot, casually using the fox and leopard to expound on stillness, vigilance, and composure. Clearly, this elder’s words are all parables about the Dao. The fox and leopard bring disaster upon themselves with their pelts, just as the Lord’s troubles arise from the state of Lu—both are burdens of existence. Thus, he wishes the Lord to flay his form and shed his skin to purify the exterior, to cleanse his heart and cast off desire to purify the interior, then wander in the wilds where no man dwells, solitary and alone. This would make him inwardly unaware of himself and outwardly unaware of others—the greatest liberation in the world. What external burdens could then trouble him? The original intent of Zhuangzi and Laozi is simply to urge people to return their hearts to the Dao, to be utterly bare and unadorned, entirely free from worldly burdens. This is the mindset of the sage who possesses the world yet does not cling to it. If one’s duty to the state is weighty, how could one lightly abandon the state of Lu? Yet if we speak of severing attachment and discarding the source of calamity, then everyone has a fox’s pelt, everyone has a state of Lu. The meaning lies beyond the words."

Xuanjing said: "This chapter uses the Dao to inspire people to leave the burning house of worldly toil and reach the wondrous realm of purity, stillness, and joy. The so-called boundless realm is the land of the formless and the soundless; the wilds where no man dwells are the state of great samadhi. When scholars regulate their breath and concentrate their spirit, returning their spirit and qi to their root, they pass through the indistinct and obscure to reach perfect stillness. Forgetting things and forgetting cares, without self or others, in a state of unknowing and undifferentiation—this is wandering with the Dao in the boundless realm. As the practice deepens, body and mind become profoundly still, unstained by the six senses, undisturbed by worldly desires. Naturally, one becomes carefree and at ease, transcending all phenomena.

Yet this is the principle; the work at the edge of the dharma realm is called 'principle distant from dust'—it does not mean abandoning one’s duties or family. If scholars can cast off everything, then with a few like-minded companions, they may retreat to nurture their nature amidst green mountains and clear waters, roaming freely in thatched huts and stone chambers, far from the bustling marketplace. In such a tranquil setting, the mind easily becomes still, and samadhi and the Dao are readily attained. Thus, Han Qingfu’s poem says: *'The green mountains and flowing waters are my home.'* The ancients attained the Dao in the mountains and forests for this reason—this is called 'both principle and practice distant,' the most sublime path."

**57. The Wanderings of Gathering the True**
*Zhuangzi, "The Turning of Heaven"* states: "The perfected people of old borrowed the Dao of benevolence and lodged in righteousness, wandering in the emptiness of freedom. They ate from the fields of simplicity, stood in the gardens of non-transaction. Freedom is non-action; simplicity is ease of nourishment; non-transaction is no expenditure. The ancients called this the wanderings of gathering the true."

Explanation: The perfected people of old regarded benevolence and righteousness as expedients for governing the world, treating them like temporary lodgings without lingering in them. They wandered freely in the land of the formless and soundless, simply following their own inclinations. Simplicity means ease of nourishment. Confucius said: *"Qian is easy to know, Kun is simple in its abilities. What is easy is easy to know; what is simple is easy to follow."* This "field of simplicity" is the empty space beyond the body—what the school of the mysterious calls the Yellow Court, the Center of the Compass, the Chamber of Spirit, the Earthen Cauldron, the Cinnabar Field. Concentrating the spirit here and merging it wondrously with the breath, one enters fetal breathing. The external senses draw in the primordial qi, which enters the body, nourishing the constructive and defensive energies, steaming and melting the fluids—this is the true practice of eating from the fields of simplicity.

The common folk cultivate gardens and fields to sustain their livelihoods, while Daoists tend the Cinnabar Field to nourish life. The primordial qi of Great Harmony is inexhaustibly summoned and gathered; jade nectar and liquid jasper are endlessly consumed. Such is its wondrous efficacy—hence it is called "simplicity and ease of nourishment."

Those who rely on borrowing have no true exit. Ordinary people’s breath flows in and out without self-mastery; should a single breath fail to come, life is no longer their own. They stand in the garden of borrowed existence. "Borrowing" means debt—with the creditor’s claim resting in another, far from secure. The creditor may press demands at any time, leaving no escape. Only when mind and breath interdepend, when external breath ceases yet one remains in perfect serenity—like the antelope hanging its horns, leaving no trace to be found—does the power over life and death shift from another to oneself. Creation cannot then constrain one; this is the wondrous state of non-borrowing. If there is borrowing, there is the breath of exit and entry; without borrowing, there is no breath of exit and entry. With neither exit nor entry, one merges with the vast oneness of heaven—this accords with the mystery of the ancient primordial Dao.

This great quiescent samādhi of no exit or entry is the profound subtlety of the alchemical school, the true mechanism of gathering and refinement. It is called the wandering of gathering the real—profound and subtle indeed. The secret formula states:
*Empty, still, tranquil, and serene,
Spirit and breath harmoniously blend.
Emptiness and being fuse as one,
Self and other are not two.
Within and without merge completely,
Nature and life return to unity.
True emptiness, great samādhi,
Beyond form, beyond name.
The gathering that is no-gathering—
Great Harmony fills to overflowing.*

The mysteries of the Daoist school were revealed by Laozi and Zhuangzi. In this profound treatise, the two sages stand as ancestors. Once the treasury of emptiness is unlocked, one may freely partake.

58. The Mystery of Fasting the Mind
In the "World of Men" chapter of the *Zhuangzi*, Yan Hui says: "My family is poor, and for months I have neither drunk wine nor eaten meat. Can this be called fasting?" [Confucius] replied: "That is the fasting for sacrifice, not the fasting of the mind." Yan Hui said: "May I ask about the fasting of the mind?" Zhongni said: "Unify your will! Do not listen with the ears, but listen with the mind; do not listen with the mind, but listen with qi. The ears are limited to hearing, the mind to matching signs. Qi is emptiness that awaits things. Only the Dao gathers in emptiness. Emptiness—this is the fasting of the mind."

Yan Hui said: "Before I had yet received this teaching, I was truly myself; having received it, I am as if I have never been myself. Can this be called emptiness?" The Master said: "It is complete."

The Master [i.e., the commentator] states: *The Zhuangzi* employs the dialogue between Confucius and Yan Hui to illuminate the subtlety of "fasting of the mind." Li Qing’an’s *Song of Refining Emptiness* says:

*To be immortal, Buddha, or Confucian—*
*The Three Teachings transmit but one emptiness.*
*From ancient times to now, those who transcend*
*All cultivate within this emptiness.*

Now, *The Zhuangzi* declares: *"Only the Dao gathers in emptiness. Emptiness—this is the fasting of the mind."* This precisely reveals that both the Confucian and Daoist traditions begin with emptiness and quiescence, progressing from the interdependence of mind and breath to the realm of great samādhi and true emptiness. Body, mind, and world dissolve entirely, directly attaining "that which precedes the Lord of Images." Self and dharma forgotten, principle and phenomena both extinguished—such is the subtlety of the fasting of the mind. The key to this dharma-gate lies in "reversing hearing to hear the self’s cessation."

*"Unify your will!"*—this means directing the will without distraction. Hearing with the ears, hearing with the mind, and hearing with qi constitute three progressive stages. *Zhuangzi* seeks to guide one into profound realization, hence the inverted phrasing: *"Do not listen with the ears, do not listen with the mind."* Beginners listen to the breath with their ears; when the practice matures, the ears are no longer needed—with a single turn of awareness, perception arises naturally. As skill deepens further, even the thought of turning awareness fades, and the mind spontaneously harmonizes with the breath. Breath and mind merge effortlessly, and I simply abide in the naturalness of emptiness. Only when body, mind, and the external world are wholly forgotten can this be called "hearing with qi." From hearing the breath to hearing with qi, one enters the purely prenatal realm.

In essence, hearing with qi is the true message beyond mind, intention, and consciousness. As *The Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says, it is *"emptiness and awareness perfectly rounded."* The subsequent text states: *"The ears are limited to hearing"* (some editions read *"hearing is limited to the ears"*), meaning the function of the ears culminates in their capacity to hear. *"The mind is limited to matching signs"*—the function of the mind culminates in its capacity for perception. Yet traces of subject and object remain: where there is a hearer, there must be something heard; where there is perception, there must be something perceived. Only upon reaching true emptiness do subject and object dissolve together, leaving only a single emptiness. This is called *"the samādhi of a single dharma-realm’s adornment,"* which perfectly accords with the subtlety of the fasting of the mind.

Yan Hui says: *"Before I practiced the fasting of the mind, the notion of self had not yet vanished, and I truly felt the presence of Yan Hui. Once I practiced it, both body and mind became empty, and neither self nor other remained. It was as if 'I halted at the back, losing my body; walked in the courtyard, yet saw no one.' Could this be called emptiness?"* Confucius affirmed it, saying: *"It is complete."* Yet this is merely provisional approval. One must understand that to sit fixedly in the realm of emptiness is still to dwell in a nest—only when one reaches *The Zhuangzi*’s state of *"neither having one nor having nothing,"* where both being and non-being are ungrasped, does one attain the ultimate fasting of the mind.

**59. The Subtlety of Reversing the Flow**
*"Following the current, one enters the sea of birth and death; reversing the current, one emerges from the sea of birth and death."* The term "reverse" means to go against the flow, tracing back to the origin before birth, and attaining "that which precedes the Lord of Images." It also carries the sense of "returning," meaning the *"revolving return to the origin."* *The Śūraṅgama Sūtra* states: *"Entering deeply through one gate in reverse, the six senses become simultaneously pure,"* and *"reversing the flow to perfect oneness, the six functions cease."* *The Book of Changes* says: *"Return: cooking, the firm reverses,"* and *"tracing origins and reversing endings, one knows the discourse on death and life."* The Old Master [Laozi] says:

*The multitude bustles, as if feasting at a grand sacrifice,*
*As if ascending a springtime terrace.*
*I alone drift, without sign,*
*Like an infant who has not yet learned to smile,*
*Unattached, as if with nowhere to return.*
*The multitude all have more than enough,*
*While I alone seem bereft.*
*I have the heart of a fool—how muddled!*
*The vulgar are bright; I alone am dim.*
*The vulgar are sharp; I alone am dull.*

He also says: *"Profound virtue is deep and far, turning back with things,"* and *"return to the root, return to simplicity, return to the limitless, return to nothingness."* All these are the esoteric principles of reversing the flow and the practice of revolving return. *"I alone seem bereft"*—this is the forgetting of both inner and outer, body and mind. *"Dim"*—this is the state of primal chaos, knowing nothing and perceiving nothing. Master Sanfeng says: *"Return to a state of dull silence, like one drunk or foolish."* At the moment of coalescing the elixir, the hundred vessels return to their source, and the breath ceases as in a small death—this is the true realm of dullness and oblivion, the authentic message of the Daoist tradition’s *"reversing the flow to perfect oneness, where the six functions cease."*

In *The Śūraṅgama Sūtra*’s assembly, the twenty-five sages each expounded their path to perfect penetration. For instance, Aniruddha’s *"revolving vision to follow the origin,"* Gavāṃpati’s *"returning taste to revolve awareness,"* Subhūti’s *"revolving dharmas to return to nothingness,"* Cūḍapanthaka’s *"reversing breath to empty space,"* and Avalokiteśvara’s *"entering the flow and forgetting the source"*—all illustrate the purport of reversing the flow. In the Daoist tradition, practice begins with regulating the breath, its subtlety lying in revolving hearing to merge with the breath, and revolving the breath to return to the origin. This perfectly aligns with the Buddhist principle of *"reversing breath to empty space."* "Reversing the breath" means shifting from the breath of existence to the breath of non-existence. The breath of non-breath is called the true breath. The Daoist tradition, through revolving the breath, enters true emptiness and emerges into wondrous being, achieving the dual perfection of emptiness and existence, the marvel of both form and spirit. One attains the three liberations, realizes the patience of non-arising, and shares the same fruition as the twenty-five sages.

**60. The Beauty of Yang Harmony**
When spring’s qi is harmonious and mild, when spring winds are warm and gentle, when orioles sing and swallows chatter, when flowers bloom and waters flow—all things at this time flourish and grow.

The Daoist tradition’s cultivation and realization are perfectly suited to this moment. When heart and breath merge in wondrous union, yin and yang find their kind, bone and flesh harmonize, and spirit and essence rejoice in concord. The primordial unity of qi washes and irrigates, steaming and flowing smoothly, saturating and nourishing the *wei* and *ying* (defensive and constructive qi). Not a single moment passes outside the beauty of Yang harmony.

Ancient immortals, in their verses, often invoked the word "spring" to depict the joy of serene harmony. *Zhuangzi* says: *"Make it harmonious and joyful, flowing without losing its delight. Let day and night be seamless, and unite with things as spring—this is to connect and generate time within the heart."* (Meaning: the four seasons do not reside in heaven and earth, but in the unbroken continuity of my heart, where time is ceaselessly generated.) *The Kinship of the Three* states: *"Cultivate without ceasing, and the qi will move like clouds and rain. Drizzling like spring rain, flowing like melting ice."* *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* says: *"The scenery of the homeland is lovely, as wind and rain deepen the spring."* Master Zhong declares:

*"A single primordial true seed,
Entering the cinnabar field, brings eternal spring.
Where pre-heaven and pre-earth return as one,
In undivided chaos, how could there be trace?"*

And:

*"The primordial unity of qi, an elixir of a thousand years,
Preserves a perpetual spring beyond ten thousand kalpas."*

Master Lü sings:

*"Rosy clouds drift over fragrant fields where jade sprouts grow,
Moonlight on emerald peaks where immortal cranes weep.
The celestial grotto’s message runs deep in spring,
The immortal’s path is trodden—mortals cannot follow."*

And:

*"A gourd of spring wine at the tip of my staff,
A furnace of cinnabar yielding ten thousand specks of gold."*

And:

*"Since awakening to the true body,
I have won the eternal spring of Penglai."*

And:

*"Twelve thousand cycles of sixty years,
This gourd holds everlasting spring’s radiance."*

And:

*"Temper the marrow, refine the root,
Petals of peach blossoms in the grotto’s spring."*

And:

*"A green serpent in hand ascends the white sun,
Immortal fruits in the cave bear everlasting spring."*

And:

*"The guest’s gourd always holds wine,
The alchemical furnace harbors another spring."*

And:

*"Clad in bark, fed on wood, in the grotto’s spring,
An ancient sword at my brow refines the pristine spirit."*

And:

*"All day without a word to share the news,
A gourd of spring wine leaves me drunk and blissful."*

And:

*"The elixir of longevity, the heart of the flower,
Layered petals bloom in radiant spring."*

And:

*"One, three, five—all numbers are spring,
Post-earth and pre-heaven reveal the Old Lord.
Flowers bloom in western rivers, brocade unfurled,
Moonlight brightens the northern sea, celebrating wind and cloud."*

And:

*"Forgetting the interplay of form and emptiness,
I brew morning and evening’s eternal spring."*

And:

*"Within the abdomen, creation moves naturally,
In the furnace, heaven and earth hold primeval spring."*

And:

*"Once the countenance is perfected, the three realms grow small,
The master dwells in the spring of all four seasons."*

Master Cuixu says:

*"When primordial qi returns to the furnace and spirit does not scatter,
Spring mountains, spring waters, and spring winds arise of themselves."*

And:

*"A hundred thousand jade dragons roar without end,
A river of spring moonlight follows the fishing boat."*

And:

*"Only within the jade gourd’s spring hues,
Do I pluck a flower to ask Fuxi and Xuanyuan."*

Master Yuchan declares:

*"Seek the body beyond the body within,
In the harmony of emptiness—a gourd of spring."*

And:

*"Green dragon and white tiger encircle the golden tripod,
At midnight, a single yellow sprout—a branch of spring."*

And:

*"Flowers sway in spring winds, birds sing of their own accord,
Who knows the Maker’s spring is heaven?"*

And:

*"The golden elder and the radiant maiden wed,
Peach blossoms at the grotto’s mouth bloom daily in spring."*

And:

*"In the Hall of Wondrous Union, quietly nurture the spirit,
Where spirit congeals and qi gathers—a gourd of spring."*

And:

*"For over two years in the thatched hut of Wuyi,
Flowers laugh, orioles sing—spring in a gourd."*

And:

*"Mercury tiger and lead dragon refine spirit and qi,
Last night, a yellow sprout—a branch of spring."*

And:

*"White clouds fill the night sky,
A single yellow sprout—a blossom of spring."*

*The Book of Returning to the Elixir* says:

*"A thousand miles of deep yin, spring’s qi converges,
Nine skies clear, dew’s essence congeals."*

Xinglin’s *Returning to the Source* states:

*"Clouds scatter from the crabapple moon,
Spring deepens in the willow wind.
Who knows this meaning?
I raise my eyes to ask the empty sky."*

And:

*"The heart’s field free of weeds,
The nature’s earth devoid of dust.
In the stillness of a moonlit night,
A spring bird’s call."*

Zixian’s *Restoring Life* says:

*"Having drunk the numinous elixir,
One becomes a carefree person of pure Yang.
In the cave’s clarity, ever abiding in luminous stillness,
Peng Island is eternally in spring."*

And:

*"Weary of worldly affairs,
I rejoice in meeting a guest from the Purple Palace.
A single word of direct transmission,
And the jade grotto’s peach blossoms bloom in spring."*

Cao Wenyu sings:

*"A three-foot sword’s qi carried in my sleeve like water,
A gourd of rosy nectar at my staff—a spring in full."*

Master Qianxu declares:

*"Startling the black dragon in the sea’s depths,
A night of wind and thunder brings spring to the great earth."*

Ke Baozhen says:

*"The three minds extinguished, harmonize the primordial qi,
The four forms forgotten, seek the master.
Before your eyes lies the Peach Blossom Land—
At this moment, flowers hold buds, awaiting the thunder’s roar,
When all things will burst into spring."*

Ma Danyang sings:

*"Fire arises in water—banish the mind’s realm,
Flowers bloom in snow—extinguish the spring of thought."*

Master Sanfeng declares:

*"Drunk, oh drunk, again drunk,
The cinnabar field’s spring glows red as jade.
Freely drinking the fragrance of the immortal peach,
The trigram wind stirs, the primordial qi harmonizes.
The battle with yin demons brings a chest full of spring,
Spirits wail, ghosts cry, heaven and earth overturn."*

And:

*"A myriad scenes all prove false,
A single red light is the ultimate truth.
This red light is the essence of spring,
Within it, as if dust in a bright window."*

And he further states:

*"Await that single point to return and submit,
Within the body, the four seasons turn to spring.
A wisp of white cloud, a waft of fragrance,
After each rain, renewal unfolds.
All day languid as a drunken man,
Leisurely guarding the cavern’s spring.
When yin essence is wholly stripped away,
It transforms into a mass of pure yang gold."*

And:

*"Just as the golden water fills the first string,
It resembles the orioles and blossoms of a second-month spring."*

And:

*"Blossoms bloom, birds sing—spring fills the sky,
Inverted dragon’s saliva paired with tiger’s blood."*

And:

*"Suddenly harmonized, spring knows no bounds,
A sacred embryo is born, called the holy womb."*

And:

*"The Yellow Dame brokers the union of three families,
Drinking wine, admiring flowers—spring spreads across the land."*

And:

*"Within the gourd, sun and moon; within the cavern, spring,
Twenty-three years of stillness in the body."*

And:

*"With a sweep of light, the true is revealed,
Joyously, the heart brims with spring."*

And:

*"With a sweep of light, the numinous is seen,
Roaming at dawn, lodging at dusk in the crystalline pavilion.
Awake, at peace; asleep, at peace,
When spring arrives, verdure flourishes everywhere."*

And:

*"The spring of extinguished thought runs deep, the cavern chamber sealed,
Far from sounds and sights, the true constant is preserved."*

And:

*"The heart like a lotus rising from water,
The mind like lightning in the clouds.
Last night, over a trifling matter,
I strayed into the Pavilion of Radiant Spring."*

And:

*"In the Pavilion of Radiant Spring, the moon hangs high,
Jade trees bloom anew, shattering the silence."*

And:

*"When the host of yin is exhausted, the radiant yang season dawns,
A branch of spring’s hue, golden blossoms resplendent."*

And:

*"I await only the moon at Qujiang to cast forth the Metal Ape,
Treading snow in the mountain of form to seek spring.
Gathering golden essence, I depart the Crimson Waters,
Harmonizing the true breath to circulate through the body."*

And:

*"Pluck the flower, wear it,
Gather the flower’s heart,
Layer upon layer of blossoms, spring’s dazzling splendor."*

Floating Hill Elder states:

*"Empty within the spirit, in division or union—all is spring."*

Shao Yaofu says:

*"Roaming the profound depths of a thousand sages,
Embracing spring’s myriad blossoms in drunken embrace."*

And:

*"Sipping again and again, slightly intoxicated,
Joyously, the heart brims with spring.
No different from the first meeting of lord and minister,
Or the primal chaos of heaven and earth."*

And:

*"When qian meets xun, gaze upon the moon’s grotto,
Where earth meets thunder, behold the heaven’s root.
Roaming between the heaven’s root and moon’s grotto,
The thirty-six palaces are all spring."*

Chen Baisha declares:

*"Nothing added beyond the ordinary,
Yet the heart is ever full with spring’s abundance."*

And:

*"The rustic is no mourner of spring,
For spring resides in the rustic’s cup of wine."*

Such verses and gathas are too numerous to cite in full.

In sum, when one’s practice reaches the point where the entire body softens and melts, true qi steams and suffuses, one enters the realm of yang harmony. For every fraction of original yang that advances, a corresponding fraction of yin qi is dispelled. By frequently abiding in this realm of yang harmony, one constantly summons and attracts the primordial unity of qi to the palace. Over time, yin is exhausted and yang becomes pure, and one naturally transforms in form to become an immortal.

The Mystery School indeed prizes yang harmony, yet the Chan school is no different in this regard. At the moment of great awakening in the lineage, the wondrous luminous true mind—the inherently pure and radiant essence—suddenly manifests. Wherever the realm of yin intrudes, it is wholly dissolved and smelted away, presenting the image of the great earth returning to spring.

Having perused the *Song Mirror* and *Dharma Grove* and other works, I find that the poems and gathas of ancient worthies extolling "the beauty of yang harmony" are beyond counting. Zen Master Dongshan Jia says:

*"Withered trees bloom with spring beyond kalpas,
Riding the royal elephant backward to chase the qilin."*

Great Master Mingbin says:

*"Withered trees roar with dragon’s song, the great earth in spring,
Spirit roots sprout from cold crag’s grass."*

Zen Master Fengxue Zhi says:

*"Ever recalling the third month in Jiangnan,
Where orioles sing, a hundred flowers fragrance."*

Zen Master Ping Zhiyang says:

*"Clouds part, moonlight fills every home,
Spring comes, flowers bloom in every place."*

Zen Master Nanjian Wen says:

*"Like wind blowing fire—no great effort,
Spring fills the imperial capital’s four hundred prefectures.
Tipping over the great earth to reveal yang spring,
Mistaking orioles’ songs for entering willow shade.
Disheartened, night deepens, sobering from wine,
Laughing at them still lodging in the deep village."*

Zen Master Li’an Ding says:

*"Mud oxen bellow at the moon, cold pools sink,
Wooden horses neigh in the wind, Mount Tai renewed.
Gazing up and down, heaven and earth are utterly undivided,
Instantly teaching grasses and trees to harmonize with yang spring."*

Zen Master Xiuyan Rui says:

*"Village songs and communal dances—where is the nāga’s samādhi?
Mangy dogs and mud pigs—pure bodies.
Penetrating root and dust, no Buddha-dharma,
Uḍumbara flowers bloom across the ten continents in spring."*

Zen Master Fohui Quan says:

*"Before father and mother were born,
Where was the nose’s place?
Old hands in the grove
All obscure the hiding verse.
Though Mount Gu sees the opportunity,
It still props up the gate."*

The Taiyuan characters dance with a fan,
Toying with idle household trinkets.
Deep in the mountains, spring’s hues run deep,
Falling blossoms scatter without number.

Zen Master Zetan Zhun says:

*"In the second and third months,
Harmonious winds fill the heavens.
Everywhere, a hundred flowers bloom,
Distant and near, mountains like paintings.
Forked paths echo with spring birdsong,
High cliffs cascade with spring waters.
Each and all, the gates of samādhi,
Vast clarity pervades the great wilds.
A fine true message—
I write it to send you home."*

Zen Master Bani Lü says:

*"Fragrant grasses, slanting sun seal the ancient path,
At White Cloud Valley’s mouth, few meet.
Spring returns, a stretch of moss and lichen green,
Lifting the traveler—no trace remains."*

Zen Master Chengtian Zong says:

*"The leaves of the bodhi cannot be gathered in full,
One phrase, selfless, seals the myriad dharmas.
A thousand sages, though full-mouthed, cannot proclaim it—
Beyond the ridge, the plum’s spring bears no tidings."*

Zen Master Tiefan Zhou says:

*"In the human realm, April’s fragrance fades,
Yet mountain temples’ peach blossoms just begin to bloom.
Ever lamenting spring’s departure, no place to seek,
Unknowing it has turned and entered here."*

Zen Master Shangfang Yi says:

*"Gently, mountain fragrance fills the road in flight,
Wildflowers scatter, grasses part and sway.
Spring’s wind holds boundless, deep intent—
Yet none to whom the orioles may tell."*

An ancient master’s enlightenment verse says:

*"All day seeking spring, yet spring unseen,
Straw sandals tread the clouds atop the ridge.
Returning, laughing, pointing beneath the plum—
Spring on the branches is already full."*

Zen Master Wuliang Shou says:

*"Within the grotto, no clouds—a sky apart,
Peach blossoms like brocade, willows like mist.
The immortals know not winter or summer—
Stone crumbles, branches wither: one year."*

Zen Master Yuan’an Gui says:

*"Entering through the gate—no family treasure,
Yet another opens the spring of the earth’s jar.
Mistaking the two sounds and sights of worldly affairs,
How much dust is added within the ear!"*

Zen Master Liangting Ti says:

*"Purple swallows sport in the sunny day,
Yellow orioles sing in the evening breeze.
The old land brims with spring’s intent,
Pair by pair, they frolic amid the flowers."*

Zen Master Baizhang Duan says:

*"Apes cry in the frosty moonlight,
Flowers laugh in the spring of Qin Garden.
Amid the vast red dust,
Each and all are old friends."*

An ancient master says:

*"All dharmas from the beginning,
Ever in the mark of still extinction.
Spring arrives, a hundred flowers open,
Yellow orioles sing in the willows."*

Zen Master Weizhong Fu says:

*"The ten-thousand-year bed lies idle, too lazy to sleep,
Dragging steps, supporting the mist atop the ridge.
Whipping the iron ox to plow the bright moon,
A single song carries the kalpa’s spring, made whole."*

Zen Master Tiantong Jue says:

*"The white ox, sought in the snowy depths—no trace,
Effort spent, transcending, the body fuses with brightness.
Moonlight on reed flowers, the sky not yet dawn,
The spirit’s sprouts freely trimmed by spring’s wind."*

Zen Master Baofeng Jian says:

*"Spring’s warmth, the sun’s harmony—flowers weave the earth,
Throughout the grove, wild orioles first trill."*

Zen Master Bani Lü says:

*"Trudging through the red dust,
Wildly dancing in the western wind, leaving no mark.
How many deep thoughts cannot be held—
Let them tread the spring of the whole garden."*

An ancient master says:

*"The three realms are only mind, the myriad dharmas clear,
Vase, tray, hairpin, bracelet—all one gold.
Jade steps reflect the spring’s own hues,
Beyond the leaves, orioles’ fine songs—empty."*

Zen Master Shimen Yi says:

*"Seated among clustered peaks veiled in white clouds,
Orioles sing in the deep valley, unaware of spring.
Before the cliff, flower-rain scatters,
At noon’s dream’s end, recognizing an old friend."*

Zen Master Jiangshan Mo says:

*"For over forty years, dwelling in the dust of the world,
Now at last revealing the honored one within.
One night, the east wind rises at the cliff’s edge—
Blowing, it makes flowers bloom, spring filling the trees."*

Zen Master Changsha Ling says:

*"Wandering the mountains by day, returning,
The head monk asked, ‘Where have you been?’
The master said, ‘First I went with the fragrant grasses,
Then followed the falling blossoms home.’
‘That seems like spring’s intent,’ he said.
The master replied, ‘It still surpasses autumn’s dew on the hibiscus.’"*

Zen Master Shanrong Bo says:

*"Fishing the moon from the Ruoye Stream to its end,
Blowing the jade flute, spring in the grotto spent.
Last night, not lodging in the deep palace,
A single oar, fisherman’s song crossing Meng Ford."*

Zen Master Xuechao Yi says:

*"The World-Honored One’s single eye spans the three realms,
Outsiders’ two pupils pierce the five heavens.
Peach blossoms smile, their intent full—
Spring’s light is not at the willow’s tips."*

Zen Master Huanji Ting says:

*"Wild birds call and chatter endlessly,
The East Emperor stealthily turns the kalpa’s spring.
Forest flowers, unopened, lie in disarray,
Yet lingering fragrance cools the drunken."*

Zen Master Xinwen Ben says:

*"Holding with both hands, then teaching to let go,
Empty body, empty ground—still doubting.
Root, dust, consciousness, and realms—no place to seek,

Zen Master Sanfeng Cang says:

*"Before the reed’s ash stirs, three feet of snow,
Where in heaven and earth is spring not present?
A thousand mountains, birds silenced; the river frozen deep—

And again:

*"Lofty eyes never touched by dust,
Who is the servant boy sharing earnest care?
In the severe winter, the three rivers freeze solid,
Yet a thousand plants and myriad blossoms cover the earth in spring."*

Zen Master Xiangchuang Hai says:

*"An eighty-year-old granny, still unmarried,
A hundred knots of tender heart—whom to confide in?
Now, taking the East Lord’s power,
Joyfully seeing her brows unfurrow, a touch of spring."*

Zen Master Weiyi Run says:

*"The Mother of Transformation is impartial, like a level palm,
A hundred flowers like brocade—spring is deep.
Usually embroidering mandarin ducks to gaze upon,
Today, threading the needle to pass to others."*

Zen Master Zhongfeng Mu says:

*"Flowers fall on the silver bed, spring resplendent,
Moon sinks in the golden tent, night far-reaching.
The empty hall, desolate, no one to share—
Only burning incense sticks to one’s heart’s content."*

Zen Master Qingshan Wen says:

*"Jade Garden and Liang Park enjoy early spring,
The fragrant grove’s full bloom intoxicates wanderers.
Unable to bear the curtain’s edge, the orioles’ urgent cries,
Only deepening the scattered profusion of fallen flowers."*

Meng the Third of San’yi Monastery says:

*"Wenshu’s wisdom, Vimalakīrti’s virtue—
How to enter and exit, how to speak with perfect roundness?
The spring light leaves the east wind’s face unchanged,
Yet lures the cuckoos of Jiangnan to weep."*

Master Xue’an Jin says:

*"Who let the painted tower stand to the west,
Where we meet and laugh in hushed tones?
Home at last, spring’s colors linger late—
Flowers fall, and partridges cry."*

Master Shuzhong Yun says:

*"Crimson strings plucked beneath the night moon,
Emerald sleeves dancing in the spring breeze.
Those who harmonize dwell in carefree ease—
Who else could share such company?"*

Master Juelang Sheng says:

*"With strokes that fail to form ‘eight’ and words that miss the mark,
The spring wind brushes the balustrade—flowers still slumber.
Where has the young lord gone, not yet returned?
Sweet grasses grow thick, sorrow covering the earth."*

Master Baiyun Duan says:

*"If you can turn things as the Tathāgata does,
Warm spring’s mountain blossoms bloom everywhere.
You’ll naturally possess a pair of impoverished hands,
Never lightly dancing the Three Terraces."*

Master Qianguang An says:

*"Rain washes the pale red peach buds to radiance,
Wind sways the light green willow threads with grace.
In the white clouds’ shadow, strange rocks emerge,
While ancient trees stand clear in the green water’s glow."*

Master Xinwen Ben says:

*"Warm sun, gentle breeze—scenery grows ever strange,
Each flower and blade of grass reveals its full mystery.
A gust of fragrant tuan-hua wind arises,
Drawing wandering bees to fly everywhere."*

Master Beijian Wen says:

*"Six senses without function—trust does not pass,
All at once entrusted to the spring wind.
A wisp of incense smoke, a tranquil painting,
A hundred birds stay away, yet flowers bloom red on their own."*

Master Jishui Guang says:

*"A thatched hut hidden by the stream’s edge,
Brushing aside mist to transplant lingzhi in a stony field.
Turning to gaze, the flowers seem drunk—
Unnoticed, a warbler alights before the window."*

Master Yuan’an Nong says:

*"Each crimson path the same red,
A thousand peach and plum trees, ten thousand in full bloom.
Who recognizes the spring wind’s face?

Master Yangshan Qin says:

*"All dharmas leave behind marks of discrimination,

Within the spring wind’s scene, heaven and earth expand—

Master Ciming Yuan says:

*"Chasing bird tracks across the empty sky,
A hidden bird’s call heralds spring again.
If you know the east wind follows no divergent path,

Master Yushi Fang says:

*"Secluded birds call amidst red and green,
A single mat, a waft of warm wind startles midday sleep.
Sleeves dance, a single robe enters the woven dust—

Master Tudu Ce says:

*"To see forms, to seek sounds—no harm in this,
Embroidering mandarin ducks amidst a hundred flowers’ shadows.
Since recognizing the golden needle,
Let the wind blow fragrance into full sleeves."*

Master Benzhu Yue says:

*"Ancient trees sealed in clouds exhale sweet scent,
A gentle breeze stirs, birds sing anew.
Turning over beneath the curtained moon,
Sleeves fill with flowers’ fragrance, sleeves fill with spring."*

Master Tiantong Jing says:

*"Raising your brows to answer a question’s start,
I’ve personally seen the Buddha—no need to hide it.
To this day, offerings fill the four quarters of the world,

Master Zide Hui says:

*"Nezha Taizi’s original body,
Towering, unattached, unstained by dust.
Clouds scatter, flowing water—heaven and earth purified,

Master Zu’an Jian says:

*"A face of earth, a head of ash, unstained by dust,
Flower streets and willow lanes delight in true nature.
The golden rooster crows at dawn, waking jade tower dreams—
A single tree blooms, spring through endless kalpas."*

Master Zundao Qi says:

*"The spring colors of Wuyuan always come late,
In second month, willows hang no threads.
Now, when the river’s ice breaks,
It is precisely when Chang’an’s flowers fall."*

Master Daozong Ji says:

*"By the wild inn and mountain bridge, horses’ hooves follow,
Peach and plum trees form paths as they go.
Who knows beyond the ancient bank’s drooping willows,
Another spring wind dances in the green mist?"*

Master Xueqiao Xin says:

*"By the paths, many rape and wheat flowers bloom,
Swallows with mud in beaks paint the painted eaves.
Pitiful—countless scattered springs,
How can they dye crimson gauze with elegance?"*

Master Lingsou Yuan says:

*"Seeking the mind, the mind’s trace is already lost,
Recognizing the eternal as the universal.
From this, idle days dissolve—
When spring comes, accumulated snow melts on its own."*

Master Xinwen Ben says:

*"Leaning half by the fence, bearing snow and frost,
In the vast expanse of shadow, a celestial pose revealed.
Last night, spring arrived in the village ahead—
The old monk in the bamboo hut remains unaware."*

Master Gushan Gui says:

*"On the world’s path of wind and waves, I do not see you,
Each meeting brings fresh sorrow.
Where do flowing water and fallen flowers go?
By the cave’s mouth, peach blossoms hold a different spring."*

Master Yunyan Yin says:

*"Vast and empty, without sage, the whole body revealed,
Face-to-face presentation—already beyond the ford.
Do not ask of Liang’s court or Wei’s gardens,
One flower, five leaves—spring arises naturally."*

Master Tianzhang Yu says:

*"Who lingers in the jade tower, reminiscing?
A single call from a secluded bird touches the heart most deeply.
Do not say you do not know the bitterness of weeping traces—
Spring’s brew, the flower-slave, grows ever more foolish."*

Master Cishou Shen says:

*"In the third month, radiant light, harmonious and warm,
Mountains and rivers of brocade share the same scene everywhere.
Dawn mist over green tiles, Cold Food rain,
Sunlit curtains rolled up in the apricot blossom wind."*

Master Xuedou Zong says:

*"The iron ox plows open the cave’s sky,
Peach blossoms, petal by petal, emerge from deep sources.
The man of Qin has gone, leaving no news—
For a thousand ages, the peaks and ridges grow ever more vivid."*

Master Qingshi Xin says:

*"Spring wind fills the flower dell, sleeves brim with spring,
Red and white, perfectly matched.
Who can bear yet another sentimental one—
A reed pipe’s note passes over the wild pond?"*

Master Caotang Qing says:

*"Rabbit horns need not exist, ox horns need not be absent.
Where existence and non-existence fail,
Fragrance fills the Way’s path."*

Master Shangfang Yi says:

*"Sun-face to the east, moon-face to the west—
Who says carefree drifting falls into the stream?
Mountain peach blossoms scatter, spring departs,
Yet the cuckoo still cries from the branches."*

He also says:

*"Rain clears, the wanderer has not returned,
When suddenly a thunderclap splits the clear sky.
The plum by the ridge has caught spring’s message—
Not like the mountain peach, blooming all alike."*

Master Yizuzi says:

*"Listening to rain through the long night, weary,
A lone lamp shines cold upon the inkstone.
Spring departs with a rustle beneath the flowers,
Everywhere, birds cry in the fading light."*

Master Huiguang Sou says:

*"House to house, all gaze upon the wild fox’s child,
Many see, few truly know.
A hundred spirits, a thousand demons—all traces swept away,
As spring’s wind reaches the ten-thousand-year branch."*

Master Shigu Yi says:

*"Spring wind scatters the green peach blossoms,
A single petal flows past a hundred thousand homes.
Who lingers at the painted pavilion’s wine shop,
Inviting others to share Zhaozhou’s tea?"*

Master Yi[ ]quan says:

*"Flowers planted on stone—how rare the sight,
Branches heavy with spring’s hidden fragrance.
Scent drifts through the realm, yet none detect its trace,
As the wild wind blows at will."*

Master Xiaofeng Zhe says:

*"Spring’s hues fill the garden, yet cannot be contained—
A single red apricot branch breaches the wall.
Do not marvel at the noble scion’s high spirit,
For such grace has ever been heaven’s gift."*

Master Rujiu Xue says:

*"The palace bird roosts deep in the jade tower,
A sliver of moon rises at the eaves, night after night.
The fragrant carriage does not return, flowers bloom on their own,
Spring comes, yet the cold-dispelling gold lies idle."*

Master Nanjian Wen says:

*"Better to accept one’s lot, take what little comes,
Thirst quenched, hunger sated—only the self knows.
Trampling through spring’s radiance, rain-soaked and full,
Who dares claim the cosmos as their own?"*

Master Shanfu Zheng says:

*"Let the nobles of Five Tombs boast of their wealth,
The patch-robed monk scorns not his poverty.
After the second month in Jiangnan’s spring,
Orioles sing through every apricot-blossom village."*

Master Jue’an Xiang says:

*"Three cries of the tripod’s lid open the universal gate,
Yet the toiling souls of the bitter sea cannot be called back.
Ninety days of spring—now half are gone,
Petals drift in vain, dappling the moss."*

Master Dabian Quan says:

*"In toil and courtesy, uphold the Dao’s meaning,
Blending light with the world, welcome the guest.
The great rhythm turns—flowers bloom on a thousand trees,
Yet the traveler’s heart still knows not spring.
Striking from the side, hammering straight—
Losing the whole body.
Beyond the green mountains, a few yellow birds’ calls
Seize all the scenery, claiming mastery."*

Master Kentang Chong says:

*"Light does not illuminate objects, objects do not endure,
When light and object both are forgotten, what trace remains?
A hundred birds do not return—spring has aged,
Falling blossoms, flowing water encircle the lone village."*

Master Yongmi Ding says:

*"Mountains and rivers mock the peach and plum’s folly,
A wisp of mist and cloud levels every tree.
Watching spring’s arrival, admiring the flowers’ splendor,
The partridge’s cry fades deep into the tangled peaks."*

Master Yuan’an Fen says:

*"The yellow bird’s song dries in the green willow’s shade,
The Long Gate Palace still speaks of spring’s absence.
Where the jade flute plays, flowers fall in vain,
As the jade carriage passes, the moon has already set."*

Master Bojian Jian says:

*"Dwelling in the imperial park, spring at its finest,
Why ask the Eastern Lord of spring’s reds and purples?
A breath of fragrant wind rises from the secluded valley,
Beckoning the orioles to sing in the fading light."*

Master Tiantong Jue says:

*"Frozen in the snow-bound hut, night brings collapse,
The wicker gate stays shut, dark and still.
Watching the withered garden transform,
Spring’s wind stirs the ashes in the pitch-pipe."*

Master Xueren Qi says:

*"Warm wind, slanting sun guide the lone staff,
Who pities the stone path sealed by green grass?
Finding home at last, spring has already gone—
Gazing toward Snow Mountain, layers of emerald."*

Master Purong Ping says:

*"Before Mount Luzu, the ancient road runs clear,
A faint path vanishes east and west.
Amid the cuckoo’s cries, spring grows old,
Scattered peach blossoms carpet the earth in red."*

Master Gunan Men says:

*"Mist swirls, rain drizzles on and on,
How many ridges and bridges cross the valley’s stream?
The twelfth-month spring wind still lacks warmth,
Yet beyond the wall, one branch blooms red."*

Master Huanji Ting says:

*"Petals drift one by one, chasing the east wind,
Spring’s radiance lies scattered, a crimson carpet.
Even if gathered up now,
The lingering fragrance still spills over the eastern wall."*

Master Fohui Quan says:

*"Masterless men fill the great Tang realm,
Gorging on wine dregs, yet failing to grasp the essence.
Passing idly by Bamboo Temple, spring deepens,
Falling blossoms dapple the moss in random hues."*

Master Xianyun Bao says:

*"Thunder roars, lightning flashes, unleashing full force,
Just as the hidden dragon lies in deep slumber.
Suddenly waking from a dream, spring’s sorrow breaks—
Dawn’s wind carries rain past the front stream."*

Master Lingyan Chu says:

*"Jade bridle, golden saddle leave the imperial city,
Apricot blossoms drift, willows sway in profusion.
With every crack of the whip, every step in spring’s wind,
Trampling the path of the returned top scholar."*

Master Xueguan Zha says:

*"An expanse of clear sky—yet still a veil,
A thousand waves surge—yet not a true tide.
Grasping both paths, calling them heartless,
Everywhere spring’s wind unfurls willow and peach."*

Master Zuan Jian says:

*"The primal path does not traverse the subtle and profound,
When Dao and peace align, the trigger above is sprung.
Atop the shadowless tree, spring’s light dawns,
The golden rooster crows on the branch that casts no shade."*

Master Boshan Lai says:

*"Not walking the bird’s path, not dwelling in dust,
Drunken eyes caress the white day’s slumber.
Do not say one never errs in meeting others—
Plucking the willow’s bloom marks late spring."*

Master Gaofeng Miao says:

*"Zhaozhou’s dog lacks Buddha-nature,
Yet spring’s full splendor spreads across rivers and lakes.
How many pluck leaves to seek branches,
In vain, leaving the sunlit paths strewn with blossoms."*

Master Yefu Chuan says:

*"The three Buddhas’ forms are never true,
The pupil in the eye is the person before you.
If you can trust the treasure within your home,
The crying birds and mountain flowers share the same spring."*

Master Wu’an Quan says:
*"Sun warm, wind mild, orioles trill anew,
Willows trail golden threads to bind the Lord of Spring.
The Lord of Spring spares not his selfless power—
Each fleck of crimson blossom, each fleck of spring."*

Master Foyin Yuan says:
*"How could it compare to spring’s wind at ease everywhere,
Flowers blooming, flowers falling—what concern is there?
Even drifting white clouds are too constrained to match,
As they billow, unburdened, filling the world entire."*

Master Baiyun Duan says:
*"Plum blossoms spent, apricot petals unfurl,
Yet spring’s wind cannot help but strip them where it stirs.
Qi, silent, holds all forms within its embrace—
Where do the ten thousand spirits thank its selfless grace?"*

Master Huguo Yuan says:
*"To exhaust the patterns of things is to master one’s home,
To meet the moment’s timing is to know the heart’s own.
How grateful we are to spring’s wind, without favor or slight—
Even the poor man’s peach and plum cast shade in its light."*

Master Fojian Qin says:
*"Though each proof follows the body’s trace,
Departure and stay alike have keepers of their place.
After sandals are worn through and one returns at last,
Falling blossoms and crying birds share the same spring vast."*

Master Meng’an Cong says:
*"Bright, bright the Way—yet none can know,
To whom may this truth its face show?
A gust of spring wind sweeps in,
Scattering petals down the path again."*

Master Tianduo En says:
*"The Five Tombs’ spring grows rich and full,
The wind behind the head blows without end’s pull.
Drunk, I call the wanderer by the river to stay—
The cuckoo’s cry fades where green willows sway."*

Master Yun’an Yan says:
*"Casually lifting the seven-catty robe,
How many Chan seekers strain to probe!
All burrow nests in Qingzhou’s land,
Unknowing spring’s hues grace Jiangnan’s strand."*

Master Baiyan Fu says:
*"Spring mountains’ reflection reddens the river entire,
Orioles and willows, enamored, cling to the steed’s attire.
Do not regret the Immortal’s brush lacks skill—
For you dwell already within the painted hill."*

Master Longmen Yuan says:
*"Willows’ hue like tender gold,
Plum blossoms’ scent like fragrant snow.
If you know spring’s qi and its might,
Every place becomes a splendid sight."*

Master Jingshan Gao says:
*"At Winter Solstice, yang revives,
Heaven and earth share a single thread’s ties.
Pity the countless souls who never see
The face they were born with naturally."*

Master Fojian Qin says:
*"Iron trees bloom with ten thousand flowers,
Stone heads sprout two or three shoots like bowers.
Clay-molded vajras open their mouths to laugh—
Tomorrow, Winter Solstice births yang’s draft."*

Master Haizhou Ci says:
*"Late spring’s red plantain sprouts along the path,
March’s peach blossoms flourish in the garden’s aftermath.
Alas, that men do not know spring’s fragrance,
While in the trees, a hundred tongues sing its cadence."*

Master Tianqi Rui says:
*"Before enduring winter’s depth, do not rejoice too soon,
Let bone-piercing cold seep through the heart’s cocoon.
Suddenly, the dream awakens to spring’s warm embrace—
Ten thousand purples, a thousand reds blanket the earth’s face."*

Master Yunyan Yin says:
*"Curtains stir with spring’s wind, dawn still cold,
Song towers’ voices choke, dreams break like gold.
The golden wheel forsakes the human realm’s domain—
Do not envy the gourd’s sun and moon’s vast plain."*

Master Tian’an Sheng says:
*"How many mistake this body for their own,
Before them, divergent paths resist being overthrown.
Coral glistens in the spring of the Ten Isles’ shore,
Yet none who meet it fathom its depth or more."*

Master Yefu Yuan says:
*"Spring winds ripple waters wave on wave to green,
Autumn rains wash forests leaf by leaf to sheen.
Midnight on the stone bed, pillow in hand, I rest—
For whom does the mountain hermit’s joy attest?"*

Master Lingyan Chu says:
*"Wild waters shimmer in a thousand-cup tide,
From coral branches, the moon hangs far and wide.
The hall’s front pillar lacks a nose to grasp—
Yet it paints spring’s wind into distant brows’ clasp."*

Master Gaofeng Miao says:
*"By the willow-lined stream, green threads descend,
Yellow orioles in the trees trill without end.
How many, lost in play, miss spring’s fleeting trace—
In vain, ten thousand petals fall without embrace."*

Master Xinwen Ben says:
*"Pointing to deep red, it matches the past,
No heavenly splendor lingers in the fragrant mass.
From Nanquan’s brush, spring is swept away—
Only fading crimson remains to intoxicate the bees’ ballet."*

Master Zhengtang Ban says:
*"The jade cave’s primal pass stretches long,
Peaches of Penglai are no common throng.
Hidden, lest the mortal world should see,
Yet spring’s wind may betray its fragrance free."*

Master Gushan Gui says:
*"If you know heaven and earth share one root,
Why return to ask another’s pursuit?
Yet Nanquan’s direct pointing imparts—
Spring blooms in dreams as effortless arts."*

Master Tieji Xin says:
*"Before the cliff, waterfalls rush away,
Behind the hut, piled stones form peaks’ array.
Spring’s intent—where has it gone?
Behold, the earth is strewn with crimson gone."*

Master Cheng Kumu says:
*"Having reached Peach Blossom’s secluded scene,
A flask of bright moon gleams like autumn’s sheen.
Reflecting on the spring’s waning day at the cave’s mouth,
Countless red petals drift upon the stream’s south."*

Master Chanyan Rong says:
*"Beyond Yu’s Gate, three-tiered waves surge,
Dwelling in the clouds, yet knowing not the verge.
Suddenly, a thread of spring wind blows—
Who can tether the flight that soars and flows?"*

Master Bojian Jian says:
*"The highest branches bloom in Shanglin’s grove,
Brushed by clear winds in March’s alcove.
Wind warm, flowers fragrant, spring at its prime,
Courtyard shadows lengthen with the slow-passing time."*

He also says:
*"A stream divides the green mountains’ hue,
Peach blossoms on both banks blush anew.
The ferryman, though asked, does not know—
Silently, they drift with wind and rain to and fro."*

Master Xiaoweng Kan says:
*"A guest in the level fields asks the way,
From a high terrace, a white ox is led astray.
Spring’s light before the eyes is not much to behold—
A pair of mandarin ducks follows the current’s hold."*

Master Falin Yin says:
*"Amid ten thousand greens, a pinch of red,
Boundless spring’s hues flow where they are led.
Bees and butterflies seek in vain—
Blame the dawn wind’s whim in their disdain."*

Master Qingfeng Chu says:
*"The great matter is clear—
Why then mourn like one who’s lost kin?
Without spring’s wind, flowers will not appear,
Yet once they bloom, the wind blows them thin."*

Master Foxing Tai says:
*"By the stream, tender willows, green each thread,
On the paths, peach blossoms, red each spread."*

Do not say the Eastern Lord lacks governance—
Still he adds warm sun and harmonious wind.

Master Zide Hui says:
*"Layer upon layer stripped away, all returns to plainness,
Spring’s warmth, wind’s harmony, days grow long.
Outside the door, birds’ songs in broken whispers,
Rock flowers scattered, filling the mountain chamber."*

Master Zhengjue Yi says:
*"Spring’s warmth, peach blossoms red on every tree,
Lingyun’s ancient words remain the same.
Yuansha’s sayings linger in the groves—
North, south, east, west, the path knows no end."*

Master Huanglong Nan says:
*"The second and third months, scenes soft and mild,
Peach blossoms red near and far on every tree.
Even the masters’ awakening is not yet complete—
To this day, they still laugh in the spring wind."*

Master Fayun Xiu says:
*"When spring rains clear in the second month’s court,
Small peaches bloom, two or three red branches.
Red and white vie in beauty for all to see—
Why then does Lingyun alone not doubt?"*

Master Foguo Bai says:
*"How laughable—the spring wind leaks its secret,
Peach blossoms newly bloom on last year’s branches.
By Luojiang, there’s a fisherman—
He laughs at Lingyun’s unshaken doubt."*

Master Gushan Gui says:
*"The peach blossom seeks the sword-bearing traveler,
Silent, he smiles in the spring wind.
White-haired, he has yet to return—
His home lies east of the sea gate."*

Master Cihang Pu says:
*"Lingyun’s smile at the sight of peach blossoms,
Thirty years passed before he came home.
Since then, after spring’s winds and rains,
His name scatters like petals across the earth."*

Master Shaoshi Mu says:
*"At first sight of peach blossoms, he hides and flees,
Trapped in iron walls, no exit to be found.
How many cling to walls and fences—
Each spring’s arrival breaks another heart."*

Master Falin Yin says:
*"Restlessly seeking willows, his heart unruly,
Trampling peach blossoms, his eyes alone red.
Weary of the garden’s spring now late,
How can he bear the drum’s beat from next door?"*

Master Qingmen Lin says:
*"Every garden blooms in riotous fragrance,
Cuckoos cry, swallows chatter wildly.
A myriad measures of spring’s splendor cannot be contained—
Yet pity the rare poet who meets it."*

Master Furong Kai says:
*"One dharma originally void, ten thousand dharmas empty,
How could this allow awakening to perfect understanding?
One might think Shaolin’s message had ceased—
Yet peach blossoms still laugh in the spring wind."*

Master Changlu Liao says:
*"Jade hidden in Jing Mountain, prized,
A flake of snow in the red furnace—spring.
Returning to the root, wind scatters leaves,
The moonlit pool’s reflection—utterly void."*

Master Fojian Qin says:
*"South of the city, a poor scholar rides a donkey,
North of the market, a young lord rides a horse.
Each with four hooves planted on the earth,
Together in spring, they reach Golden Bright Pond."*

Master Ku Mu Cheng says:
*"Wandering everywhere, north, south, east, west,
Returning late, the moon like a hook.
A gust of spring wind scatters flowers—
Unknowingly, he nods in thought."*

Master Huanji Ting says:
*"Face to face, no one—yet the realm is empty,
Spring’s wind flows warmly everywhere.
Should you see it again as before,
Dare I vow we share life but not death?"*

Master Touzi Qing says:
*"Ancient cliffs, moonlight locked in layers,
Withered trees welcome fragrance, late with spring.
Last night, the Milky Way barred the Southern Dipper,
Golden crow follows phoenix past the wheel of heaven."*

Master Cuiyan Zhen says:
*"Sun scorches, wind lashes—asking whence the ancestor came,
Red dust stretches endlessly, eyes cannot lift.
How many rush and toil—
In deep spring’s second month, earth-shaking thunder."*

Master Fushan Chu says:
*"Grass hall, spring’s warmth, the sun begins to redden,
In the hall, diligent slumber, truly deep.
In dreams, a single sound—heaven and earth grow old,
Fading blossoms again chase the fifth-watch wind."*

Master Baiting Yong says:
*"Wind mild, sun warm, spring at its height,
Willows golden, flowers’ shadows dense.
Entering the old haunts of Peach Blossom Spring,
Each peak locks away another peak."*

Master Zhengtang Bian says:
*"I ask the world—what keeps men so busy?
Better to report spring’s affairs to spring’s light.
Even if drunk before flowers every day,
A season still holds ninety such scenes."*

He also says:
*"Painting true suchness to life,
Unfolding it amid the flowers,
A yellow oriole steals a glance—
Dares not descend from the branch."*

Master Xue’an Jin says:
*"Lost his boat in Dongting Lake,
A barefoot Persian sleeps beneath the waves.
Though all the world calls, he will not wake—
Spring’s wind blows him into Apricot Blossom Village."*

Master Yueting Zhong says:
*"Fallen leaves have followed the flowing water away,
Spring’s wind has not yet released the hundred flowers.
The green mountains’ visage remains as ever—
All day they lie exposed to the fading light."*

Master Tianzi Cui says:
*"In the third month, spring just begins to enjoy peace,
Cuckoos call ceaselessly, summoning the fading light.
Lacking the mood to compose a verse,
He treads the bright moon’s path, singing as he returns."*

Master Danlu Chun says:
*"Spirit soars beyond past, present, and future,
The three realms are but a single point of mind.
Beyond the balustrade, spring’s wind, spring’s butterflies dance,
Before the gate, willows, dawn orioles sing."*

Master Gu Yun Jian says:
*"A single call awakens a thousand autumns’ dreams,
To whom now belongs the boundless scenery?
Lifting his gaze, all is clear—nothing external,
The bright moon still shines on the flowered branches."*

Master Ji Zongche says:
*"Entrusting his feelings to playful bees leaving flowers,
Touching sandalwood, the wind from the precious tree.
Turning to the spring colors in the courtyard,
A pheasant’s cry shatters the vast emptiness."*

Master Cishou Shen says:
*"Eating rice, he bites on grit,
Breaks his third tooth.
After the spring wind passes,
Even his staff blooms."*

Master Qianren Gang says:
*"Amid peonies’ fragrance, the wind sways gracefully,
In pear blossoms’ shadows, the moon is round.
The host, drunk, sleeps on the Emperor Fuxi’s pillow,
Gazing at the red curtains’ inverted reflection."*

Master Huimen Kai says:
*"Wind high, moon cold, the azure sky stretches,
Suddenly the Silver River pours its jade streams.
All at once, everything becomes one hue—
A lake’s waters ripple with a lake’s spring."*

Master Quanjian Xu says:
*"Beholding the same moon, the realm grows profound.
Even Buddhas do not know—who is the true kindred spirit?
Peach blossoms riot in the distant spring wind,
A thousand miles of longing stir the traveler’s heart."*

Master Zifu Guan says:
*"The sky remains vast, the waters clear,
A silver hook suddenly snares the river-crossing man.
Turning back against the current to the village shore,
He finds the path home, his face alight with spring."*

Master Bojian Jian says:
*"At kalpa’s dawn, a patch of idle land—
Only the mud ox and stone maiden can till it.
Before the millet and sorghum bloom bright,
Peach and plum are planted to charm with fragrance."*

He also says:
*"Why do mountain plums so often flourish?
Only because they have endured frost and snow.
Yet the lone rider on his lame donkey stands,
Unknowing of spring’s descent upon the mossy rocks."*

And again:
*"Without the spring wind, flowers do not open;
Once open, they are blown away by the wind.
Scattered petals trampled into mud,
Their lingering fragrance swells in vain."*

Master Zifu Guan says:
*"Spring gardens riot with blossoms like waves,
Butterflies vie in beauty, their scent striking the nose.
As the sun sets behind the thatched eaves and dusk falls,
A frosty moon illuminates the pond."*

Master Xuelun Qi says:
*"A single hair’s turn encompasses Mount Sumeru,
Seized in hand, it brings a smile to the eyes.
Do not say kin are hard to find—
Amid the flames of ice-flowers, spring grows lush."*

Master Sanfeng Cang says:
*"No need for guest and host to meet in kinship,
One who grasps the divine mechanism transcends all dharma.
On a snowy night, plum blossoms usher in spring early,
While the garden’s fragrant herbs remain unaware of renewal."*

Master Gu’an Yue says:
*"Whose peach and plum vie in splendor,
As cuckoos call again and again, beckoning the traveler home?
Once he trod the path by Wuling Stream’s banks—
The grotto’s spring surpasses the mortal world."*

Master Gunan Men says:
*"Each bout of wind and snow brings deeper cold,
Yet when the cold recedes, spring’s warmth expands.
Why labor to repeat what’s already clear?
West of the post station lies Chang’an."*

Master Li’an Ding says:
*"A towering iron staff grinds against the moon,
Enduring frost and snow, its spirit shines brighter.
Suddenly, in the night corridor, it opens a laughing mouth—
By dawn, the earth is steeped in spring."*

Master Hongding Jiao says:
*"Layer upon layer of mist and rain chant the moss,
How does spring’s light arrive from ten thousand miles?
When the partridge calls, the sun warms the clearing,
And the bamboo staff ascends the Terrace of Gazing Home."*

Master Xianghu Ren says:
*"Leisurely he climbs, leaning on the railing,
Gazing at the streams and mountains framed like a painting.
In the immortal garden, spring winds stir pipes and strings,
Amid the throng of songs, the sound of rain grows dense."*

Master Haihui Xing says:
*"To transplant flowers, one loves the fine, misting rain;
To plant willows, one prefers a dim, overcast sky.
Behold the early spring of Shanglin Park—
Flowers cradle pearls of dew, willows veil themselves in mist."*

Master Deshi Xin says:
*"The spring wind brushes wildflowers into crimson,
Their branches high and low, some pale, some deep.
Endless vistas of water and mountain hues—
A single bird’s cry echoes through the empty peaks."*

He also says:
*"To grasp and release is but wasted effort,
Circling thoughts lead nowhere.
Suddenly turning back, spring is late—
At the staff’s tip, a single red orb is won."*

And again:
*"A hidden bird sings in the tall trees,
Fading blossoms drift upon the flowing stream.
Unknowing that spring is late,
The lotus blooms, its fragrance filling the nine continents."*

Master Falin Yin says:
*"Spring reaches the peach blossoms, overflowing the water’s source,
A world apart, its splendor unique.
The fisherman dares not speak of it to others,
Fearing it might stir idle sorrow in his descendants."*

Master Deqing Qi says:
*"All because of the moon over Huaidi,
It illuminates the spring of Yingyang.
A single arrow pierces the layered pass—
His merit high, yet he raises no banner."*

Master Miaoyun Xiong says:
*"A single uncarved lump, the heart of primordial antiquity—
Who has so cunningly chiseled it, losing its true purity?
Though one may wield the power to mend the sky with molten stone,
How can one resist the East Lord’s early teasing of spring?"*

Master Quanyue Zu says:
*"The moon over the river, the plum’s sparse shadows sway,
In subtle hues, spring stirs in the Penglai gardens.
A gust of harmonious wind betrays all—
Heaven is filled with fragrance, guiding travelers to the ford."*

Master Cishou Shen says:
*"For saints and mortals, no separate paths diverge,

Master Tiantong Hua says:
*"The garden’s spring lingers on the branches,

Master Lan’an Shu says:

Master Zhe’an Fan says:

Master Wanshan Ning says:

"Spring is everywhere—
even at the world’s edge, one returns early."

Master Zhenjing Wen says:

Master Shengke Yu says:
*"The Hall of the Empty King is dismantled,

Master Huiyin Jing says:

Master Baiyun Duan says:

Master Qingmen Lin says:

Master Bojian Jian says:

He also says:
*"Spring turns to Yangzhou, ten thousand trees align,

Master Shangfang Yi says:
*"The golden vale’s spring light fills the eyes,

Master Hansong Cao says:
*"Mist and rosy clouds fill the bamboo hat in the cold dawn,

Master Fachang Yu says:

Boil snow to brew tea and sober the drunk.
Beyond the path travelers have not trod,

Master Zhenjing Wen says:
*"Great function manifests, affairs unfold—
where does spring not bloom?
Send them to the hall for three meals of inquiry:

Master Xuedou Xian says:
*"Spring mountains layer in jumbled green,

Alone in the vastness of heaven and earth,
I stand gazing—where is the limit?"*

Master Wushi Dao says:
*"Xuedou’s family treasures,

Here at Wushi, though possessions are few,

Now, what is Wushi’s livelihood?"*

Master Zhuozhu Zhang says:
*"Swallows chatter, orioles sing in the warm spring sun,

Master Songru Mi says:

Master Cishou Shen says:
*"Shifting step by step, the old heavenly robe,

If today one understands what happened that day,

Master Luohan Nan says:
*"Wind scatters shattered jade—snow on a thousand peaks,
rain drips on cliff flowers—spring in ten thousand lands.
One could listen to the murmuring stream’s flow,

Master Yuan’an Fen says:
*"The east wind laughs with flowers in spring’s light,

A cuckoo’s cry darkens the hanging greenery—

Master Huaiqing Hai says:
*"From the other shore, messages rarely reach,

Master Nanjian Wen says:
*"Once I washed my ears by the green stream,

*"The ancestral intent from the west knows no east or west,

How many travelers gaze in vain—

Master Su’an Ding says:

Fragrance rises from both banks, drunken on the warm breeze,

Master Meng’an [ ] says:
*"Rising early to cherish the flowers, sitting in the spring wind,
another has already played with red and green.
Hand in hand, drunk beneath the blossoms,
unaware of the layered shadows of clouds and moon."*

Master Hengchuan Gong says:
*"Why must we join hands to raise one?
Just call the novice over.
The iron pot has no feet, no ears—

Master Donggu Guang says:
*"Three by three, two by two, none the same,
hand in hand, walking into the grass.
Turning back, slipping on embroidered shoes—

Master Yongjue Xian says:
*"Turn the pivot at the center—another mechanism,
a side path few have known.
Ancient halls, clouds deep, no footprints—
spring winds, growing grasses cross the former stream."*

Master Tudu Ce says:
*"The nature of mind has always been one,
through being and non-being, emptiness reveals true emptiness."*

From ancient times to now, those lost beyond delusion at the source—
spring enters the garden groves, red in every place.”

Master Yunzhang Han says:
*“Bright, bright the message reveals the whole mechanism,
a thousand-yard Chan radiance shines behind the skull.
Whether this or that, both are lifted away—
in Jiangnan’s third month, the partridge cries.”*

Master Kuimu Cheng says:
*“Spring winds stir, green waves sway,
countless boatmen chase the sea tides.
They see only gulls skimming white waves—
how would they know the bright moon dwells in the cloudy sky?”*

Master Zide Hui says:
*“The buddhas of the three times swallow all in one mouth,
the old mountain deep and still, moon at dusk.
Light splits the crown, the noon gate dawns—

Master Minshan Wei says:
*“Spring without feet wanders everywhere,
