Master Qianxu said: “Between nurturing and refining, one must still make distinctions.” Master Shangyang said: “Treasure essence and enrich qi—this is nurturing the self; facing circumstances without attachment—this is refining the self. Nurturing the self emphasizes stillness, while refining the self encompasses activity.”

Thus, to remain unstained by even a speck of dust, to empty all myriad thoughts, to abide in constant stillness while constantly responding, to dwell in activity yet remain ever tranquil—this is the work of refining the self. To be full of qi and whole in spirit, to restore and accumulate early—this is the effect of nurturing the self. If one unites and penetrates these, the work ultimately lies nowhere but in the interdependence of mind and breath. When this interdependence reaches great samādhi, nurturing the self resides here, and refining the self also resides here.

Someone asked: “Using samādhi to nurture the self aligns with the *Triple Concordance Canon*’s saying, ‘Internally to nurture the self, abide in tranquil emptiness’—its meaning is easily understood. But to say that samādhi refines the self seems contrary to Master Qianxu’s principle of refining the self as encompassing activity. Could you further elucidate this?”

He replied: “At the moment when spirit and breath are both settled, both inner and outer are empty. Because of this inner and outer emptiness and stillness, the primordial true yang is drawn to my body. The true qi steams and permeates the *ying* and *wei*, just as plants receive sweet dew, making my body and mind daily stronger—this is what is meant by nurturing the self. Yet though I am empty and still, when the primordial true yang arrives at my body, my entire being becomes soft and numb, undergoing various transformations of the *se*-skandha, while I remain unmoved and serene, as if unaware—responding yet still, like fire forging gold, the gold does not change color but grows ever more refined and luminous. Is this not refining the self?

Furthermore, because of great samādhi, the *vijñāna*-spirit gradually submits, the original spirit gradually manifests, habitual tendencies gradually dissolve, and worldly toils gradually cease. What the ancients called ‘the heart dies and the spirit lives’—is this not the meaning of refining the self? Though Master Qianxu spoke of refining the self as encompassing activity, the essence of refining the self truly lies in activity without activity. For stillness reaches its extreme and gives rise to movement—this movement is the movement of qi. When qi moves, the spirit immediately awakens. If this awakening drifts outward, spirit and qi separate, and the primordial instantly transforms into the acquired. If the awakening does not drift outward but remains settled externally, spirit and qi do not separate, and they are sent back to the earthen cauldron to be firmly sealed. Thus, both nurturing and refining the self ultimately hinge on a single word: *samādhi*. Samādhi is the non-duality of stillness and response—the Dao of the elixir begins and ends with it. As the *Book of Changes* says: ‘That which begins the myriad things and ends the myriad things—nothing is more flourishing than *gèn*.’ *Gèn* is stillness and cessation of movement—this is samādhi.”

Someone asked: “Then do nurturing the self and refining the self have a sequence? Is there an intention that they mutually support one another?”

He replied: “Nurturing the self and refining the self indeed rely on each other. Though there is no inherent sequence, it is not incorrect to speak of one. Why? The essence of nurturing the self depends on the cultivation of primordial true yang, so that my original qi grows daily more abundant and my original spirit daily more flourishing. Yet for every portion of primordial true yang that enters, a portion of acquired yin qi is dissolved. As yin qi is dissolved, deluded thoughts and desires diminish accordingly. For these desires are entirely the mischief of yin qi. Thus, the more abundant the true yang, the purer the mind. The deeper the work progresses, the more habitual tendencies and discriminating views are transformed, the fewer deluded thoughts arise, until one faces circumstances with suchness, unstained by even a speck of dust, all myriad thoughts emptied—all this is caused by the primordial true yang dissolving the delusions of the mind. That refining the self draws upon nurturing the self is abundantly clear.

Moreover, as delusions daily dissolve and monthly transform, the central earth of the self grows ever stiller, body and mind ever more tranquil, and the power of samādhi ever increases. The primordial true yang from without is increasingly drawn in, until qi is sufficient and the fire is withdrawn—the returning elixir is formed. That nurturing the self supports refining the self is also beyond doubt.”

Thus, refining and nurturing mutually support one another. Though the ancients spoke of "nurturing in stillness" and "refining in activity," this was framed in terms of the opposition between movement and quiescence. When movement and quiescence merge as one, stillness is ever-responsive, and responsiveness is ever-still—refining is nurturing, and the work proceeds as a single, unbroken practice. There is nothing to divide, nor any need to divide, hence the saying: "It does not depart from the single word *quiescence*."

**89. Nurturing the Self and Refining the Self (II)**
The Way of the Golden Elixir was called "learning the undifferentiated" in ancient times. The Old Sage spoke of "guarding the center and embracing the One," while Zhuangzi simply said "guarding the One and abiding in harmony." There was no mention of nurturing the self or refining the self. During the Western Han, Master Cui Xifan’s *Mirror for Entering the Medicine* comprised eighty-two verses in two hundred forty-six characters, encompassing the entire Dao of the Elixir without once referring to nurturing or refining the self.

One may ask: "When, then, did such terms arise?"
The answer: "In the Eastern Han, Master Wei Boyang’s *Triplex Unity* states: *'Inwardly nurture the self, abiding in tranquil emptiness. The root is hidden yet luminous, inwardly illuminating the body.'* This is the origin of the term *nurturing the self*. The term *refining the self* first appears in texts after the Tang and Song dynasties. The Pure Yang Realized One’s *Lyrics to the Melody ‘Spring in Qin Garden’* says: *'The sevenfold-returned elixir requires one first to refine the self and await the time.'* Master Sanfeng’s *Lyrics to the Melody ‘A Sprig of Flowers’* says: *'Moment by moment, rein in the horse of the mind; instant by instant, refine the monkey of the heart. Day and night without rest, the work of refining the self is unceasing.'* By the Ming dynasty, Master Qianxu’s *Rectifying the Golden Elixir* provided precise instructions on refining the self."

I say: The Dao of the Elixir is fundamentally simple. For one who attains the samādhi of heart and breath interdependently harmonized, nurturing the self with true water and refining the self with true fire leaves nothing unaddressed. True water is the water of true emptiness of nature, the true emptiness of the water of nature. True fire is the fire of true emptiness of nature, the true emptiness of the fire of nature. When the work reaches true stillness and true emptiness, refining and nurturing are both subsumed, the wondrous aperture and mystery merge as one, and all is unified.

**90. Subduing the Dragon and Taming the Tiger**
The *Triplex Unity* states:
*"The crescent moon forms the furnace and crucible,
the White Tiger serves as the pivot of refinement.
Mercury, the sun, becomes flowing pearls,
the Green Dragon accompanies it.
Raise the east to meet the west,
and the hun and po naturally bind one another."*
Elsewhere it says:
*"The Dragon calls to the Tiger,
the Tiger inhales the Dragon’s essence.
The two consume one another,
both covetously merging."*
Though the phrasing is plain, its implications run deep.

Master Ziyang’s *Awakening to Reality* says:
*"The White Tiger of the western mountains rages wildly,
the Green Dragon of the eastern sea cannot be withstood.
Seize them with both hands and force them to fight to the death,
and they transform into a lump of purple gold frost."*

The *Four Hundred Character Inscription on the Golden Elixir* says:
*"The Dragon comes from the eastern sea,
the Tiger rises from the western mountains.
The two beasts battle fiercely,
transforming into the marrow of heaven and earth."*

Another verse, *Song for Master Liu the Daoist*, says:
*"When the season arrives, employ the matchmaker.
The Metal Elder and the Maiden of Mercury wed.
The Metal Elder prefers to ride the White Tiger,
the Maiden of Mercury ever mounts the Crimson Dragon’s form.
The Tiger comes to rest in the autumn mountains,
the Dragon stirs from the azure depths.
The two beasts meet and battle fiercely,
waves surging and seething like a boiling cauldron.
The Yellow Dame and Ding the Elder lend their might,
shaking heaven and earth, startling gods and ghosts.
In an instant, the battle ends, clouds and rain disperse,
and a mysterious pearl is planted in the mud below."*

The *Song of Stone Bridge* says:
*"I dwell within the mountains, truly boasting much,
where flowers that never wither grow everywhere.
North of the mountain, a cave conceals a fierce tiger,
emerging to roar, wind and rosy clouds arise.
South of the mountain, a deep pool hides a scaly dragon,
ascending in clouds, descending in rain, the mountain shrouded in mist.
When the two beasts meet and battle,
the hidden pearl is the true omen of the mysterious."*

Master Ziyang vividly depicts the battle of Dragon and Tiger, evoking awe and dread. I once raised this with my teacher, Wang, who said: "When heart and breath depend on one another, the Dragon is naturally subdued. What else remains unresolved? Do not cling to words or fixate on phrases."

Lu Qianxu remarked: "It is only because of the phrase *'the two tigers fight'* that misguided and heterodox schools have proliferated." Thus, in his *Exegesis on the Four Hundred Characters*, he writes:
*"Kan-lead is hard to obtain yet easily devours people, hence symbolized by the Tiger. Li-mercury is prone to flight and difficult to control, hence symbolized by the Dragon. The Dragon comes from the eastern sea, coming to join the Tiger. The Tiger rises from the western mountains, rising to follow the Dragon. The elixir method drives the Dragon to join the Tiger, guides the Tiger to follow the Dragon, causing the two beasts to devour and consume one another, battling within the palace of wu and ji. When they merge and harmonize, they transform into the marrow of heaven and earth, and the returning elixir may be accomplished."*

Xuanjing said: "Subduing the Dragon means restraining the mind’s incessant delusion. Thoughts arise ceaselessly, galloping without pause, emerging and vanishing unpredictably, their origin unknown—hence likened to a Dragon. Taming the Tiger means mastering the breath’s ingress and egress. The breath is as difficult to regulate and tame as a Tiger. Thus, subduing the Dragon is subduing the mind, and taming the Tiger is taming the qi. The wonder lies in the interdependence of heart and breath beyond the body. When the heart depends on the breath, it congeals; when the breath depends on the heart, it flows smoothly. Gradually they harmonize, growing ever finer and subtler, until they stand immovably still—thoughts arise and cease no more, the breath enters and exits no more. Then the efficacy of subduing the Dragon and taming the Tiger is manifest."

This is the foundational work of the Mysterious School. Furthermore, at the moment of extreme emptiness and profound stillness, when the primordial true qi arrives, the entire body feels a melting, tingling sensation. If one stirs even the slightest thought at this juncture, the primordial instantly reverts to the postnatal, causing harm rather than benefit.

Thus, at the very instant the melting, tingling sensation arises, swiftly depart from the physical form and turn toward the interdependence of heart and breath beyond the body. Persist in this until settling into samādhi, whereupon true yin and true yang naturally fuse, returning to the earthen cauldron to be firmly sealed. This primordial true qi is also likened to the Tiger; when subdued through great samādhi, it congeals into the Elixir, no longer scattering outward.

The primordial true yang most effectively purges the delusions of the mind-ground, rendering one’s nature quiescent and emotions empty. With the heart stabilized and breath subdued, one remains unperturbed by phenomena, no longer drifting into distraction—this is the mastery of spirit through qi, what the alchemical texts call "true Lead restraining true Mercury."

The *Book of Changes* states: *"Treading on the Tiger’s tail, it does not bite the person—propitious."* This is the image of taming the Tiger. It further says: *"Using the Nine, one sees a host of Dragons without a leader—auspicious."* This is the image of subduing the Dragon.

Thus, the interdependence of heart and breath is the starting point of subduing Dragon and Tiger; great samādhi and true emptiness are its gradual stages. When the celestial nature unfolds in clarity and Dragon and Tiger leave no trace, this is the ultimate fruition of their subjugation.

**Verse:**
*(Adapted from the gāthās of Chan Master Puming and others, replacing "ox" and "man" with "Dragon" and "Tiger," for the Chan metaphor of herding the ox shares the same purport as the Daoist subjugation of Dragon and Tiger.)*

Dragon and Tiger vanish without a trace,
Bright moon’s light embraces the ten thousand forms.
Should you ask the true meaning therein—
Wildflowers and fragrant grasses grow in profusion.

No shadow of Dragon, no track of Tiger,
Why carve steps into the vast emptiness?
In the end, nothing whatsoever remains,
Yet the ten thousand forms naturally abound.

Seeking their radiance in vain,
No Dragon, no Tiger—mist and water dissolve into space.
As the great earth awakens from spring’s dream,
The sun climbs high, incense scatters, flowers bloom in clusters.

No trace of Dragon or Tiger to be found,
Like the pure moon pervading empty space.
Why inquire further into its meaning?
Birds sing of themselves, flowers bloom of themselves.

A life built on the tip of a snail’s horn,
From the outset, they share a single home.
How laughable that ancients left this image—
Thirty feet of wisteria vine leave no room for delay.

---

**91. Refining and Withdrawing-Adding**

What is meant by "civil refinement and martial tempering"? In a word, it is the state where spirit and qi harmoniously merge, and body and mind remain unmoving.

Li Daochun’s *Zhonghe Collection* states: *"Someone asked, ‘What is refining?’ I replied: ‘At the moment when body and mind are about to unite yet remain ununited, if even the slightest stray thought intrudes, confront it with resolute determination—this is martial tempering. After body and mind have united and spirit and qi have merged, guard it with a gentle, harmonious heart—this is civil refinement.’"* There is no other principle here; simply subduing body and mind is the refining of Lead and Mercury.

To forget emotions and nurture nature, to empty the heart and cultivate spirit, to instantly still the myriad conditions and clarify the hundred thoughts—this is the foundation of the Elixir, likened to the Sacred Embryo.

The oral instruction says: The wondrous union of heart and breath in the Mysterious School, with a single intent of harmonious merging, is the work of refining. The state of being indistinct and vague, profound and obscure, chaotic and undifferentiated—this is the landscape of refinement. If distinguished in detail, then the interdependence of breath is martial tempering, while the absence of breath in samādhi is civil refinement.

What is meant by "withdrawing-adding"? It refers to withdrawing Lead and adding Mercury. The work lies solely in the word "settling"; when body and mind attain great samādhi, the Dao-embryo naturally rounds itself. No contrivance is needed—naturally, there is withdrawal without withdrawing, addition without adding. This is the wondrous function of non-action and non-effort.

Lu Qianxu’s *Treatise on Withdrawing-Adding* states: *"Someone asked about the principle of withdrawing Lead and adding Mercury. I replied: I heard from Master Liyang that after obtaining the Medicine and returning it to the cauldron, one nurtures it with the natural true Fire, continuously and subtly present. Within this, the transformations of withdrawing and adding arise spontaneously, without allowing the slightest use of intellect or force. For the Dao is non-action, yet spirit and qi naturally act in accord with the wondrous workings of creation. It is like cooking rice—one and the same principle. When Lead is added to Mercury, it is like water being poured into rice. The water must not be excessive, nor the rice too scant—just as the two eights correspond. With even fire, the water gradually dries while the rice gradually swells, becoming cooked rice. The drying of the water is called withdrawing Lead; the swelling of the rice is called adding Mercury. Withdrawing is not internal reduction—spirit enters qi as heaven’s qi moves within earth, its mechanism concealed. Adding is not external overflow—qi envelops spirit as earth’s qi receives heaven, gradually nurturing growth. Thus, the embryo rounds and spirit transforms, giving rise to a body beyond the body. The wondrousness of creation reaches this point, all occurring naturally, without knowing how or why. If one seeks to understand the how and why of withdrawing and adding, it is no longer natural."*

The *Verse Commentary on the Golden Elixir’s Verification* further states: *"Yet one must also know that when Lead and Mercury combine to form the Elixir, it is like salt dissolving in water, like glue blending with color. How can one then distinguish which is Lead, which is Mercury, or what can be withdrawn or added? Ah! The Returned Elixir is also emptiness—at this point, idle chatter is in vain."*

Li Daochun’s *Zhonghe Collection* states: *"Someone asked, ‘What is withdrawing-adding?’ I replied: ‘The body unmoving and qi settled is called withdrawing; spirit settled and heart unmoving is called adding. Body and mind unmoving, spirit congealed and qi bound—this is called returning to the origin. Thus, extracting the yang from Kan to replenish the yin in Li and form Qian is called withdrawing Lead and adding Mercury.’"*

Xuanjing said: *"When body and mind are unmoving, this is the Great Fixation. Spirit and qi conjoin in stillness, merging into a single crucible. With long-continued quiescent illumination, qi is wholly transformed into spirit, and the numinous radiance shines alone—all phenomena dissolve and fuse. Is this not the sign of the perfected embryo? The Patriarch Lu likened it to cooked rice, a most apt comparison. The essential point of Elixir-making lies in the Great Fixation: when body and mind are quiescent and unmoving, Lead and Mercury return to True Earth. Steaming and refining, withdrawing and adding, bathing and gentle nurturing, shedding the embryo and spiritual transformation—all are contained within it. Thus it is said to be most simple and most easy."*

**Ninety-Two: Extracting Kan to Fill Li**
Master Ziyang’s *Awakening to Reality* states:
*"Extract the solid center from the Kan position,
Transmute the yin within the Li palace.
From this, transform into the vigorous body of Qian—
Whether hidden or soaring, all depends on the heart."*

Master Sanfeng’s *Essentials of the Mysterious* states:
*"Extract the Elixir from within Kan,
A golden blossom reveals a single stem.
Auspicious clouds unfold across the heavens,
Propitious light fills the gates of death."*

The Mysterious Tradition borrows the images of the *Yijing* to illustrate the Dao of the Elixir. The true yang within Kan is originally Qian’s former property; only after falling into the posterior heaven does Qian break to become Li, and this one yang sink into the Kan position. Now, employing the method of return, one extracts the solid from Kan to fill the hollow in Li, thereby restoring the Qian trigram and reverting from old age to youth. When the practitioner’s cultivation reaches the point of utter emptiness and profound stillness, the whole body softens and numbs—this is precisely the moment when the three yang of Kan enter. Nurturing it with the Great Fixation, gradually gathering and congealing, one proceeds until the Elixir forms, and the work of extracting Kan to fill Li is complete. The crucial point is to recognize the one move beyond the body’s empty space, for then extraction has its locus.

This image of extracting Kan to fill Li traces its origin to Nüwa’s smelting stones to mend the heavens. Even in Zhuangzi’s *Free and Easy Wandering*, the passage *"The roc charts its course southward"* subtly reveals this image. The *Free and Easy Wandering* states:
*"In the Northern Darkness there is a fish, its name is Kun. The Kun is so vast that no one knows how many thousands of miles it spans. It transforms into a bird, its name is Peng. The Peng’s back is so vast that no one knows how many thousands of miles it spans. When it rises in flight, its wings are like clouds hanging from the sky. This bird, when the sea surges, will journey to the Southern Darkness. The Southern Darkness is the Celestial Pond. The *Qi Xie* records strange matters. It says: When the Peng journeys to the Southern Darkness, the water churns for three thousand miles. It mounts upon the whirlwind and ascends ninety thousand miles, departing on the sixth-month gale."*

This passage arrives as if cleaving the void, sweeping across with unbridled force.

Those who do not understand dismiss it as mere absurdity; to those who have grasped the secret, it is immediately clear as the work of "borrowing from Kan to fill Li." Let me briefly interpret its imagery:

The fish in the Northern Darkness symbolizes the true yang within Kan, for Kan resides in the north. Its transformation into a bird signifies the moment when qi stirs with the season. "Rising in flight" denotes the upward surge of qi. "Its wings like clouds hanging from the sky" describes the billowing ascent, white qi filling the void—just as Lü Zu said, "White clouds ascend to the upper gate," and as Master Zi Yang put it, "At first, it is like clouds filling a thousand mountains." The Southern Darkness represents Li in the south. Zhuangzi’s pairing of north and south mirrors the opposition of Li and Kan. This bird’s migration from north to south—is this not the movement of *wu* flowing to *ji*, the very process of "borrowing from Kan to fill Li"?

Zhuangzi’s analogy of Kun and Peng refers precisely to the true yang qi. This primordial qi is vast and unyielding, so immense that none can measure its thousands of miles. When the Peng migrates to the Southern Darkness, "the water churns for three thousand miles"—these three thousand miles signify the three yang of Qian. "Mounting the whirlwind to ascend ninety thousand miles" refers to the nine of Qian. In the alchemical practice of "fierce fire refinement" (where heart and breath interdepend externally), the image of nine is employed; in "gentle fire nurturance" (where breath ceases in samadhi), the image of six is used. Movement corresponds to Qian, stillness to Kun. The true yang within Kan is originally Qian’s own essence, hence the three thousand and ninety thousand both align with Qian’s imagery.

As the true yang ascends, the bellows are stirred to aid its progress, lest it stall midway. Fire blazes with wind, surging through the three barriers to pierce the crown of the head—this is the subtlety of employing nine. The following line, "departing on the sixth-month gale," refers to the six lines of Kun. Kun embodies stillness. Here, at the gate of Kun’s return, stillness reaches its extreme and gives rise to movement. Receiving this true yang qi of Qian, refined with gentle fire, the Elixir of Return is formed, replenishing primordial yang to restore the Qian state—this is called "rejuvenation." Nine is the number of yang, yet within it, the six yin symbols are already implicit.

This passage is profoundly esoteric; for two thousand years, no one has fully expounded its meaning—truly, discerning truth is difficult. Liu Xin classified the works of Zhuangzi and Liezi as Daoist, while categorizing the esoteric scriptures of immortals under "miscellaneous arts," revealing his failure to grasp the source of the Dao. Is the cultivation of immortals not the Dao? Did Laozi, Zhuangzi, Liezi, and Guan Yin not succeed in Daoist practice and become immortals? The principles of alchemical classics do not exceed those of Laozi, Zhuangzi, Guan Yin, and their peers; they merely employ symbolic language, making comprehension elusive.

The *Baopuzi* claimed, "Laozi’s discussions are too broad and vague, while Zhuangzi, Wenzi, Guan Yin, and their followers, though following the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, never reached the ultimate teachings, remaining a thousand *li* from the path of immortality." Alas! Such a statement betrays a lack of reflection. In this collection, the profound meanings of Laozi, Zhuangzi, Liezi, Guan Yin, and others are fully revealed and exhaustively expounded. If Ge Hong were to see this, one wonders what his reaction would be!

---

**93. Jade Refinement and Gold Refinement**
The Mystic School speaks of "jade liquid refining the form" and "gold liquid refining the form," later termed *jade refinement* and *gold refinement*. Jade is prized for its warmth and luster; where jade lies hidden in the mountains, grasses and trees never wither. The human body is the same—when true qi is abundant, the skin glows, the complexion brightens, and one’s spirit becomes robust and flourishing. The *Cantong Qi* states, "The yellow center gradually permeates reason, its moisture reaching the skin"—this is the effect of jade refinement.

Gold is valued for its indestructibility, like the unbreakable vajra. After attaining the Great Return Elixir through cultivation, one transcends the ordinary to enter sagehood, the Dharma body enduring eternally, unharmed through kalpas. Hence, the term *gold refinement*, and the Elixir is called the *Golden Elixir*. Traditionally, practitioners often regard inner nurturance—serene and non-action—as *jade refinement*, while the refinement of the Great Return Elixir, the transformation of the spirit and shedding of the mortal form, is called *gold refinement*. The distinction between the Lesser and Great Returns is thus framed as *jade* and *gold refinement*, yet the practice fundamentally revolves around the interdependence of heart and breath.

When one reaches the state of great samadhi, internally, the seven returns occur, the lead cauldron warming gently. Externally, the nine returns manifest, the primordial unity of qi responding to every stimulus, merging with body and mind into a single furnace, forged into one. This is the simultaneous nurturance of inner and outer, the unity of heaven and humanity—golden resonance and jade vibration, all pervaded by one principle.

---

**94. Subduing Qi and Ingesting Qi**
The ancients said:
*"Subdue qi without ingesting it; ingest qi only after subduing it.
Ingesting qi does not grant longevity; longevity requires subduing qi."*

To subdue qi is to guide qi with spirit, heart and breath interdependent, transforming ordinary breath into true breath—the wondrous mystery of the primordial natural Dao, the true essence of the unity of nature and life. Ingesting qi is a method of post-heaven intention, akin to what moderns call "breathing fresh air"—exhaling the old and inhaling the new, like Western deep breathing or China’s ancient practices of "preserving spirit and swallowing qi." Unaware of the crucial step of transcending the void outside the body, one cannot attain the marvel of true breathlessness, relying instead on post-heaven respiration to draw in air. Such practices of exhalation, inhalation, and guiding qi merely bring comfort and longevity.

Subduing qi, however, severs external respiration, returning breath to the origin. Body and mind settle into stillness, the true void within sensing the wondrous existence beyond. Wondrous existence and true void merge seamlessly, forged into one, coalescing into the Dao embryo. Transcending the ordinary to enter sagehood—its power is immense.

Purple Clarity Elder said: "Refining the elixir with fire to form the cinnabar is precisely guiding qi with spirit to attain the Dao." This is the teaching of subduing qi. Subduing qi begins with regulating breath.

Xu Jingsun said: "Internally harmonizing true qi while preserving breath, naturally the transformations of creation restore youthful countenance." Cao Wenyu said: "Concentrating qi to achieve softness, spirit lingers long; the coming and going of true breath flows effortlessly." Lü Zu said: "Cease striving at the alchemical furnace and river chariot; the crane’s embryo and tortoise’s breath extend endlessly." Longmeizi said: "Breathing yin and yang should be silent; regulating inhalation and exhalation must be continuous." All these speak to the essence of regulating breath. When breath is regulated to stillness, the work of subduing qi manifests.

**95. Ordinary Breath and True Breath**
Ordinary breath is the inhalation and exhalation through our mouth and nose. One exhalation and one inhalation make a single breath. Exhalation expands and belongs to yang; inhalation contracts and belongs to yin. This breath through the mouth and nose begins when we leave the womb, hence it is called ordinary breath. All ordinary people, day and night, never depart from this breath.

The alchemical school employs the method of mind and breath interdependent, uniting mind with breath. Spirit and qi merge, gradually harmonizing and refining until they seem to exist yet not exist. At this time, the eighty-four thousand pores open, true qi steams and permeates, blending into blissful ease—soft, tranquil, and indescribable. As Zhang Jinghe’s *Tai Xi Jue* says: "Like fish in a spring pond, like hibernating insects. Vast qi fuses, numinous winds stir. Neither turbid nor clear, neither mouth nor nose. No going, no coming, no exiting, no entering." This is the true realm.

When ordinary breath ceases, true breath naturally appears. Once true breath appears, true qi naturally arises, yang fire advances, and yin tally retreats. Thus it is said: the breath that does not breathe is called true breath.

**96. Mysterious Breath and Embryonic Breath**
The *Da Dong Jing* states: "Stabilize harmony, wondrous clarity, and mysterious breath ensures longevity." Mysterious breath is true breath, also called embryonic breath, spirit breath, or tortoise breath. When spirit and qi embrace, the mind holds no thoughts, with no going or coming, external breath ceases, and the embryo congeals—hence it is also called embryonic breath, resembling the breath of an infant in the womb.

Master Ma said: "The cavernous void is pure and still; mysterious breath flows unimpeded, without obstruction, inner and outer both clear." He also said: "Let not the thunderous void startle you; receiving the register, golden blossoms yield jade essence. Nurturing clarity to return to the Great Beginning, continuous mysterious breath ensures longevity."

The term "mysterious" means that one’s breath aligns with the breath of the void and the breath of heaven and earth. Thus one can seize the creative power of heaven and earth, congealing the numinous elixir in an instant. If external breath does not cease, it cannot be called mysterious. This embryonic breath is the precursor to the return in the Mysterious School. One must grasp the crucial step of the void beyond the body, entering qi with spirit, gradually regulating and harmonizing, refining and subtling, until breath naturally stills, the body merges with the void, and one dissolves into samādhi—only then does one enter the wondrous realm of mysterious breath.

**97. Responding to Stars and Responding to Tides**
Master Cui’s *Ru Yao Jing* speaks of "heaven responding to stars, earth responding to tides." Commentators have expounded much on principle but revealed little of the secret. From my observation, it precisely illustrates the image of mind and breath interdependent.

How so? Heaven responding to stars refers to the fire within *li*, a single point of spirit-light—our own numinous awareness. Reflecting inward and congealing into the qi cavity, like starlight shining downward, the *kan* water receives the steaming of the *li* sun, naturally transforming into ascending qi, like the tide flowing upstream. This is the wondrous function of the five phases inverted: fire, which flames upward, is made to descend; water, which flows downward, is made to ascend. Thus *kan* and *li* merge, and water and fire assume the image of completion.

The secret says: When mind and breath externally align, heart-fire does not flame upward but shines downward. Once heart-light shines downward, kidney-water naturally transforms into ascending qi and no longer rushes downward. When postnatal yin and yang merge, body and mind settle into stillness, naturally achieving the arising of yang in quiescence. When the time arrives, the wondrous principle manifests: the single yang within *kan* surges upward, the true fluid within *li* descends, metal and water merge, the four images unite, and the work of seven returns is accomplished.

Thus, when mind and breath externally align, *kan* and *li* internally merge. Responding to stars and tides is like an echo answering a call—its marvel is beyond conception.

**98. Profound Obscurity and Primal Obscurity**
*Laozi* said: "Profound, obscure—within it lies essence." *Zhuangzi* said: "The essence of the supreme Dao is profoundly obscure." Lü Zu said: "How to recognize the profoundly profound Dao? The Dao lies in profound obscurity—examine it closely." He also said: "Profoundly obscure, obscurely profound, born of vagueness; vaguely, hazily, it coalesces into a mass." Li Daochun said: "Vast qi congeals spirit in profound obscurity, emerging from existence and entering non-existence in vagueness."

An ancient immortal said: "True lead is not produced within the five metals; it is born in profound obscurity before heaven and earth." Ning Xuanzhi said: "Not in worldly toil, not in mountains—seek directly the source of profound obscurity." Chaoyuanzi said: "The enlightened ruler governs, myriad states clear; a single stream of the Yellow River connects to profound obscurity." He also said: "Profoundly, obscurely, primally harmonious—white and clear. Three return to the homeland; the heir apparent returns to the eastern sea."

Cangmingzi said: "Within the vague and obscure, there is an image—only then does one know the utmost mystery of creation." He also said: "Water and fire ascend and descend into the Yellow Court; the union of true essence congeals in profound obscurity." Chen Xiyi said: "When profound obscurity just reveals a trace, the vague and hazy still do not distinguish self from other." Master Sanfeng said: "Within profound obscurity, there is trust; in vagueness, there is no seeing or hearing." Wang Yangming said: "Leisurely observing the forms of things, all teem with life; in stillness, one awakens to heaven’s mechanism and enters profound obscurity."

Such verses and gathas are too numerous to cite in full. In sum, *yaoming* ("profound obscurity") is where spirit and qi merge in darkness, entering a state like drunkenness yet not drunkenness—this is the sign of embryonic breathing. Only when spirit and qi unite can one summon primordial true yang. Then, within stillness, movement arises, and true essence is born. Thus, to gather the primordial, one must deeply enter profound obscurity, attain utmost emptiness and profound stillness, and respond to every stimulus—naturally, the medicine takes form with an image.

*Zhuangzi* said: "Exhaust life and fulfill emotion, and heaven and earth rejoice while all affairs vanish. All things return to their nature—this is called *hunming* ('chaotic obscurity')." Lu Fanghu said: "Life is what heaven bestows; emotion is what nature emits. Exhaust life and fulfill emotion, and the center is attained, harmony is also attained. Thus, above and below flow as one with heaven and earth, and the burdens of things are entirely dissolved. Hence it is said: 'Heaven and earth rejoice while all affairs vanish.' 'All things return to their nature'—this is called *hunming*: restraining one’s nature and returning to it. When emotion is fully expressed, all expressions are harmonious. Returning to nature means being utterly still and motionless, returning to the center. Returning to the center, one is dim and silent, equal to the primordial chaos. Hence it is said: 'This is called *hunming*.' The art of chaos is nothing but this cultivation."

Xuanjing said: *Hunming* is merging with profound obscurity, the very image of chaos, directly entering the great samadhi of true concentration, blending with the Dharma-realm’s great unity. This is what *Laozi* meant by "returning to the limitless."

Thus, from the initial concentration of profound obscurity, one transitions into the great concentration of *hunming*, where the burdens of things are entirely dissolved, and cultivated nature returns to virtue.

---

Laozi said: "The Dao models itself on spontaneity." The *Cantong Qi* said: "What spontaneity does is no false or deceptive Dao." It also said: "Yang abides in harmony, and nature and emotion are spontaneous." Lü Zu said: "Cease thoughts, forget schemes, and merge with spontaneity." The *Zhao Lun* said: "Serene and profoundly silent, one wondrously accords with spontaneity." The *Xinxin Ming* said: "Observing all dharmas equally, all return to spontaneity." It also said: "Grasping it, one loses measure and must enter deviant paths. Releasing it to spontaneity, the body has no coming or going."

Cangmingzi said: "The great Dao is empty and void, following spontaneity. Beyond spontaneity, there is no mystery. Be supple and focus qi like an infant—hungry, seek food; tired, sleep." The *Yinfu Jing* said: "The Dao of spontaneity is still, thus heaven, earth, and the myriad things are born." It also said: "Therefore, the sage knows the Dao of spontaneity cannot be violated and thus regulates it accordingly." This is the evidence that both Chan and Daoism value spontaneity.

Laozi also said: "What cannot be seen is called *yi* ('subtle'); what cannot be heard is called *xi* ('rare'); what cannot be grasped is called *wei* ('minute'). These three cannot be further questioned, so they merge into one." He also said: "Chaotic, as if turbid." Dongshan said: "Chaotic, with nothing to hide—what more is there to seek?" Caoshan said: "Chaotic, without inside or outside, harmonious and level above and below." He also said: "Chaotic, concealing principle and phenomena—its signs are utterly obscure. Before the King of Awesome Sound awakened, how could Maitreya be alert?" This is further evidence that both Chan and Daoism value chaos.

What, then, is the ultimate difference?

It is answered: Returning to the limitless, chaotic and without trace. Principle and phenomena both vanish; merit and rank both conceal—this is called *hunran* ("chaotic"). *Hunran* is the image of chaos. *Ziran* ("spontaneity") is acting without effort, still and serene—like a bright mirror reflecting images, an empty valley echoing sounds, each following its capacity without imposing the self. This is the wondrous function of the true Dao.

The excellence of *hunran* is the virtue of chaotic completion—this is the wondrous essence of the Dao. In terms of practice: when mind and breath interdepend to utmost purity, the mind naturally follows the breath, and the breath naturally follows the mind, without allowing the self to arise in intention or arrangement. Even all firing times must not be controlled by the self. When the tally naturally accords, this is the primordial realm, the verification of wondrously merging with spontaneity.

As practice deepens, even this wondrous state of spontaneity is forgotten. Chaotic and undifferentiated, unknowing and unaware—even if yang arises, the mind remains utterly still and unmoved, no different from unawareness. At this stage, wondrousness is exhausted and merit is forgotten, returning to simplicity. Profoundly still, the physical body gradually reverts to childlike purity. The Gate of Yang closes, the consciousness-nature gradually transforms, and all unwholesome habits are smelted away. Body and mind both assume the image of childlike purity. This chaotic true realm is the secret key to returning to childhood and the mysterious mechanism of restoring life.

The *Goulou Bearing the Cicada*, *Boatman Steering the Boat*, *Carpenter Making a Saw*, *Gongchui Turning the Lathe* in Zhuangzi’s *Attaining Life*, and the *Butcher Ding Carving the Ox* in the *Nourishing Life* chapter all illustrate the firing times of spontaneity. As for Ji Sheng’s raising the fighting cock to become a wooden cock—this precisely illustrates the firing times of chaos.

100. **Softness and Numbness**
Through the interdependence of heart and breath, long and pure refinement is achieved. The spirit settles with the breath, and the breath transforms with the spirit. At this stage, breathing shifts from the mouth and nose to the pores—opening and closing in harmony with heaven and earth, empty and natural. The true yang of heaven and earth then permeates the four limbs and hundred bones, penetrating the five viscera and six bowels, bringing a sensation of melting softness and bliss. As the practice deepens, the softness intensifies, from the crown to the soles, permeating both inside and out. When softness reaches its extreme, it turns into numbness. This numbness manifests in three distinct forms: first, numbness during the interdependence of heart and breath; second, numbness in the state of dim indistinctness; and third, numbness within profound stillness. To attain numbness in stillness is precisely the moment of circulating the *Small Celestial Cycle*. These subtle transformations of firing times are unrecorded in the myriad volumes of alchemical texts, transmitted only through a master’s oral instruction.

---

101. **Before and After Gui**
The *Wuzhen Pian* states: *"When lead encounters gui’s arising, swiftly gather it; when gold meets the full moon’s decline, it is no longer fit to taste."* This clarifies gathering before gui. Zhang Sanfeng’s *Xuan Yao Pian* says: *"The Supreme Dao, proclaimed again, reveals the secret of pre-heaven and post-heaven. It speaks only of lead arising after gui, not of yang arising before gui."* It further states: *"When the lead flower appears at gui’s end, the Western Garden’s branches bloom once more."* And: *"Lead arises after gui, yin and yang divide—just as the first crescent of metal and water fills, like orioles and flowers in spring’s second month."* This clarifies gathering after gui. The *Lesser Yang* and *Wenshi* schools diverge in their alchemical formulas—how can they be reconciled?

Master Xuanjing replied: I once heard from Master Wang that lead is yang, and gui is yin. When yin reaches its extreme, yang arises; when stillness reaches its limit, movement returns. Thus, it is said that lead arises only after gui. Yet the birth of true yang is swift as lightning, unable to linger in the pre-heavenly state. In an instant, it generates gui-water, turning yang into yin. Hence, it is said: *"When lead encounters gui’s arising, swiftly gather it; when gold meets the distant full moon, it is no longer fit to taste."* To gather swiftly at gui’s arising is precisely to act urgently before gui-water emerges. Thus, the *Wuzhen Pian* states: *"It cannot be used when seen; when used, it cannot be seen. In dim indistinctness, they meet; in profound obscurity, transformation occurs. In a flash, the flame soars, and the true person naturally appears."* Zhang Sanfeng’s *Xuan Yao Pian* also says: *"Seek the true seed where lightning flashes; trace the root source when the wind’s signal arrives."* Thus, whether before or after gui, the true mechanism of gathering holds subtle meanings within. When harmonized, the principle remains unified—they are not in conflict.

---

102. **Yang Fire and Yin Talisman**
Alchemists speak of advancing yang fire and retreating yin talisman, abbreviated as advancing fire and retreating talisman, also called talisman-fire. Master Ziyang’s *Wuzhen Pian* states: *"Gather in due time, discerning floating and sinking; advance fire cautiously to avoid peril."* And: *"When the first yang arises in renewal, advance fire without delay."* Longmeizi’s *Jindan Yinzheng Shi* says: *"At the hour of zi, advance fire; at gui, conceal it—this is the morning’s fire-advancing chapter. Respond to yin and yang in silence; regulate breath’s ebb and flow with continuity."* And: *"At the hour of zi, eighteen stars appear—this is the talisman-retreating fire cycle. As tamed ice begins with *Gou*, stored treasures fill *Kun*."* Master Qianxu said: *"Fire is the fire of spirit. Advancing fire nurtures yang; retreating talisman nurtures yin."* The *Preface to the Four Hundred Characters* states: *"Refined with yang fire, it transforms into yang qi; nourished with yin talisman, it transforms into yin essence."* The Dao of heaven and earth uses yang to generate and yin to complete. Thus, warmth, heat, cold, and coolness each follow their fixed order, and the myriad things thereby undergo generation, growth, harvest, and storage. The Dao of the golden elixir is no different.

I once posed this question to Master Wang, who replied: *"These are all metaphorical expressions, like fish traps and rabbit snares. The alchemical method simply involves the interdependence of heart and breath, until external breathing becomes faint, and the entire body melts into soft bliss. When primordial true yang arrives upon you, irrigating and steaming, advancing one part yang naturally retreats one part yin—just as advancing one part light retreats one part darkness. All occurs naturally, leaving no room for the slightest contrivance. This is what Ziyang meant when he said: ‘The great elixir’s method is utterly simple and easy. Its explanation is concise and precise, beyond further elaboration. Even the dull and ignorant, if they practice it, will immediately ascend to the realm of sages.’ If one relies on hexagrams, lines, and times to determine advancement and retreat, how could the dull and ignorant endure it?"*

Lu Qianxu’s *Canto on the Measurement of the Cantong Qi* states: *"Someone asked about advancing fire and retreating talisman. I replied: Fire is the fire of spirit—I already know this. But what is the yin talisman? Does it have any explanation? I heard from my immortal teacher regarding the seven returns and nine refinements: Seven is the number of fire, nine the number of metal. Refining metal with fire to form the elixir is like guiding qi with spirit to attain the Dao. From this perspective, the wondrous work of elixir-making begins and ends with a single fire. When advancing, it is fire; when retreating, it is talisman. Talisman means union—speaking of ascent and descent, advance and retreat, inner and outer in harmony. When circulating fire, spirit and qi embrace, holding to the One without separation, continuous as if present. It is but a single fire—where is there room for a yin talisman to be used?"*

Thus, in alignment with the hexagrams *Gou* (䷫), *Dun* (䷠), *Bo* (䷖), *Kun* (䷁), *Pi* (䷋), and *Guan* (䷓), we speak of "submission," "departure from position," "destruction and harm," "loss and disappearance," and "return to the origin"—all referring to yin in retreat. Just as after the full moon, yin gradually wanes, its light naturally diminishing, fading bit by bit until it reaches darkness, only to revive again as the new moon, this speaks of yang in advance, not of yin. If we were to speak of yin, we should instead speak of *advancing* talismans.

From this perspective, within our own bodies, where is there room for a yin talisman to be used?

Furthermore, the *Discourse on Fire Talismans* states:
"Someone asked about the similarities and differences between the advance and retreat of fire talismans, the morning *Tun* (䷂) and evening *Meng* (䷃). I replied: In the past, before receiving my teacher’s guidance, I privately considered the timing of fire difficult to discern. I once measured it against the celestial cycle, aligned it with hexagram qi, divided it by watches and clepsydra—all to no avail. Only later did I suddenly awaken, realizing that the ten thousand volumes of elixir classics and the six hundred fire records could all be discarded in an instant. The so-called true fire has no fixed timing, and the great medicine has no fixed weight—this was no deception."

I say: Indeed, as Master Wang has stated, when a single measure of primordial true yang advances, yin qi naturally retreats in equal measure, as if matching tally sticks. This is one explanation.

When heart and breath depend on each other, this is *advancing fire*, governing refinement. When this dependence deepens into samadhi and both spirit and breath are forgotten, this is *retreating talisman*, governing nurturance—just as the Perfected One of Hidden Emptiness said. This is another explanation. Movement is yang, stillness is yin; movement governs advance, stillness governs retreat.

**103. Igniting and Extinguishing Fire**
In elixir methods, igniting fire means heart and breath depending on each other, while extinguishing fire means forgetting both spirit and breath, entering samadhi in perfect tranquility. This is the common oral instruction.

My late teacher transmitted three secret methods for extinguishing fire:
1. **Extinguishing fire during essence refinement.** Without this method, one often becomes attached to the body, risking seminal emission. Whenever yang arises and the external yang stirs, leading to ejaculation, it is always due to ignorance of how to extinguish fire.
2. **Extinguishing fire during qi refinement.** Without this method, one often risks qi leakage, called "losing the elixir," rendering all prior efforts futile. Even the ancient Perfected One Bai Yuchan was not spared this calamity, as seen in his poem: *"I must re-rig my fishing rod, / And cut anew the autumn bamboo."* How much more so for others? Without knowing the initial method for extinguishing fire, the yang pass cannot be sealed, and the foundation of the elixir cannot be completed. Without knowing the second stage’s method, even with sufficient qi, one cannot form the elixir; after forming it, one cannot nurture it; and after the elixir matures to circulate the great celestial cycle, one cannot *"reinstall the furnace, reestablish the tripod, / Ride the tiger and mount the dragon to transcend the mortal realm."*
3. **Extinguishing fire during spirit refinement.** Without this method, samadhi cannot be perfected, the light of the heart cannot become whole, and one risks the peril of leakage, inevitably regressing to a lesser attainment. The ancient teaching of the three leakages (perception, emotion, and speech) and the principle of manifesting dignified conduct without departing from quiescent samadhi are both essential for verifying the completeness of nature and spirit in samadhi. This stage of extinguishing fire is most critical and most profound. Without it, one cannot refine nature to its subtlety or act without obstruction.

For four years, I studied under Master Wang. He often spoke of the initial method for extinguishing fire during essence refinement, never concealing it. However, the oral instructions for the latter two stages were only revealed during my final audience in the fourth year. After four years of diligent effort, I obtained them with difficulty and dare not record them carelessly. I treasure and guard them in secret. Scholars need only know that the Western Lineage’s transmission indeed includes three methods for extinguishing fire, ensuring safety, perfection, and transcendence.

For beginners, when yang first arises, desire is easily stirred, leading to seminal emission. At this moment, a clear teacher must impart the essential method to extinguish the postnatal ministerial fire, so that body and mind remain unmoved and the peril of leakage is avoided. Yet in recent times, many blind teachers do not even know how to remedy the ailment of yang arising and seminal emission, let alone understand the initial method for extinguishing fire during essence refinement. How could they possibly grasp the deeper, secret methods of the second and third stages, which lead to the boundless, freely self-existent state of *"shattering empty space"*?

The leakage of qi during the second stage of qi refinement is called "losing the elixir." In the indistinct, profound state, yang qi surges like wildfire, escaping through the *weilu* (tailbone), impossible to restrain—akin to seminal emission during essence refinement (though one leaks from the front, the other from the rear. After extinguishing fire, the yang pass is sealed, the front path blocked, and leakage occurs through the anus). Bai Yuchan’s *Poem on Failing to Refine the Elixir* says:
*"I gathered it into my jade gourd,
Guarding it closely, daring not to leak.
At midnight, thunder and wind suddenly arose,
Smoke and vapor filled the vast emptiness.
Such a state and flavor—
A mute biting his tongue.
Clutching my belly, I can only laugh,
Lest my heart grow vexed and hot.
I must re-rig my fishing rod,
And cut anew the autumn bamboo."*

This is the true circumstance of qi leakage. It arises from ignorance of how to extinguish fire, suffering this great calamity. If one leaks again upon re-refining and reaching qi sufficiency, progress in cultivation becomes impossible. Thus, the method for extinguishing fire at this stage is profoundly secret.

Someone asked: What fire is extinguished in the final stage?
I answered: The fire of ignorance. If the subtlest ignorance is not purified, nature cannot become whole. Only when ignorance is entirely dissolved and cleansed can one attain the wisdom of leakage’s end and thorough penetration. Having verified the absence of leakage, one transcends both the worldly and supraworldly, attaining unobstructed freedom.

Otherwise, one may attain only the five supernatural powers but not the sixth, which is the secret essential of completing the Dao through final return to emptiness.

This transmission traces from Ancestor Lü to Ancestor Li, from Ancestor Li to the Perfected One of Western Garden, from the Perfected One to Master Wang, and thence to me. Between these four transmissions, less than a century has passed—truly what Master Qianxu called “the fortune of three lifetimes, the rare encounter of a thousand years.”

**Section 104: The Geng Month and the Full Moon**

The *Geng* month refers to the moon of the third day. The full moon refers to the moon of the fifteenth day.

The *Cantong Qi* states: “On the third day it emerges bright, as *zhen* receives *geng* from the west.” The *Wuzhen Pian* states: “When the moon is but a half-wheel bright at the edge of the sky, the dragon’s roar and tiger’s howl are already heard.” Ancestor Lü instructed Master Qianxu: “When snow mirrors the cold pool and the new moon hangs on the plum branch, only then may the medicine arise.” The Perfected One Qianxu’s *Ode to the Dao De Jing* states: “The young maiden first opens the northern flower; look up to see the *geng* moon, a slanted hook.” All these clarify the meaning of the *geng* month.

The *Wuzhen Pian* states: “On the fifteenth day of the eighth month, admire the toad’s radiance—precisely when the golden essence is at its peak.” Master Shi Xinglin says: “When the wind first stirs in myriad hollows and the moon suddenly rounds over a thousand mountains, swiftly issue the command to circulate the *zhou tian*.” Chen Cuixu says: “On a moonlit night, gazing within, one may gather and conjoin celestial soul and terrestrial soul to form the numinous elixir.” Zhang Sanfeng says: “The moon’s fullness depends on the oral instruction; the marvel of the midnight hour lies in heart transmission.” He also says: “When the moon is full, the jade bud blooms.” All these illustrate the meaning of the full moon.

What path should one take?

I answer: The two ancestors, Qianxu and Hanxu, have already clarified this. Qianxu’s *Preface to the Wuzhen Pian* states: “Someone asked, ‘You speak of the fifteenth day of the eighth month and also of the third day when *geng* emerges—what is the meaning?’ I replied, ‘The fifteenth symbolizes the sufficiency of the metal-water *qi*; the third symbolizes the freshness of the metal-water medicine. If *qi* is insufficient, water will not arise. When considered together, the meaning becomes clear.’”

Ancestor Hanxu says: “The newly appearing yang light is the evening of the third day. The fullness of metal-water is the night of the fifteenth. When alchemists speak of the third day and also of the fifteenth, the third symbolizes the freshness of the metal-water *qi*, while the fifteenth symbolizes its sufficiency. If *qi* is insufficient, water will not arise. The third and fifteenth must be regarded as one moment, envisioned as one continuous thread—one must not calculate by counting numbers.”

The oral instruction states: When the scholar’s practice reaches great samadhi, forgetting form and image, abiding in emptiness and stillness, then the primordial *qi* will arise abundantly, like the full moon—this is what is meant by “when the source is clear, the *qi* is surely sufficient.” Within samadhi, at the first awakening of yang, when it aligns with the natural rhythm and turns outward in dependence, without stirring a single thought, then the yang *qi* is pure and fresh, not old but tender, like the moon of the third day. Thus, the *geng* month and the full moon point to the flourishing of the medicine and the freshness of the sprout—their meaning is consistent, not contradictory.

When samadhi is sufficient, *qi* flourishes; when departure from the body is swift, the medicine is fresh. In this way, send it back to the earthen crucible and re-enter great samadhi. Then the *zhou tian* practice will be without error, the gathering and nurturing will be proper, and the verification of the returned elixir will be visible in days—is this not the essential key to restoration?

Master Qianxu’s *Preface to the Wuzhen Pian* states: “Someone asked, ‘Why is tender medicine usable?’ I replied, ‘In the *qi* of creation, what has accomplished its work retreats, and what is to come advances. It is like brewing wine: the three-day ferment, though floating and slight, can transform a thousand jars. At this time, the flavor may be faint, yet the vital impulse is vigorous. If it has already ripened into wine, it cannot be used again.’”

The harvesting of medicine takes the tender precisely for this reason." This is appended here for reference.

**105. The Toad and the Hare’s Spirit**
The *Cantong Qi* states:
*"On the third day, clarity emerges,
Zhen receives Geng from the west.
On the eighth, Dui receives Ding,
The first quarter hangs straight as a cord.
By the fifteenth, Qian’s body is complete,
Fullness abounds in Jia’s eastern realm.
The toad and the hare’s spirit,
Sun and moon’s *qi* shine as one.
The toad gazes at the hexagram’s node,
The hare spits forth radiant light."*

The *Cantong Qi* employs the two images of the toad and the hare’s spirit as most wondrous. Master Ziyang’s *Wuzhen Pian* follows this, saying:
*"On the fifteenth of the eighth month, admire the toad’s glow—
Precisely when metal’s essence is robust and flourishing."*
And again:
*"If you ask what true lead is,
The toad’s light shines all day upon the Western River."*

Master Xu Shenweng says:
*"Resplendent, the golden flower of sun and moon’s essence,
Flowing, the jade liquid of heaven and earth’s marrow.
Deep in the night, the sky’s expanse is free of dust,
Only the toad’s light illumines the divine water."*

An ancient worthy’s poem reads:
*"On the Western River’s bank, raise your gaze—
A tide of toad-light dips into emerald waves.
Now is the time to refine the two eights with care,
Diligently entrusting it to the Yellow Dame."*

All trace their origin to the *Cantong Qi*’s image of the toad.

Master Qianxu the Perfected’s *Ceshu* states:
*"Those who speak of the moon today use many names—
Some call it the toad, others the hare’s spirit.
Yet the toad and the hare’s spirit must be distinguished:
The toad is the moon’s essence, while the hare’s spirit is the moon’s body.
Now, the moon’s light is borrowed from the sun,
Thus the *qi* of sun and moon must face each other to generate brightness—
This is the natural principle of yin and yang’s gestation.
Yet yang arises gradually:
The toad’s birth depends on the hexagram’s node.
As yang beneath the hexagram grows, the toad’s essence gradually forms,
And only then does the hare spit it forth to generate light."*

Master Xuanjing says: The toad symbolizes the *qi* of primordial true yang. When the practitioner’s work reaches great samadhi, Qian and Kun naturally unite. Stillness gives rise to movement, and when true yang arrives, the toad’s light appears. Swiftly direct it outward with a single touch, maintaining unmoving mindfulness. Thus true yang will not escape, and you may send it back to the earthen crucible for secure sealing. The toad lurking at the water’s bottom symbolizes metal within water. The hare’s spirit, illuminated by the sun’s light, symbolizes the medicine’s production after the union of spirit and *qi*.

**106. Divine Water and the Flowery Pond**
Master Yuchan’s *Danfa Cantong* states:
*"The heart’s source, the ocean of nature, is called the Flowery Pond.
Nature is like water—it is called divine water."*

This is the supreme alchemy of the highest vehicle. Master Ziyang’s *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* says:
*"The Flowery Pond’s lotus blooms,
Divine water’s golden waves are still.
Deep in the night, the moon is bright—
Heaven and earth become a single mirror."*

These four lines offer vivid metaphors that resonate with Master Yuchan’s words.
*"The Flowery Pond’s lotus blooms"* describes the blossoming of the heart’s flower, the revelation of nature’s light. Master Yuxi says:
*"Split open the Great Ultimate’s bud,
Revealing the heart of heaven and earth.
The void’s expanse knows no bounds—
A sliver of moon appears above the solitary peak."*
This is the meaning of the flower’s bloom.

*"Divine water’s golden waves are still"* describes the ocean of nature’s waves calmed, the winds of circumstance stilled, the waves of consciousness unarisen—profoundly settled and at rest.

*"Deep in the night, the moon is bright"* and the following line illustrate the principle of pure clarity and luminous reflection, where all phenomena merge in emptiness. *Zhuangzi* says: *"When the great vessel is settled, radiance issues from celestial light."* The *Great Cavern Scripture* states:
*"When numinous light enters brilliance, the ten thousand spirits arise together."*
And again:
*"The black pearl reveals its true form,
Within and without, all is luminously clear."*
And:
*"The source’s purity shines with light,
Its cultivation bears fruit.
In quiescence and wondrous awareness,
Mysterious breath naturally grants long life."*
This is its meaning.

Some take the mouth as the Flowery Pond and saliva as divine water—this is the alchemy of the lower grade. Others take the union of *qi* and spirit as the Flowery Pond and the entry of spirit into *qi* as divine water—this is the alchemy of the middle grade. But Master Yuchan’s teaching transcends form, body, spirit, and *qi*, thus belonging to the most supreme vehicle. Nature and heaven unfold in clarity, perfectly round and purely wondrous, utterly beyond the reach of thought—deeply accordant with the ancient sages’ principle of *"the constant virtue knows no deviation."*

**107. Heaven’s Root and the Moon’s Grotto**
The Song Confucian Shao Yaofu’s poem reads:
*"Eyes and ears keen, a man’s body—
The great potter’s gift is no poverty.
Only by exploring the moon’s grotto do you know things,
Without gathering heaven’s root, how can you know man?
When Qian meets Xun, observe the moon’s grotto;
When earth meets thunder, see heaven’s root.
Roaming between heaven’s root and the moon’s grotto,
All thirty-six palaces are spring."*

This poem, *"Chant on Observing Things,"* subtly contains the alchemical transformations of the Daoist school. For the alternation of firing times does not depart from movement and stillness. Within movement there is stillness, within stillness there is movement. When movement and stillness unite, quiescence and responsiveness never part—only then is its wonder fully realized.

Thus Kun is earth, stillness. Zhen is thunder, movement. When earth meets thunder, it forms the hexagram *Fu*—this is called *Heaven’s Root*, precisely the moment of utter emptiness and profound stillness when one yang returns. That primordial *qi* emerges from the formless, and when the time arrives, the spirit knows. The *"knower of man"* refers to the pure yang’s master, the *qi* of primordial true *yi*.

Qian is heaven. When Qian meets Xun, it forms the hexagram *Gou*—this is called *the Moon’s Grotto*, precisely the time of gentle fire after obtaining the medicine and returning it to the crucible for nurturing. Yang has stirred, yin has stilled—then gather and withdraw it. *Heaven’s Root* reveals the mechanism of generation, while *the Moon’s Grotto* signifies the intent of retreat and concealment.

Understanding the meaning of *Heaven’s Root* and *the Moon’s Grotto*, one’s gathering, nurturing, bathing, sealing, and securing will all align with the proper measure. As *The Awakening to Reality* states: *"Once Fu and Gou are mastered in application, who can say the golden elixir will not succeed?"* Generally, the marvel of creation lies in the reversal of yin and yang—*Heaven’s Root* initiates at the fore, while *the Moon’s Grotto* observes completion thereafter. This is what is meant by *"what continues it is goodness; what completes it is nature."* *"Thirty-six palaces all abloom with spring"* precisely illustrates the fire-timing without error, the harmony of yin and yang, where every corner of the heart brims with spring. *The Mirror of Entering the Medicine* says: *"Primordial qi, postnatal qi—who attains it remains ever as if intoxicated."*

---

**Returning to Life and Returning to Nature**

The ancient sage said: *"Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called returning to life; returning to life is called constancy; knowing constancy is called clarity."* Zhuangzi said: *"Use the heart to return to the heart."* Returning the heart is returning to nature. This teaching of returning to life and returning to nature is the profound subtlety of the Daoist school’s cultivation of nature and reversal of virtue, the wondrous path of thorough realization of the true and constant.

The study of returning to life requires returning the self to emptiness and quiescence, for only emptiness can respond. The practitioner, through the interdependence of heart and breath, directly enters the state of great samadhi. When samadhi endures and stillness prevails, this is called returning to the root. Returning to the root means moving from activity back to stillness. When stillness reaches its extreme, it reverts to movement—primordial *qi* responds to resonance, and I respond to it with movement. Externally, heart and breath interdepend; spirit and *qi* unite as one, abiding in samadhi without reckless dispersion. This is *"seeking the mysterious in the water palace, stirring the wind of Xun to move the fire of Kun."* Then, through the interdependence of heart and breath, gradually shift from martial fire to civil fire. When spirit and breath both forget, one enters great samadhi again. Thus, the prior and posterior heavens each find their place; inner and outer harmonize; body and mind become serene and joyful. The true *yi*’s *qi* obtained is then sent to the earthen crucible for secure sealing—only then may one conclude a single cycle of practice.

Therefore, the study of returning to life must undergo three reversals: from movement to stillness, from extreme stillness back to movement, and from movement again to stillness. Master Wang once told me: *"One samadhi before yang arises, one samadhi after yang arises. The former samadhi awaits the birth of the medicine and the resonance of true yang; the latter samadhi serves for bathing, nurturing, sealing, and secure concealment."* The *Classic of the Unseen Correspondence*’s *"three reversals day and night"* likely refers to this stage of work. This is the esoteric mystery of the Daoist school’s return to life, which must pass through *"three reversals"* to accomplish the task.

Returning to nature is the Daoist school’s principle of *"dawn’s clarity revealing the solitary."* As Master Ziyang said: *"There is nothing that is not my heart; there is nothing that is my self."* He also said: *"Shatter the empty void to see the whole body."* Li Daochun said: *"Shatter the empty void to attain great awakening."* And again: *"Lift it clearly to reveal the whole body, then must break through the pivot of primordial unity."* Master Sanfeng said: *"Round and luminous, this one point no thousand sages have transmitted."* Master Miaozheng said: *"The great radiant mirror shines brilliantly; all things and I are reflected within. The wondrous body ever abides in stillness, its light illuminating the six gates."* In such vast clarity of spirit, essence and function are thusness itself. Transcending this upward path, one attains what is called *"great rest"* and *"great freedom."* Abiding in the ever-quiescent light, one may walk arm in arm with all buddhas and tathagatas—this may be called the full fruition of bodhi.

---

**Action and Non-Action**

Master Ziyang’s *Awakening to Reality* states: *"At first, those who act are rarely seen; only when non-action is reached do the multitudes recognize it. Yet seeing non-action as essential, who knows that action is the foundation?"* Here, action and non-action are presented together. Master Qianxu’s *Profound Insight into the Dao De Jing* says: *"All action is illusion; non-action is also illusion, yet not a trivial one. Dismissing both action and non-action still leaves illusion—only when clouds disperse does the moon shine clear in the empty sky."* How, then, to reconcile them?

It is said: When heart and breath interdepend within external emptiness, one neither clings to action nor falls into void. It is both action and non-action, neither action nor non-action—only then does one accord with the Dao’s wonder and manifest its wondrous function. Thus, Master Qianxu also composed a verse: *"Originally there was neither being nor non-being; do not vainly seek non-being in the great void. Recognize the true wondrous function of spontaneity—ten thousand rivers’ bright moons are but a single solitary wheel."* Reading this verse, one knows the Daoist school’s purport lies elsewhere.

Someone may ask: *"The *Diamond Sutra* says: ‘All conditioned things are like dreams, illusions, bubbles, shadows.’ Does not the Daoist practice of refining essence, refining *qi*, refining spirit fall into action? If it is action, it remains but a dream. If it is non-action, why speak of refining?"*

The answer: *"You know only action and non-action, but not acting without attachment. Acting without attachment means moving all day yet never having moved—what concern is there for action? The *Diamond Sutra* is no different: it speaks of emptiness throughout, without clinging to form, yet does not fall into annihilation. The sutra’s saying ‘give rise to the heart without abiding anywhere’—is this not the meaning of spirit and *qi* uniting in emptiness? Again, in the ‘Sequence’ chapter, it describes ‘putting on robes, holding the alms bowl, going and returning for alms, washing the feet, arranging the seat.’ Upon seeing this, Subhuti praises: ‘Rare, World-Honored One!’ Now, what is the purport of the ‘Sequence’ chapter, and whence comes Subhuti’s praise? If you do not fault the World-Honored One for putting on robes, holding the alms bowl, washing feet, and arranging the seat, why fault the Daoist for refining essence, refining *qi*, refining spirit? The ancient immortals said: ‘The elixir is refined within non-refinement; the Dao is practiced within non-practice.’"*

"‘Act without acting, and nothing is left undone; nothing is left undone, yet there is no acting—only then does one accord with the wondrous Dao.’ Master Sengzhao said: ‘Because of non-action, though in motion, one remains ever quiescent; because nothing is left undone, though quiescent, one remains ever in motion—thus things cannot be reduced to oneness. Though in motion, one remains ever quiescent—thus things cannot be divided into twoness, and the more one moves, the more quiescent one becomes.’ Things cannot be reduced to oneness, and the more quiescent one becomes, the more one moves—this is how acting is non-acting. Though motion and quiescence differ, there is no distinction to be made between them. How can one say that to have acting is to have acting, and to have non-acting is to have non-acting? The bodhisattva abides in the dharma-gate of equality between exhaustion and non-exhaustion, neither exhausting conditioned action nor abiding in non-action—this is the meaning. One may contemplate it thus."

Someone asked: "Then how are dream, illusion, bubble, and shadow to be dissolved?"
The reply: "Who knows dream, illusion, bubble, and shadow? Who speaks of dream, illusion, bubble, and shadow? Does the one who knows dream, illusion, bubble, and shadow still become dream, illusion, bubble, and shadow?"
Hmm! ○ ○ ○
Attaining quiescence and attaining harmony.

The *Datong Sutra* states: "Attaining quiescence, one does not move; attaining harmony, one does not shift." Master Hanxu’s *Concise Explication* says: "Quiescence without movement is samādhi; harmony without shifting is peace." As for the profound teaching, only when the heart and breath harmonize and merge do the body and mind attain dual quiescence, becoming utterly still. The more quiescent the body and mind, the more harmonious the qi, until external breath ceases entirely, and one abides in great samādhi. Within samādhi, the prior and posterior heavens naturally unite, entering true quiescence. Only then does "supreme harmony overflow, and bones scatter like cold jade."

The Old Sage said: "Quiescence is lord over restlessness," and "Though there be glory to behold, one dwells in serenity, transcendent." He also said: "To know harmony is to know constancy." Quiescence and harmony—these are the great principles of the profound teaching, the model for sagely cultivation.

---

The *Zhuangzi*’s "Great Master" chapter states: "The Dao has sentiment and trustworthiness, yet is without action or form. It may be transmitted but not received, attained yet not seen." The Old Sage said: "Dark and obscure, within it there is essence; its essence is most true, within it there is trustworthiness."

The Buddhist explanation: The Dao is true emptiness. True emptiness is not empty, thus it manifests wondrous being. Sentiment and trustworthiness are the signs of wondrous being. What is sentiment? It is movement arising from extreme quiescence, resonance through response—what is called "the return of the yang." When the prior-heaven qi arrives, the time comes and the spirit knows. The arrival of qi is the living *zi* hour; the knowing of the spirit is the living *wu* hour. Metal returns to essence—this response to that stimulus accords with the natural tally. Departing from the physical body, when the heart and breath depend on each other externally, the work of gathering is achieved.

Master Qianxu’s *Supplementary Ink to the Southern Florescence Sutra* says: "There is a thing formed in chaos, born before heaven and earth. The sage, compelled, names it the Dao. It is without form, without action—yet why does it have sentiment and trustworthiness? Laozi said: 'Vague and indistinct, within it there is something; dim and obscure, within it there is essence; its essence is most true, within it there is trustworthiness.' These few lines are the secret treasury of discourse on the Dao through the ages. Zhuangzi’s learning derives from Laozi, and he directly speaks of sentiment and trustworthiness. What are sentiment and trustworthiness? They are spoken from the perspective of observing its subtleties through desire. Essence is the movement of quiescence; trustworthiness is the tally of movement. The word 'trustworthiness' is especially secret. A thousand sages and ten thousand perfected ones share this single key. Only with a teacher’s transmission can one realize it. Thus it is said to be transmissible, yet not receivable—meaning it cannot be seen."

In my view, what Laozi calls "essence" is what Zhuangzi calls "sentiment." The *Awakening to Reality* says: "In vagueness they meet, in obscurity there is transformation; in a flash, a flame flies, and the true person naturally appears." The *Essentials of the Profound* says: "Seek the true seed where lightning flashes (this is essence, sentiment); when the tally of the wind arrives (this is the sign of trustworthiness), find the original source." These few lines suffice.

---

The purport of prior-heaven and posterior-heaven is explained in two layers.

First, as mutual opposition. For example, the emptiness outside the body is prior-heaven, while all within the physical body is posterior-heaven. Again, original essence and original qi are formless substances, called prior-heaven; the essence of intercourse and the qi of respiration, having fallen into form, are called posterior-heaven. Thus, through mutual opposition, the purport of prior and posterior heaven is elucidated.

Second, as progressive depth, the unfolding of practice. For instance, if harmonizing heart and breath is prior-heaven, then the usual state without practice is posterior-heaven. From harmonizing heart and breath, one enters vagueness and obscurity—then vagueness and obscurity become prior-heaven, while harmonizing heart and breath becomes posterior-heaven. Advancing further from vagueness and obscurity to great samādhi, where breath has no exhalation or inhalation, the heart no arising or ceasing, inner and outer are forgotten, and roots and dust are extinguished—then great samādhi becomes prior-heaven, while vagueness and obscurity become posterior-heaven. From great samādhi, one reaches complete emptiness and non-arising, emptying not only body, mind, roots, and dust, but even the form of samādhi itself. Space is pulverized, and the measure of the dharma-realm vanishes—then the pulverization of space becomes prior-heaven, while great samādhi becomes posterior-heaven. With each advance, it is like ascending a nine-tiered terrace. Progressing from lower to higher learning depends entirely on the practitioner’s effort in cultivation.

---

Master Zhang Sanfeng said: "Before encountering a true person, the scholar should be cautious and humble, accumulating merit and virtue. Do not retreat when facing demons, do not resent when slandered.
