Caoshan said: "Those who study the Dao are like cats or white oxen—when hungry, they eat grass; when thirsty, they drink water, never worrying that the Dao will not be attained." This aligns perfectly with the meaning of "eyes bright as a newborn calf, seeking nothing from the past." Thus, to cultivate the Dao, one should emulate the undifferentiated state, like an infant who has not yet learned to smile—only then can one return to authenticity and recover simplicity.

---

172   Guan Yin Discusses the Dao (Part One)
From the *Liezi*’s “The Yellow Emperor”:
Liezi asked Guan Yin, “The perfected person walks underwater without obstruction, treads on fire without burning, moves above the myriad things without fear. May I ask how one attains this?”

Guan Yin replied, “This is the preservation of pure qi—it does not belong to the realm of cunning, skill, or boldness.”

Child! The fish speaks to you. All that possesses form, appearance, sound, or color belongs to the realm of things. How can things distance themselves from one another? What suffices to reach the primordial? It is merely form. Thus, things arise from the formless and rest where transformation ceases. Those who attain this and exhaust its depths—how could they be led astray? They dwell in measureless depth, conceal themselves in traceless order, and roam through the beginning and end of the myriad things. They unify their nature, nurture their qi, and embrace their virtue, thereby penetrating to the source of all things. Those who do so preserve their Heavenly endowment whole, their spirit without flaw—how could external things intrude?

Consider the drunkard who falls from a cart: though the fall is swift, he does not die. His bones and joints are the same as others’, yet the harm he suffers differs—his spirit remains whole. He rides unaware, falls unaware; neither life nor death, neither terror nor dread, enters his breast. Thus, he encounters things without fear. If one preserved by wine can be thus, how much more so one preserved by Heaven? The sage conceals himself in Heaven, and so nothing can harm him.

This wondrous passage, also recorded in the *Zhuangzi*, belongs to the Daoist art of preserving life. "Preservation of pure qi" and "unifying one’s nature, nurturing one’s qi" describe the practice of heart and breath interdependent, gathering the treasures of Heaven. "Concealing oneself in traceless order" points to the technique of transcending the body into emptiness, concentrating the spirit in the void while emptying body and mind. "Roaming through the beginning and end of the myriad things" means returning to true emptiness, merging with the primordial before form.

All "form, appearance, sound, and color" pertain to the postnatal bodily form. If one clings to the bodily form in seeking the Dao, how can one transcend form and reach the primordial, where Heaven does not oppose? Only by concentrating the spirit in the emptiness beyond the body and regulating the breath can one return to the primordial state and merge with the Great Unity.

Below, the text further expounds the essence of preserving the spirit: when the spirit is whole, the body is whole; cold and heat cannot invade, nor can life and death, sorrow and peril, enter. This is why nurturing the spirit is the key to nurturing life. "The sage conceals himself in Heaven" means that one’s small Heaven-and-Earth (heart and breath) hibernates within the great Heaven-and-Earth (the emptiness beyond the body). In such a state, one merges with Heaven-and-Earth as one, blending into the formless. Thus, one shares the same body with emptiness and the same function with Heaven-and-Earth; bodily form and Dharma-body are nondual, movement and stillness, opening and closing, all proceeding with the great transformation. As the *Zhuangzi* says, "The Dao flows through as one." Hence it is said: "Only the enlightened know that all is one." To be "through" is to attain; to attain is to approach the subtle.

Shi Jianwu said: "Heaven and man share the same qi; they respond and commune. Yang comes from emptiness, embracing me, the master." Zhang Ziqiong said: "Heaven and man share the same qi from the beginning; only the bodily form obstructs their communion. When refinement reaches the point where form and spirit merge, one knows that form is none other than true emptiness." Man conceals himself in Heaven, and so Heaven and man act in unison, establishing the foundation of the myriad transformations—this is called "Heavenly roaming."

As for the practice, it is simply concentrating the spirit in emptiness, interweaving heart and breath, and attaining great stillness. The *Cantong Qi* says: "The true person dives into the deep abyss, floating and roaming within the compass." And: "The origin is hidden in brightness; the bodily form is concealed within." Confucian Yang Xiong’s *Tai Xuan Jing* likewise states: "Conceal the heart in the abyss; beauty lies in returning to the root." Both draw from this teaching, revealing the secret of concentrating the spirit and regulating the breath beneath the pillar.

---

173   Guan Yin Discusses the Dao (Part Two)
From the *Liezi*’s “Confucius”:
Guan Yin said: “Within oneself, take no abode; let things manifest their forms. Still as a mirror, responsive as an echo—thus the Dao resembles things. Things depart from the Dao; the Dao does not depart from things. Those who are good at the Dao neither use the ears, nor the eyes, nor strength, nor the heart. To seek the Dao through seeing, hearing, form, or intellect is misguided. It may appear before you, then suddenly behind; employed, it fills the six directions; discarded, none know its whereabouts. Neither those with intent nor those without can grasp it—far or near. Only those who silently attain it and let their nature perfect it can obtain it.

To know and forget emotion, to be capable yet not act—this is true knowledge, true ability. How can one have emotion if one emanates non-knowing? How can one act if one emanates non-ability? A clod of earth, a pile of dust—though they do nothing, they are not without principle.”

This wondrous discourse by Guan Yin perfectly embodies the Dao, circling within its center, illuminating past and future. It is the supreme teaching of the Mysterious School, the subtle Dao of the pillar’s simplicity and constancy. "Within oneself, take no abode" deeply accords with the *Diamond Sutra*’s "abide nowhere while giving rise to the heart." "Let things manifest their forms" means clarity shines in every instance, revelation appears in every thing—what the Perfected Purple Yang called "not a single thing is not my heart."

"Still as a mirror" describes stillness that illuminates, ever illuminating without cease. As the *Zhuangzi* says: "The mind of the perfected person is like a mirror: it neither advances nor retreats, responds without storing, and thus masters things without harm." The mirror’s function is to reflect things without emotion: it responds to what comes and does not retain what goes. Thus, it illustrates the marvel of the perfected person’s mindless response to things.

"Their movement is like water"—universally nourishing yet without intent. Though water moves, its moist nature remains unchanged, revealing the secret of the perfected person’s unchanging response to conditions.

Their response is like an echo—revealing how each knock elicits an immediate answer: a great sound yields a great response, a small sound a small response, and equal sounds equal responses. Without fail, it answers every strike, illustrating the marvel of universal response without intent.

"That their Dao is like things" shows how it accords with each capacity, neither lacking nor exceeding—whether in principle or in practice, nothing is not perfectly fulfilled.

"Silently one attains it" expresses the wonder of mind-to-mind transmission, as when one drinks water and knows its warmth or coolness for oneself.

"Those whose nature is perfected attain it" means that the inherent perfection of heart-nature is realized through direct realization, not through contrivance.

"Emerging without knowledge" aligns with the *Prajñāpāramitā Sūtra*’s teaching of "non-knowledge."

"Knowing yet forgetting emotion" perfectly captures the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*’s sublime principle of "knowing without seeing."

Nirvāṇa’s untainted true purity—Guan Yin must have personally realized it.

Viewed alongside the preceding section’s teachings on nurturing qi and concealing spirit, the heart-transmission of the Master of the Pillars and the profound mysteries of the Daoist tradition are fully revealed.

---

174. Kàng Cāng’s Proof of the Dao
From the "Zhongni" chapter of the *Liezi*:

A minister from Chen paid a state visit to Lu and privately met with the Shusun clan. Shusun said, "There is a sage in our state."

The minister asked, "Is it not Kong Qiu?"

Shusun replied, "It is. How do you know he is a sage?"

Shusun said, "I once heard Yan Hui say: ‘Kong Qiu can set aside the mind and employ the body.’"

The minister from Chen said, "There is also a sage in our state—have you not heard of him?"

Shusun asked, "Who is this sage?"

The minister replied, "Among Lao Dan’s disciples is one named Kàng Cāng, who has attained Lao Dan’s Dao. He can see with his ears and hear with his eyes."

The Lord of Lu, hearing this, was greatly astonished and sent his highest minister with lavish gifts to summon him. Kàng Cāng accepted the invitation and arrived.

The Lord of Lu, speaking humbly, inquired of him. Kàng Cāng said, "Those who transmitted this were mistaken. I can see and hear without using ears and eyes, but I cannot reverse the functions of ears and eyes."

The Lord of Lu said, "This is even more extraordinary! What is the nature of this Dao? I earnestly wish to hear it."

Kàng Cāng said, "My body unites with the heart-mind, the heart-mind unites with qi, qi unites with spirit, and spirit unites with the Nothingness. When there is a presence with firm resolve or a sound with pure resonance—whether distant at the eight wilds’ edge or near within the space between brows and lashes—whatever comes to disturb me, I must know it. Yet I do not know whether this is perceived by my seven apertures and four limbs, or known by the heart, belly, and five viscera. It is simply self-knowing."

The Lord of Lu was greatly pleased. Another day, he told this to Confucius, who smiled but did not answer. (The two sages both resonated in that smile—subtle! Subtle!)

This chapter penetrates above and below, concise in words yet comprehensive in meaning, leaving nothing unencompassed, and strikes the mark with divine subtlety. The Song dynasty Chan master Yongming composed the *Zongjing lu*, which also cites this passage. In his explication of "self-knowing," he states that it is the wondrous accord of the One Heart, transmitted from sage to sage—only this Dao.

Xuánjìng remarked: The lines "the heart-mind unites with qi" and so forth point to the interdependence of heart-mind and breath, forgetting the form to cultivate qi, forgetting qi to cultivate spirit, and forgetting spirit to cultivate emptiness. These three barriers of practice encompass all without omission. Truly, this is the height of simplicity and subtlety. As for "seeing and hearing without using ears and eyes," it is evidence of the six senses returning to stillness and the merging of disparate natures into unity. The ancients said, "Seeing without eyes, hearing without ears"—this is the true realm of the Daoist adept. The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* states: "If you refrain from following the twelve conditioned states—movement and stillness, union and separation, tranquility and change, obstruction and passage, arising and ceasing, brightness and darkness—and uproot even one sense faculty, freeing it from entanglement and turning it inward to return to the original true, the radiance of its nature will shine forth. Once this luminosity is revealed, the remaining five senses will likewise be uprooted and fully liberated. Do you not know that in this assembly, Aniruddha sees without eyes; the dragon Bhadanta hears without ears; the goddess Gaṅgā perceives fragrance without a nose; the brahmin Gavāṃpati knows taste with a different tongue; the spirit Śunyatā senses touch without a body; and the śrāvaka attains quiescence. Here too, Mahākāśyapa, having long extinguished the root of thought, abides in perfect clarity, knowing without reliance on mental activity."

This confirms that in the cultivation of immortals and buddhas, the six senses are liberated, the dust of defilements dissolves, and awakening is perfected—there is no second Dao.

Alas! Had Laozi not taken the *Yi*’s imagery as his foundation but instead followed Fuxi, the Yellow Emperor, Lao Dan, Guan Yin, Kàng Cāng, Zhuangzi, and Liezi to compose the *Cantong qi*, it would surely have been even more remarkable.

---

175. The Old Fisherman’s Angling
From the *Zhuangzi*, "Tian Zifang" chapter:

King Wen observed at Zāng and saw an old man angling. Yet his angling was no angling—though he held a fishing rod, he did not angle as others do, for his was the angling of constancy. King Wen wished to raise him to office and entrust him with governance, but feared his great ministers and elders would not accept it. He wished to leave the matter and let it go, yet could not bear the thought of the people being without a ruler.

At dawn, King Wen summoned his ministers and said: “Last night, I dreamed of a worthy man—dark-complexioned and bearded. He rode a dappled horse with one red hoof and declared: ‘Entrust your governance to the Old Fisherman of Zāng; perhaps then the people may find relief.’” The ministers, startled, exclaimed: “This was our late lord, the former king!” King Wen said: “Then let us divine his will.” The ministers replied: “The command of the former king admits no alternative—what need is there for divination?” Thereupon they welcomed the Old Fisherman of Zāng and entrusted him with governance. No statutes were altered, no decrees were issued. After three years, King Wen surveyed the realm and found: the ranks of scholars had disbanded, their factions dissolved; officials no longer cultivated virtue; measuring vessels dared not cross the four borders; and the feudal lords harbored no disloyalty. Thereupon King Wen appointed him Grand Preceptor, faced north, and inquired: “Can such governance extend to all under Heaven?” The Old Fisherman, silent and unmoved, declined with vague words. By nightfall, he had fled, vanishing without trace.

Xuanjing observes: The Old Fisherman of Zāng was none other than Grand Duke Wang, a man of the Dao. He feigned angling as a guise: one hand held the rod, the other watched the floating bob, his spirit gathered in emptiness, heart and breath interdependent. In a trance of indistinct reverie, he angled for something beyond the hook. Thus, though his hand grasped the rod, the rod never stirred. Angling yet not angling, not angling yet angling—how sublime! The ancients cultivated their work in every moment and place. As the Boat Monk said: *“A thousand feet of line cast deep—intent lies in the abyss. But tell me, what was the outcome?”* I cite the Boat Monk’s verse in witness:

*A thousand feet of silk line hangs straight down,
A single ripple stirs ten thousand more.
In still night’s chill, the fish do not bite—
The moonlit boat returns empty.*

When King Wen raised the Old Fisherman to governance, the man embodied the inner sageliness and outer kingliness of the Dao. Without action, the people transformed themselves; without rewards, they strove; without words, they trusted. His governance was resplendent, surpassing even King Wen’s reach. For he moved hearts purely through the Dao, without recourse to laws or decrees. Thus, when King Wen sought to appoint him Grand Preceptor, the old man drifted away like a wild goose into the boundless sky—what archer could aspire to such heights? Truly, he came and went without trace, a divine dragon whose head appears but tail remains unseen.

---

176. The Casting of Bells in the Northern Palace
From the *Zhuangzi*, "Mountains and Rivers" chapter:

For Duke Ling of Wei, Beigong She levied funds to cast bells. He erected an altar beyond the outer gate, and within three months, the upper and lower chimes were completed (all eight instruments assembled in suspension—so swift was their completion). Prince Qingji saw this and asked: “What method did you employ?” She replied: “In the space between (embracing unity alone), I dared not impose any method. I have heard: ‘Once carved and polished, return to simplicity.’ Unknowing and unassuming, drifting in doubt, I gathered in boundless vagueness. I sent off the departing and welcomed the arriving—arrivals were not barred, departures were not hindered.”

From their strength and vigor, following their curves and contours, yielding to their natural exhaustion—these three phrases describe the marvel of spontaneity. Thus, though levies were gathered morning and evening, not a hair was harmed; how much more so for those who tread the great thoroughfare!

The *Secret Explication* states: The *Zhuangzi* is nine-tenths parable, and this too is a parable. "Casting bells" is a metaphor for forming the embryo. "Levying funds" refers to gathering the primordial qi. "Completed in three months" signifies the hundred-day foundation of base-building. "Erecting an altar beyond the outer gate" clarifies that the empty space outside the body is the alchemical altar, the crucible and vessel positioned therein. From "in the space between" onward, it purely demonstrates the work. What is meant by "in the space between"? It is the principle of guarding the center and embracing unity, the practice of concentrating spirit and regulating breath. When heart and breath harmonize, the two realms converge, merging into one—this alone is the task. "Return to simplicity" means that, through prolonged stabilization of spirit and qi, thoughts and breath are both forgotten, returning to chaos. "Unknowing and unassuming, drifting in doubt, gathering in boundless vagueness" describes a state of utter oblivion, profound stillness. "Sending off the departing and welcoming the arriving" means the heart follows the breath: one breath departs, one breath arrives, heart and breath cling to each other. "Following, yielding, relying"—these three words exhaust the subtleties of breath regulation. Since ancient times, no one discussing breath regulation has surpassed this three-word secret. In a single phrase: simply follow nature. Gathering in the morning and levying in the evening, primordial yang accumulates daily, yet my body and heart remain unmoved, profoundly settled. Through stillness, one responds without sensing toil, so not a hair is harmed. The concluding lines are even more marvelous: "the great thoroughfare" refers to the divine continent of the Red Region, the empty space outside the body. Dwelling in the world’s great thoroughfare, treading the Dao with ease—what affair could remain unresolved? Mencius said: "Dwell in the world’s broadest abode, stand in the world’s correct position, walk the world’s great Way." This truly aligns with the marvelous principle of the great thoroughfare. Sima Ziwei said: "The empty void, a single aperture called the Mysterious Pass, lies between heaven and earth in the human body. Vastly encompassing the Dharma Realm without trace, subtly entering dust motes unseen." Luo Gongyuan said: "A single aperture of emptiness amid heaven and earth, entwined and secret, impervious to wind." All reveal the secret of "the great thoroughfare."

---

177. Confucius’ Admirable Retreat
From the *Zhuangzi*, "Mountain Trees" chapter:

Confucius was besieged between Chen and Cai, going seven days without cooked food. Taigong Ren came to offer condolences, saying: "Were you nearly dead?" Confucius replied: "Yes." "Do you detest death?" "Yes." Ren said: "Let me speak of the way of not dying. In the Eastern Sea there is a bird called the *yidai*. As a bird, it is leisurely and unhurried, appearing incapable. It flies only when aided and roosts only when pressed. Advancing, it dares not take the lead; retreating, it dares not lag behind. In eating, it dares not taste first but must take the remnants. Thus, it is never expelled from the flock, and outsiders never harm it, so it avoids disaster. The straightest trees are felled first; the sweetest wells are drained first. You, in your intent, adorn knowledge to startle the foolish, cultivate yourself to expose impurity, shining brightly as if carrying the sun and moon in your stride—how could you escape harm? Long ago, I heard from a man of great completion: 'Those who boast achieve no merit; those who complete merit fall; those who achieve fame suffer loss.' Who can relinquish merit and fame and return to the multitude? The Dao flows but does not dwell in brightness; virtue acts but does not reside in renown. Pure and constant, one resembles the mad. Erasing traces, relinquishing power, one does not pursue merit or fame. Thus, one bears no blame from others, and others bear none from them. The perfected person remains unknown—why do you delight in this?" Confucius said: "Excellent!" He parted from his associates, left his disciples, and fled to the great marshes. Clad in furs and coarse cloth, eating acorns and chestnuts, he entered the beasts’ midst without disrupting their herds, entered the birds’ midst without disturbing their flocks. Birds and beasts did not detest him—how much less would humans!

The *Explication* states: This passage uses Confucius to expound a lesson, urging those who cultivate the Dao to relinquish thoughts of merit and profit, blend with the world, avoid standing out to alarm others, and refrain from seeking fame to exalt themselves. Serene and detached, indifferent and remote—only thus can one preserve the body and avoid harm. Yang Yinxiou said: "Zhuangzi’s 'pure and constant' is Laozi’s 'simple and dull'—Zhuangzi inherited Laozi’s teachings, forming a distinct school." Gui Zhenchuan said: "Riding the Dao to wander through the world, appearing wise or foolish, one must shed burdens and empty oneself, embrace simplicity and adaptability, relinquish merit and fame, abandon social circles, accept poverty and follow one’s lot, neither chasing things nor priding oneself—this is the way to preserve the body and avoid harm." Lu Fanghu said: "The Dao flows without dwelling in brightness—from ancient times to the present, day and night pass like this, silently operating without ever declaring itself as Dao. This is the Dao’s marvel. Those who embody the Dao, dwelling in attainment without attachment, approach it. 'Attainment' means achieving one’s will. 'Residing in renown' refers to self-display and self-boasting. 'Pure' means singular; 'constant' means ordinary. To unify the heart and make conduct ordinary is to resemble the recklessly mad. Thus, it is said: 'one resembles the mad.' Erasing traces means shutting the door and sweeping away tracks, leaving no wheel ruts behind."

To relinquish power means neither serving kings and lords nor engaging in persuasive speech. Thus, one does not establish merit for the world or fame for all ages, nor does one seek perfection from others—therefore, others cannot demand perfection in virtue from them. Such conduct, seeking neither recognition nor prominence, belongs to those who leave no trace. I observe that practitioners of the Dao are often slandered by the vulgar, half of which stems from self-display. Scholars must therefore discard ornamentation and embrace plainness, merging indistinguishably with the great unity. They should act in hidden subtlety, leaving no trace, seeking only self-knowledge rather than worldly renown—only then can they transcend free of encumbrance. This point is of utmost importance, hence its inclusion here. If one can depart from the dust of the world, retreat into the great marshes or beneath cliffs and ravines, dwelling in thatched huts or stone chambers in tranquil seclusion, utterly cut off from the world, it would be even better.

---

**178. Yanzi’s Sitting-in-Forgetfulness**
From *Zhuangzi·The Great Master*:
Yan Hui said, “I have made progress.”
Confucius asked, “What do you mean?”
He replied, “I have forgotten benevolence and righteousness.”
Confucius said, “Good, but not yet sufficient.”
Another day, they met again, and Yan Hui said, “I have made progress.”
Confucius asked, “What do you mean?”
He replied, “I have forgotten ritual and music.”
Confucius said, “Good, but not yet sufficient.”
Another day, they met again, and Yan Hui said, “I have made progress.”
Confucius asked, “What do you mean?”
He replied, “I sit in forgetfulness.”
Confucius started in surprise and asked, “What is sitting-in-forgetfulness?”
Yan Hui said, “I discard my limbs and body, dismiss my hearing and sight, leave behind form and knowledge, and merge with the Great Thoroughfare—this is called sitting-in-forgetfulness.”
Confucius said, “To merge is to have no preferences; to transform is to have no constancy. You are indeed worthy! I would follow after you.”
Here, I shall briefly elucidate its meaning.

Yan Hui’s sitting-in-forgetfulness is an effortless entry into samādhi. When samādhi endures, inner and outer become utterly forgotten—this is the most wondrous and profound state. "Leaving form" means the body is emptied; "dismissing knowledge" means the mind is emptied. When body and mind, inner and outer, are all empty, one’s hidden self leaves no trace, and the entire dharma-realm manifests. Thus it concludes with "merging with the Great Thoroughfare"—this is precisely the moment of realizing the equality of dharmatā.

Lu Pingquan said, “Sitting-in-forgetfulness is the Chan school’s ‘facing the wall.’” Sima Ziwei said, “Sitting-in-forgetfulness is the foundation of long life. Thus, one summons the true to refine the form, and when the form is purified, it unites with qi. One embraces the Dao to refine qi, and when qi is purified, it unites with spirit. When the body and the Dao become one, this is called attaining the Dao. The true is the dwelling place of the Dao. Therefore, one calms the spirit to align with the true.”

Zhuangzi said, *“When the universe is at peace and settled, it emits celestial radiance.”* The “universe” is the mind; “celestial radiance” is the illumination of wisdom. When the mind is first settled, wisdom shines forth from within, illuminating the emptiness of all phenomena. The mind then merges with stillness—this is called sitting-in-forgetfulness.

I say that in the profound tradition of sitting-in-forgetfulness, the subtlety lies in the dual settling of mind and breath. From settling, one forgets; spirit and qi return to their root, and the embryo of the Dao takes form. Within this lies boundless celestial mechanism. As Cao Wenyu said, *“Merge into one and then forget the one—thus may one emerge and submerge with the primordial transformation.”* If one merely practices withered Chan, it is no different from sitting while distracted—this is not sitting-in-forgetfulness.

**Liezi Riding the Wind**
In the *Zhuangzi*’s “Free and Easy Wandering” chapter, it says, *“Liezi rode the wind and traveled, soaring lightly and gracefully. After fifteen days, he returned. Among those who attain good fortune, he was not one to strive anxiously.”* The *Liezi*’s “Yellow Emperor” chapter also states, *“Liezi studied under Master Lao Shang and befriended Bo Gaozi. Having transmitted the Way of these two masters, he rode the wind and returned.”*

Xuanjing said: In my view, this is merely figurative speech.

The in-and-out breath of us humans is none other than the *wind element*; with spirit guiding qi, heart and breath interpenetrate—proceeding thus to the state of *great samādhi* is the true practice of "riding the wind." Liezi further states: *"When the heart congeals and form dissolves, bones and flesh wholly fuse. One no longer senses where the body leans or where the feet tread, drifting east and west with the wind like a withered leaf or husk, utterly unaware whether the wind bears me or I ride the wind!"* This is the merging of heart and breath into oneness, where one no longer knows whether spirit depends on breath or breath on spirit. As spirit and breath fuse, they enter together into the realm of *huanghu* and *yaoming*, the state of *xiyi* and *great samādhi*—this is the esoteric purport of Zhuangzi’s *Free and Easy Wandering* and the true essence of Liezi’s "riding the wind." The "fifteen days" symbolize the first half-month up to the full moon as the phase for *advancing the fire*, requiring the *xun* wind to stir it. After fifteen days, the yang tide naturally recedes, so one must *retreat the talisman* to correspond with it. Master Cuixu said: *"When spirit and qi merge in darkness and qi returns, bones and flesh fuse in harmony—one knows it not."* Hence, "bones and flesh wholly fuse."

The perfected adept, possessing the *spiritual power of swiftness*, roams the ten directions—wherever the mind wills, there they arrive. What need have they for wind? Thus, the wind Liezi rides is none other than the *breath-wind*, the essential technique of guiding qi with spirit and the profound purport of the harmonious fusion of heart and breath.

**Changfang’s Earth-Shrinking**
The *Biographies of Divine Immortals* records that Fei Changfang possessed divine arts and could contract the earth’s veins, bringing a thousand *li* into immediate view as if before one’s eyes, then restoring them to their original expanse. This *earth-shrinking* method, if considered in light of the unobstructed spiritual powers of immortals and buddhas, allows one to compress thousands of *li* into a foot’s span or eons into a single instant—time and spatial measure may be extended or contracted at will, without hindrance. Such principles are entirely credible. As the heart is free, so too is the Dharma.

Delving into its esoteric meaning, it is truly the purport of heart and breath depending on each other, spirit and breath merging in secrecy. Through this mutual dependence, the in-and-out breath shortens from long, then from long to short, until it vanishes—is this not the image of *earth-shrinking*? Some may ask: If so, then is the earth’s vein equated with the in-and-out breath? What proof is there? The answer: Heart and breath are the yin and yang of the human person, the heaven and earth of the body. In the *Book of Changes*, they are *Qian* and *Kun*; in the human, they are body and mind. The heart is spirit; the body is qi. Thus, the image of *earth-shrinking* is the image of *revolving the breath to return to the origin*, the dissolution of breath into emptiness. When the heart unites with the breath, the breath’s extension and contraction also become free, expanding and contracting in perfect measure—this is the alternating use of *civil fire* and *martial fire*.

Zhou Jichang’s *Daoist Songs* states: *"Who knows the wondrous art of mending heaven? Who understands the marvel of shrinking earth?"* Master Yuchan’s *Breath-Regulation Formula* says: *"In regulating the breath’s fire-timing, there is the *gathering breath*. The heart must be able to empty and humble itself, then essence can enter the crucible—this is called the *earth-shrinking* method."* This may mutually verify the present explanation.

**Nüwa Mends Heaven**

*The Huainanzi* and *Records of the Grand Historian* both record that Nüwa smelted the Five-Colored Stones to mend the heavens’ breach. Nüwa was the younger sister of Fuxi and an ancient sovereign. Though the smelting of stones to mend the heavens never occurred in fact, the image remains. It embodies the alchemical secret of *drawing from Kan to fill Li*.

Heaven is the body of *Qian*, the pure Yang substance. Its sudden collapse and breach symbolize the middle line of *Qian* sinking into *Kan* and transforming into *Li*. The stone is the single Yang within *Kan*. When refined and used to mend *Li*, it restores the *Qian* hexagram. Thus, when *Qian* and *Kun* invert to become *Kan* and *Li*, metal sinks and wood floats. When *Kan* and *Li* invert to become *Qian* and *Kun*, the sunken metal rises, and the floating wood descends. The reverse application of the Five Phases hinges solely on this central inversion.

The alchemical method of *drawing from Kan to fill Li* originated with Nüwa. Without doubt, Nüwa’s elixir method was taught to her by her brother Fuxi. In activity, it is Fuxi; in stillness, it is Nüwa—are they not the primal ancestors of the Mysterious Tradition? The origins of Daoist learning are profoundly ancient, as this may attest.

Nüwa’s smelting of stones to mend the heavens and Zhuangzi’s *roc bird soaring southward* both embody the image of *drawing from Kan to fill Li* to restore the *Qian* body. In terms of practice, it does not extend beyond the mutual dependence of heart and breath.

---

**Shu Ao Regulates the Breath**
In *Zhuangzi·Tian Zifang*, Jian Wu asked Sunshu Ao: “You have thrice served as Prime Minister without pride, and thrice been dismissed without sorrow. At first, I doubted you, but now I see your nostrils breathing freely—how do you cultivate your heart-mind?”

Sunshu Ao replied: “How do I surpass others? I accept what comes without refusal and do not cling to what departs. I regard gain and loss as no concern of mine, and so remain free of sorrow. How do I surpass others?”

Sunshu Ao had mastered the gateway to regulating the breath, concentrating the spirit, and abiding in joy—attaining the samādhi of self-enjoyment. Thus, the rise and fall of office left no trace in his heart; truly, he was free and untrammeled. The phrase *xuxu* describes the breath as fine and subtle, drifting leisurely like a butterfly circling among flowers—its movement so delicate. The description is most apt. At first, Jian Wu could not fathom how Sunshu Ao remained so unmoved by wealth and honor, but upon observing the harmonious tranquility of his nasal breath, he suddenly understood. How remarkable a figure Jian Wu was as well!

**Hugong Conceals His Body**
Both *The Biographies of Divine Transcendents* and *The Book of Later Han·Biographies of Masters of Esoteric Arts* record that Hugong sold medicines, hanging a gourd at his stall. After the sun set, he would leap into the gourd, where none could see him—save for the market inspector Fei Changfang, who witnessed this from an upper story and rejoiced. Fei then went to pay homage, personally sweeping the ground before Hugong’s seat and preparing food and offerings. Hugong accepted these without refusal.

Thus, over time, Changfang remained unwavering in his devotion, never daring to make any requests (beholding the sincerity of ancients in seeking a master, truly worthy of emulation). Hugong, recognizing Changfang’s steadfast faith, said to him, “Come again at dusk when no one is about.” Changfang followed his instruction and returned, whereupon they leapt together into the gourd. Once inside, he no longer perceived it as a mere gourd but beheld instead a world of immortals’ palaces—towers and layered gates, covered walkways and halls, fine wine and delicacies filling the space. They drank together, then emerged.

Later, when Hugong prepared to depart, Changfang followed him into the mountains to study the Dao. This episode is most wondrous, revealing its meaning both openly and subtly. The gourd symbolizes the mysterious aperture of the *xuanguan*, the very essence of “guarding the center”—a realm of emptiness beyond the body. Leaping into it with one’s form is to concentrate the spirit in the void. Retreating and concealing oneself within the gourd, spirit and breath intermingle, gradually harmonizing, gradually settling, until the physical form dissolves, and the primordial *yuan-yang* true *qi* of pre-heaven permeates and nourishes the body, suffusing it with a soft, blissful ease, as if intoxicated by the warmth of spring—an ineffable delight. This is the profound significance of the gourd containing another heaven.

*The Mirror of Entering the Medicine* states:
*“The pre-heavenly qi, the post-heavenly breath—*
*Those who attain it ever seem drunk.”*
This is the meaning of their shared intoxication and satiety.

Thus, Master Sanfeng said:
*“Who knows the vastness of heaven and earth in stillness?*
*I love the long days and months within the gourd.”*
And again:
*“Knowing only the realm of heaven and earth within the gourd,*
*Who recalls the passing years of the human world?”*
And:
*“A single night of diligent refinement below—*
*Within the gourd, a thousand years of days and months.”*

Lü Zu said:
*“Wind and clouds of the grotto return to my grasp,*
*The days and months of the gourd rest in my breast.”*
And:
*“The world’s cycles of sixty years cannot bind,*
*Within the gourd, heaven and earth are free.”*
And:
*“Beyond the world, mist and rosy clouds are my companions;*
*Within the gourd, sun and moon are ever fair.”*
And:
*“Qi returns, the elixir forms of itself,*
*Within the gourd, Kan and Li unite.”*

Longmei Zi said:
*“Endless transformations of life and creation—*
*All manifest as a grotto-heaven within the gourd.”*

Chen Cuixu said:
*“Within, there is a true gourd-heaven,*
*Where wind and light are bright, the moon pure.”*
And:
*“Though the seas may turn to mulberry fields,*
*Within my Dao, not a year has passed in the gourd.”*

Bai Yuchan said:
*“The heart enters emptiness, practicing the fire times;*
*Inner and outer scenes—heaven within the gourd.”*
And:
*“Beyond the body, seek within the body;*
*Harmonious, vital qi—a spring within the gourd.”*
And:
*“A carefree, idle man,*
*His hut holds a gourd of spring.”*

Tang Guangzhen said:
*“When the day comes that the elixir is formed,*
*Drunk within the gourd, no need for support.”*

Cangming Zi said:
*“Within the gourd, every scene is present,*
*Yin and yang rise and fall by their own measure.”*

All these describe the inner vision of withdrawing into the gourd, harmonizing the breath, merging spirit and *qi*, the true *qi* flowing like clouds, wearing flowers and drinking wine—carefree and at ease. The profound principle of the gourd-heaven is most wondrous. To resolve the question of human existence and transcend the sufferings of birth, aging, sickness, and death, nothing but this gourd-heaven will suffice. Qiu Zu’s Daoist name, Changchun (“Ever-Spring”), deeply grasped the secret of the gourd-heaven.

Master Gui’an of Yu’an said:
*“Entering through the gate, one finds not the family treasure;*
*Beyond, there is the gourd’s heaven and earth of spring.”*
Even Chan Buddhism praises the gourd-heaven. Yet in recent times, Chan monasteries cling to withered Chan, cold ashes and dead wood, utterly devoid of vitality—clearly not the true intent of the Western Patriarch.

**184. The Queen Mother Cultivates Peaches**
*The Comprehensive Mirror of Divine Transcendents* details the grandeur of the Peach Assembly. Immortals raise their cups, reveling amidst seas and mountains—how the heart yearns for such a scene! The *pantao* peaches are cultivated by the Queen Mother of the West, ripening but once every three thousand years. Yet Dongfang Shuo is said to have stolen them. In Zhang Sanfeng’s *Lyrics of the Rootless Tree*, he writes:
*“Entering the immortal court, bold of spirit,*
*I stole the peaches of the Queen Mother of Yao Pond.”*
Though couched in allegory, this holds a profound secret. The Queen Mother embodies *Kun*, the image of Laozi’s “attaining emptiness and guarding stillness.” The peach symbolizes the primordial *qi*. The ancestral *qi* of pre-heaven must rely on *Kun*-earth to take form. As *Awakening to Reality* says, “Depending on the position of *Kun*, the body is formed.” *The Mirror of Entering the Medicine* states:
*“Born in Kun, planted in Qian.”*
*The Kinship of the Three* says:
*“The eldest son inherits the father’s body,*
*By the mother, the foundation is laid.”*
The *Book of Changes*’ *Kun* hexagram reads:
*“In the southwest, one finds companions.”*
All these describe the same image.

The peach ripens once every three thousand years—three being the generative number of wood—thus the peach embodies the image of *Zhen*. The Queen Mother represents the image of *Kun*; when she plants the peach and reaps the peach, above *Kun* and below *Zhen* form the hexagram *Fu*, the image of *"Thunder quakes beneath the earth, and the yellow sprout emerges from the soil."* This is also what is meant by *"From emptiness and stillness, white snow is born; from silence, the yellow sprout arises."*

Dongfang Shuo entered the Queen Mother’s peach garden and stole the peaches, which is to say, within the moving lines of the *Fu* hexagram, he gathered the primordial ancestral *qi* and returned it to the earthen crucible. As *Awakening to Reality* states: *"Recognizing the call, he brings it home to nourish."*

Dongfang Shuo and the Queen Mother naturally stand opposite as east and west. First, he enters from the east into the west, then returns from the west back to the east. *Awakening to Reality* says: *"The Metal Duke is originally the son of the eastern household, sent to the western neighbor to lodge and take form."* In *Journey to the West*, Sun Wukong is born in the Eastern Continent of Superior Body, travels to the Western Continent of Cattle-Gift to study the Dao, and later returns to Flower-Fruit Mountain. His battle with Erlang Shen (paired with the Maiden of Cinnabar in spiritual affinity), his capture by Lord Laozi, and his confinement in the Eight-Trigram Furnace (returned to the earthen crucible and sealed fast) all share the same meaning.

Otherwise, why must the Queen Mother be the one to cultivate the peaches? Why must the act of stealing them be attributed to Dongfang Shuo and no other? When the peaches ripen, the immortals gather to raise their cups in celebration, yet those who cultivate the profound mystery, once their practice reaches fruition, find their entire body softened, the true *qi* of original yang coursing and steaming through them, circulating throughout, like clouds drifting and rain descending, all things flourishing and harmonious. At all times, they may pluck the peach of immortality and drink the wine of the immortals—why wait for the Queen Mother to spread her feast before raising a cup?

Master Lü says: *"I drink the wine of long life in solitude—who knows my carefree joy?"* Master Zhang Sanfeng declares: *"When hunger comes, I drink the wine of long life, daily growing drunk as mud."* These words may be pondered.

One, eight, five—primal harmony in a single hue.

The *Scripture of the Five Kitchens* states: *"When qi harmonizes with supreme harmony, attaining the One, the Dao is wholly at peace. Harmony itself is no single harmony—its profound principle merges with the boundless."* The *Scripture of the Heart Seal* says: *"Supreme harmony overflows, bones scattering like cold jade."*

In the cultivation and realization of the profound mystery, heart and breath merge in wondrous union, water and fire blend as one, inner and outer harmonize alike. With the harmony of the entire body, one resonates with the harmony of heaven and earth, the surging harmony pervading all, vast and inexhaustible. Thus, the *Triple Concordance Canon* declares:

*"Dripping like vernal rain,
Flowing like melting ice,
From head to foot it streams,
Then ascends once more,
Coursing through the infinite,
Pervading all within."*

Shi Xinglin says:
*"Clouds disperse, revealing the crabapple moon,
Spring deepens with the willow’s breeze.
Who knows this meaning?
I lift my eyes to ask the empty sky."*

This is the wondrous realm of supreme harmony, where phoenix and simurgh sing in unison. Here, the embryo of the Dao may be perfected, mortal form transformed. By bathing body and mind in its purity, desire’s fire is stilled and the five spirits grow serene; by nurturing the root-source, yin qi dissolves and the hundred bones align. Gathered, the five qi ascend to the origin; dispersed, they fill the five viscera. No greater art of nurturing life exists, and within it lies the fullness of longevity.

The ancient sage said: *"To know harmony is to know constancy."* Liezi declared: *"The waxing and waning of the one body all communicate with heaven and earth, resonating with the ten thousand kinds. Harmonious at the beginning, harmonious at the end—still the spirit, extinguish thought, and therein lies the Way of life."* Such is the subtlety of advancing in the profound mystery.

**Eulogy:**
From cinnabar peaks, phoenix and simurgh alight in the jade tower,
In the secret hall, the *Xiaoshao* hymn plays its nine movements.
The rustic elder knows not the honor of the imperial carriage,
Yet through the six streets still echoes the sound of the silent whip.

**186. Beyond the One Hue**
In the practice of the profound mystery, when one reaches the state of utter supreme harmony, a single hue, the work of nine returns and seven reversals is already accomplished. Ascending further, the very void shatters, effortlessly transcending all, abiding neither in the one hue nor in the mysterious wondrous. Freed from the body, without reliance—only then is it called "transcending the norm."

Thus, the ancient worthies said: *"When the one hue dissolves, only then is it called noble. Shifting one’s step in subtlety, the crane escapes the silver cage. Turning within the station, the moon spreads gold upon the earth."* Dongshan remarked: *"White powder cannot conceal traces, Chang’an is no place for long abiding."* For though Chang’an is fine, it is not a home for lingering. Turning to the next station, not dwelling in nobility, one naturally cannot be confined.

If one clings to the edge of the one hue, to the station of purity, one still falls into the rut—how could this accord with the supreme mystery of the Dao?

**Eulogy:**
Having grasped the principle of emptiness,
One follows illumination to forget the nature.
Unless merit and power are exhausted,
How can one avoid awaiting the Empty King?

(*The Heavenly Music Collection* concludes)

**Appendix: Six Texts**

**Appendix I: Responses to Ten Questions from Gentleman Tang Muxuan**
**By the Hermit of Haiyin Mountain**

**1. On the Stages of Learning the Dao—Please Outline the General Framework.**
**Answer:** The stages of learning the Dao may be summarized in four steps: faith, understanding, practice, and realization. This is the broad outline.

Faith is the first step, and understanding the second. Faith must be deep, and understanding must be thorough. For example, if one resolves to journey to Wudang Mountain in Hubei to pay homage, one must firmly believe in the existence of the Taihe immortal realm and the possibility of reaching it. Understanding means clearly grasping the route—knowing the land and water paths, as well as the conditions for food and lodging along the way—and preparing sufficient travel funds. Practice entails personally traversing the terrain, advancing according to the predetermined route. Realization is attained upon reaching the destination, where one abides in freedom and enjoys the fullness of the Way. Realization has varying depths, but liberation is the ultimate goal. Until liberation is achieved, one remains in the stage of practice and cannot be said to have entered realization.

By "liberation," I mean transcending the Five Turbidities, surpassing the Three Realms, and escaping both the segmental and transformative forms of birth and death. For beginners, faith and understanding are urgent tasks. Once practice begins and understanding is transcended, realization becomes the ultimate aim.

**2. On the Stages of Cultivating the Dao—Please Also Outline the General Framework.**
**Answer:** Tanzi’s *Book of Transformations* states: *"Forget the form to nourish qi; forget qi to nourish spirit; forget spirit to nourish emptiness. When emptiness and reality interpenetrate, this is called Great Harmony."* This is the general framework of the stages.

Thus, Master Bai said: *"Forget the form to nourish qi, and qi transforms into spirit—this is the Great Dao penetrating the Three Passes."* Since the Yuan and Ming dynasties, it has been commonly said: *"Refine essence into qi, refine qi into spirit, refine spirit to return to emptiness."* However, this is not as all-encompassing as Master Tan’s teaching.

**3. Today, many study the Dao, but none are heard to have attained it. Where lies the crux of the problem? Can you point it out?**
**Answer:** "Studying the Dao" is a general term. Among those who use it, some are sincere in their pursuit, aiming to transcend birth and death; others seek fame and profit, using it as a pretense; some follow along temporarily but soon abandon it, beginning without perseverance; and others blindly follow false teachers, practicing without guidance. All call themselves Dao-seekers, but most do not align with the Dao.

Let us focus on those who genuinely study the Dao to transcend birth and death: some encounter true teachers, while others do not; some receive complete instructions from true teachers, while others only learn preliminary practices or obtain only half the method. Even among those who are sincere, have met true teachers, and received complete instructions, some face various obstacles that hinder their practice; others procrastinate until their allotted time runs out, leaving no opportunity for cultivation; and some are able to let go of everything, advancing without hindrance—these are those whose virtue is sufficient and whose Dao is complete, thus fulfilling their aspirations.

Generally, cultivating the Dao must be supported by virtue. Those lacking in virtue often encounter demonic obstacles when attempting to practice. I have witnessed this many times. For example, if you have long resided in an inn, accumulating unpaid debts for room and board, you may continue staying without immediate reckoning. But if you decide to leave for elsewhere, the innkeeper and attendants will demand a full settlement of all accounts before allowing you to depart. This world within the Three Realms is like an inn where we have lodged for kalpas, accruing countless karmic debts from past lives. If you vow to transcend birth and death and leave the Three Realms, all past karmic debts must be settled at once—otherwise, there will be no future opportunity for repayment. This is why, in *Journey to the West*, the moment Tang Monk vows to fetch the scriptures from the Western Heaven, eighty-one tribulations arise. Few attain the Dao, half due to not meeting true teachers, and half due to their own procrastination or karmic obstructions.

**4. Should those who study immortality eat meat or abstain from it? If one studies Buddhism, the teachings are explicit—this is not an issue. However, alchemical texts contain no precepts mandating vegetarianism for Dao cultivators. Conversely, Master Sanfeng said: *"Drink wine, eat meat, yet keep a vegetarian’s diet of wine and meat in the belly."* He also told Layman Wang: *"For those who abstain from meat, I say: ‘A kind heart surpasses a kind mouth; it suffices to follow the gentleman’s teaching to stay far from the kitchen.’"* The *Daoist Ballad* states: *"Do not abstain from meat or commit lust, for lust forfeits the treasure of long life; wine and meat pass through the intestines, but the Dao resides in the heart."* This clearly permits meat-eating.

Yet I wonder: why does Buddhism enforce precepts while Daoism relaxes them? Are their teachings so divergent? Do you eat meat or abstain? On this matter, what insights can you offer to guide later learners?**
**Answer:** In my work *Random Notes on the Treasures of the Dao*, there is a discussion on the meat-eating question. When I have time, I will excerpt and submit it for publication in this journal. This issue pertains to the cultivation of virtue.

We who practice the Dao are descendants of the ancient sages and must naturally adhere to the ancestral teachings. Among the Three Treasures of the ancient sages, compassion is foremost. It is said: *"Thus the sage constantly excels in saving beings, and so abandons none."* And: *"Heaven will save them, with compassion as their defense."* Because people eat meat, nets are cast in the mountains and forests, and traps are set in the depths of waters. Oxen and sheep, large creatures, and fish, turtles, shrimp, and crabs, small ones, are captured and slaughtered without respite.

Just ask yourself: does this accord with the ancient sages’ principle of *"great compassion as foremost"* and their teaching of *"constantly excelling in saving beings"*? If you admire and emulate the sages’ way of *"long life and enduring vision"* yet reject and discard their injunctions to *"practice great compassion, save all beings, and remain tranquil and free from desire,"* then you become self-serving and profit-seeking, turning your back on the sages and betraying the Dao. In such a case, your virtue will be insufficient, and you will find it difficult to attain immortality.

If you truly desire long life, you must also wish for every being to enjoy long life and fulfill its true nature. Only then will you align with the spirit of great compassion. Among those who have eloquently discussed immortality, none surpass *Baopuzi*. In its second scroll, *"On Immortality,"* it states: *"The method of learning immortality requires tranquility, joy, and detachment, cleansing oneself of cravings and desires."* It further says: *"The Dao of immortality demands love extended even to creeping insects, never harming any sentient being."* And again: *"The Dao of immortality requires abstaining from foul and rank foods, fasting to purify the intestines."*

In *"Subtle Principles,"* it declares: *"Those who seek long life must accumulate merit, cultivate compassion toward all beings, extend empathy to others, and show kindness even to insects."* All these teachings align perfectly with the *Daodejing*. Yet if one kills beings to nourish oneself, how far does this stray from the precepts of *"kindness extended to insects, love extended to creeping things, never harming sentient beings"*? And how far does it depart from the admonition to *"cleanse oneself of cravings and desires"*?

Master Sanfeng said: *"A kind heart surpasses kind words; embody the noble person’s teaching to distance oneself from the kitchen."* He continues: *"Nurturing qi naturally nourishes the body; one should follow the perfected person’s prohibition against foul odors."* This clearly shows that harmonious food suffices to nourish the five viscera, rendering unnecessary the *Inner Canon*’s dictum that *"those deficient in essence should supplement it with flavors."*

The *"perfected person’s prohibition against foul odors"* means abstaining from meat, as the *Analects* states: *"Food of displeasing color or foul odor is not eaten."* Between mouth and heart, a kind heart is naturally superior to kind words. Yet how much more sublime is it to observe the precepts with urgency, cultivating both heart and speech in perfect harmony!

I observe that Master Feng’s words are boundlessly harmonious, yet you cling only to his opening line while neglecting what follows—this becomes a one-sided view. The phrase *"wine and meat pass through the intestines, but the Dao resides in the heart"* should be weighed by its final three characters. Today’s people let wine and meat fill their bellies while their hearts remain devoid of the Dao, indulging only in flavors and yielding to the five desires. Their state is worlds apart from Master Sanfeng’s realm, so one cannot seize upon this line to raise objections.

In essence, both immortals and buddhas prize a pure and tranquil heart. If the mouth craves fish and meat, the eyes will crave the five colors, and the ears will crave the five sounds. Dwelling daily amid the realm of the five desires, one risks losing resonance with the pure heart. Moreover, killing living beings accumulates karmic enmity: if I harm others, they will seek to harm me in turn. Cause and effect circulate without the slightest deviation. We who cultivate the Dao must urgently clear our past debts and lighten our karmic obstructions—how can we incur new ones?

I myself began studying the Dao at nineteen, eating meat as circumstances allowed. Not until twenty-seven did I encounter *The Myriad Goodnesses Resource Collection* by Zhou Anshi of the early Qing—a most excellent book. After reading it repeatedly, a heart of compassion arose spontaneously within me. I realized that killing to sustain one’s own life contradicts the great compassionate principle, harms heavenly harmony, depletes hidden virtue, and violates the benevolent teachings of Confucius and Laozi. It was time to change course.

Yet old habits die hard. After a few days of vegetarianism, cravings for meat returned. Adapting to the circumstances, I alternated between meat and vegetarian meals, while ceasing to kill any living beings—no fish, shrimp, or other creatures were purchased. Whenever I had spare money each month, I bought animals to release in acts of liberation. After more than a year of this practice, I finally adopted a pure vegetarian diet, which I have maintained for seventeen or eighteen years now.

Both immortals and buddhas triumph through a heart of compassion, seeing all beings as oneself. Ancient legends speak of the Compassionate Immortal and the Heavenly Worthy of Great Compassion Who Saves from Suffering. If you take compassion as your guiding principle, then abstaining from meat and refraining from killing will pose no difficulty. How can you doubt this simply because it is absent from the immortals’ scriptures?

Confucius said: *"Loyalty and forbearance are not far from the Dao. What you do not wish for yourself, do not impose upon others."* Zengzi said: *"The Master’s Dao consists solely of loyalty and forbearance."* Setting aside profound theories, the proverb says: *"Put yourself in another’s place."* If you do not wish to be harmed or killed, yet daily wield blades against defenseless creatures, this is a failure of forbearance. The ancient sages taught compassion and protection, yet you turn your back on them, slaughtering lives to fill your belly—this is a failure of loyalty.

All creatures, however humble, possess sentience. This sentience is no different in essence from that of a sage who has attained the fruit. To destroy sentient beings is to lack benevolence. Thus, this matter bears profoundly on the cultivation of virtue. If you claim that one whose humanity is incomplete can still attain the immortal Dao, I remain skeptical.

**Five:** What distinguishes the cultivation and realization of immortals and buddhas?
**Answer:** After all, water flows eastward to the sea; in the end, clouds must seek their mountain home.

**Six:** How do the attainments of immortals and buddhas compare in superiority?
**Answer:** When clouds settle, every home has its moon; when spring arrives, every tree blooms with flowers.

**Seven:** Does studying immortality hinder worldly engagement? Does worldly engagement hinder the study of immortality?
**Answer:** Dense bamboo does not obstruct flowing water; how can high mountains block the flight of white clouds?

**Eight:** What constitutes the family style of a Daoist?
**Answer:** Walk with unhurried steps, speak in a low voice, attend to each breath, and distance the heart from thoughts. Only when you cast off all ties and return to the mountains will true freedom and ease manifest.

**Nine:** You must have read many alchemical texts—with which do you most resonate?
**Answer:** *The Collected Works of Master Bai*.

**Ten:** Regarding *The Seventeen Daoist Books*, are they orthodox or heterodox?
**Answer:** One who has wandered through the Dragon Canon will naturally discern at a glance. But if one was born in a thatched hut, let them be dazzled by the five colors. The worst is like Zhu Bajie eating the ginseng fruit—swallowing it whole and then asking what it tasted like! Never mind the taste—why must the ginseng fruit grow in the Wuzhuang Temple? What is the Wuzhuang Temple? What is the ginseng fruit?

---

**Appendix II: Five Letters in Reply to a Friend**
**By Haiyin Mountain Man**
**First Letter**

Wang Menglou of the Qing devoted his life to Buddhist study, then turned to immortality in his eighties, exchanging poems with immortals. Your letter asks, *"Why descend in old age?"*—this is a misunderstanding. The study of the Dao aims to resolve the three sufferings of old age, sickness, and death. At eighty, one is already aged: vitality wanes, steps falter, and eating becomes difficult. Hearing and sight lose their acuity; hair turns white, the face wrinkles, and death draws near.

At such a time, if someone could relieve one’s immediate suffering, the heart would gladly follow. This is the natural inclination of human nature. Menglou had a deep affinity for Chan, yet in his exchanges with immortals, they must have transmitted to him arts for prolonging life and dispelling illness—methods for regulating breath and calming the spirit—so that he might attain true benefit and resolve the vexations of old age and sickness. While the Buddha’s teachings are lofty, many discuss its principles, but few have realized them in practice. To claim that the sufferings of old age and sickness cannot be resolved, yet the suffering of death can; or that one cannot attain sagehood in this life, but can after death—these are nothing but self-deception and deceiving others.

The Daoist tradition values only the present moment: if one can calm the spirit and harmonize the breath to gain true benefit, the future will reveal itself without inquiry. Thus, the Daoist path is like a merchant acquiring goods—demanding immediate payment, not promissory notes, and disdaining credit. Today’s Buddhists, however, seek future rewards, rebirth after death, all relying on promissory notes. Yet when the note comes due, whether it can be honored remains uncertain. The proverb says, *"Rejecting cash in hand for credit"*—this perfectly captures the mindset of most Buddhists today.

Have you not read the *Sutra in Forty-Two Sections*, the earliest Buddhist text translated into Chinese? The Buddha asked how long a person’s life lasts, and none of his disciples’ answers satisfied him. Finally, one replied, *"It lasts but a single breath."* The Buddha praised him, saying he understood the Way. What does this mean? How is breath related to the Dao? Know this: where breath resides, the Dao resides. Since life exists in the space between breaths, why not, before the breath ceases, calm the spirit and regulate the breath to avoid bankruptcy? If one waits until the breath is cut off, the cash is already spent. Even with a promissory note, where can it be redeemed? How can one bear to wait for bankruptcy—is this not delusion?

**Second Letter**

Your letter says that *"life lasts but a single breath"* merely illustrates its brevity—*"the incoming breath does not guarantee the outgoing."* My brother, you have grasped only half of it. If the Buddha meant only to speak of brevity, he would have said, *"Excellent! You understand time,"* not *"Excellent! You understand the Way."* Clearly, this is not a matter of time.

The Dao resides in the space between breaths—this is the meaning of *"regulating breath and calming the spirit."* Breath is the wind-like aspect of the heart-mind. When breath is regulated, the heart-mind is settled; when breath is harmonious, the heart-mind is at peace. When one is enraged, the heart-mind rages, and the breath grows coarse. During a race, the heart-mind races, and the breath becomes short. The dead have no breath because the heart-mind has departed; the heart-mind in samadhi has no breath because it is quiescent. Thus, from having breath to regulating it until there is no breath—when external respiration ceases entirely—then the heart-mind has no arising or ceasing. With no arising or ceasing of the heart-mind, no inhalation or exhalation of breath, the state of great samadhi emerges, and the Dao abides there.

Have you not seen the words of Prajñātāra, the twenty-seventh patriarch of Chan, in reply to the King of East India? He said: *"This poor monk’s exhalation does not follow the myriad conditions; his inhalation does not dwell in the skandhas. Constantly turning the sutra thus for hundreds of thousands of millions of volumes—not merely one or two."* Prajñātāra took the regulation of inhalation and exhalation as the turning of the sutra—turning the sutra of one’s own body, not another’s. When spirit and breath are harmoniously blended, continuous yet imperceptible, the inner landscape is pure and still, the outer world empty and merged—is this not what is meant by *"exhalation does not follow the myriad conditions, inhalation does not dwell in the skandhas"*? This is the practice Laozi described as *"focusing qi to attain suppleness, embracing the soul and holding to the One."*

Turning another’s sutra brings great merit, but turning the sutra of one’s own true breath brings even greater merit. Turning the sutra of written words brings great merit, but turning the sutra of wordless truth brings even greater merit. Yet people abandon the near to seek the far, crave the lofty but neglect the practical. If one cannot even master a single breath, how can one speak of anything else?

Today, there are millions of Buddhists, yet all disregard the *Sutra in Forty-Two Sections*, dismissing it as too simple. The meaning of *"life lasts but a single breath"* eludes them entirely. They vainly hope to attain Buddhahood in this very body, yet possess not a shred of the capital required—like a pauper with not a single coin dreaming of becoming the owner of Yong’an Xianshi, the grandest amusement company before Liberation. How absurd!

The *Sutra in Forty-Two Sections* is the first step in Buddhist practice. Establishing the Dao within the space between breaths is its very essence. The Daoist *Huangting Jing* says: *"Behind lies the secret chamber, before the gate of life; sun emerges, moon enters—breath abides."* Chen Xubai said: *"Breath comes and goes without interruption; the sacred embryo is perfected, returning to the primordial."* Xu Jinyang said: *"Internally harmonize true qi with breath; naturally, the transformations restore youthful countenance."* Li Daochun said: *"Opening and closing respond to heaven and earth—this is the gate of the Mysterious Female. From no exit or entry, one alone reigns over the three realms."* And again: *"Carefully observe the books of the sages of the Three Teachings—the character ‘breath’ is simplest. If one works on the practice of breath, becoming a Buddha or an immortal requires no effort."* Zheng Heyang said: *"Where there is a heart-mind, there is breath; heart-mind and breath depend on each other and cannot be separated."*

"Reversing breath harms the heart-mind,
Forcing heart-mind and breath to prey upon each other.
When heart-mind and breath prey upon each other, the six demons attack,
And the celestial soul is driven into the realm of ghosts.

Master Ju said: *Breath is the root of all virtues in one’s own heart-mind.
When breath flows smoothly, the heart-mind is at peace, and the hundred limbs are at ease—
The great treasury of radiant light stands firm as bedrock.
Round and fluid, not a speck of shadow clings,
Nature and life pure and boundless, matching heaven itself.*

Śākyamuni’s subtle words spoke of nothing else,
Laozi’s *Dao and Virtue* all concern this.
Yanzi found joy in his bamboo bowl and gourd ladle,
Clearly seeing that breath abides—never daring to slacken.

Though one may expound ten thousand classics and a thousand scriptures,
All rest in the realm of settled heart-mind and breath."

Observe the final line, and the phrase *"when breath flows smoothly, the heart-mind is at peace, and the hundred limbs are at ease,"* and you will grasp the meaning of *The Sutra in Forty-Two Sections*—that the Dao resides in the space between breaths, where in a single inhalation and exhalation, the wondrous practice of establishing the Dao-ground is perfected.

*The Treatise on Consciousness-Only* may be fine,
But it cannot cure white hair or stomach ailments—
Not like the wondrous simplicity of returning wind and blending it,
Where breath alone suffices.

Is this so? Reflect carefully upon it!

**Three**
**Unobstructed**

Your letter suggests setting aside the Lesser Vehicle’s *Sutra in Forty-Two Sections* to discuss the Great Vehicle’s *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* and *Avataṃsaka Sūtra*. Very well—let us speak of these two.

Have you not seen that among the *Śūraṅgama*’s twenty-five sages who attained perfect penetration, two achieved the exhaustion of outflows and realized arhatship precisely through regulating the breath? The first was Śroṇa Koṭīkarṇa, who declared: *“When the Buddha asked about perfect penetration, as I have realized it, reversing the breath to merge with emptiness—this is foremost.”* The second was Sundarananda, who said: *“When the Buddha asked about perfect penetration, I dissolved my thoughts, and through long-continued breath-regulation, illumination arose, outflows were extinguished, and this—this is foremost.”* What is meant by “reversing the breath to merge with emptiness”? It is the cessation of external respiration, the transformation of qi into spirit, and the radiance of spirit-light.

Furthermore, in the *Śūraṅgama*’s ten stages of abiding, the phrase *“body and mind unite and grow daily”* describes the interdependence of heart-mind and breath in forming the sacred embryo. *“Having roamed within the Dao-embryo, one personally attends the lineage of awakening; as the embryo matures, the human marks are complete.”* It also states: *“The ten spiritual marks of the body are simultaneously perfected.”* And again: *“Having taken form and emerged from the embryo, one is personally a Buddha-child—this is called the abiding of the Dharma Prince.”* Here, the Dao-embryo is fully realized, and the true person appears.

People know only that the *Śūraṅgama* criticizes the ten kinds of immortals, yet they do not realize these immortals belong to the earthly immortals—mere Lesser Vehicle practitioners of immortality. The lineage transmitted beneath the pillar aligns with the *Śūraṅgama*’s ten stages of abiding. Within this profound mystery, those who receive the true transmission understand it for themselves. Among the Great Vehicle scriptures, none so wondrously accords with the esoteric teaching of *“regulating the breath to form the embryo, nurture the embryo, and emerge from the embryo”* as the *Śūraṅgama*.

The Tiantai school’s contemplative teachings hold that in a single lifetime, one can only attain the initial stage of perfect abiding. Yet in the esoteric tradition’s cultivation and realization, a single lifetime can indeed attain all ten stages of abiding. Those of superior capacity, having realized the ten stages, leap directly into the two wisdoms of equal and wondrous enlightenment. For once the ten stages of abiding are complete, one has attained the Dharma-body, with boundless lifespan—free to roam and cultivate the Dao. The most difficult part is entering the abiding from the state of an ordinary being. How does one enter the abiding? The abiding is constant abiding; if one dies, one does not understand constant abiding. Constant abiding is longevity—both life and nature are eternally abiding.

Setting aside the *Śūraṅgama* for now, let us turn to the *Avataṃsaka Sūtra*’s *Chapter on Leaving the Worldly*, which expounds the ten kinds of freedom. The first is *“freedom of life”*—abiding in lifespan for incalculable eons. Is this not the Buddha’s longevity? Have you not also seen in the *Entering the Dharma Realm* chapter that Sudhana visited the bhikṣu Ocean Banner, who had transcended inhalation and exhalation, without any other thoughts or perceptions, and entered the great quiescent samādhi, remaining in that samādhi for six months and six days before emerging? What is meant by *“transcending inhalation and exhalation, without any other thoughts or perceptions”* is precisely the esoteric tradition’s state of *“dual extinction of breath and thought, dual stabilization of body and mind”*—what Master Huzi called *“the Great Thoroughfare, without trace.”* The Great Thoroughfare is the image of emptiness and quiescence; *“without trace”* means no sign is discernible, like the antelope hanging its horns—no trail can be found. This great samādhi was attained by the bhikṣu Ocean Banner, and it is also attained by the esoteric tradition’s good spiritual friends. If, in samādhi, the heart-mind abides but the breath does not, this is only a semblance of quiescent extinction, not true quiescent extinction. Such a person, if their breath were obstructed during samādhi, would be unable to maintain it. Thus, only samādhi without breath is true samādhi. Samādhi with breath is worthless—still water does not harbor dragons. How could one then perfect the ten spiritual marks of the body simultaneously, emerge from the embryo, and personally become a Buddha-child?

Furthermore, in the *Entering the Dharma Realm* chapter, Sudhana’s fiftieth visit was to the youth Virtue-Born and the maiden Virtue-Girl. Their city was called *Wondrous Intention Flower Gate*, and the Dharma-gate they taught was called *Liberation through Illusory Abiding*—this too conceals the secret meaning of *“heart-mind and breath interdependent, harmonizing in samādhi.”* Observe that all the good spiritual friends Sudhana had previously visited were solitary individuals, but here they appear as a pair—what else could this signify but the representation of one yin and one yang, the symbolic harmony of heart-mind and breath? The youth and maiden lived and traveled together. In terms of cultivation, at the stage of fruition, samādhi and wisdom harmonize as a pair; at the stage of practice, heart-mind and breath harmonize as a pair. The word *“wondrous”* is also symbolic—it is one yin and one yang. *“Wondrous Intention Flower Gate”* is akin to the Laozi’s *“Gate of the Myriad Wonders”* and *“Mysterious Female Gate.”* At the moment when heart-mind and breath harmonize, there arises a subtle mutual awareness. When, in quiescent stabilization, yang is born, the time arrives and spirit knows—like a child recognizing its mother. It is wondrous beyond words—is this not *“wondrous intention”*? Heart-mind and breath follow each other, phoenixes in harmony, a natural union of husband and wife. Yet the man does not loosen his robe, nor the woman untie her sash—they revere each other as divine, cherish each other as their own child. Is this not *“illusory abiding”*? Thus it is called *“liberation through illusory abiding.”* Only when one reaches the great samādhi, the true samādhi—without going or coming, without exiting or entering, forgetting both inner and outer, body and mind both quiescent, emptiness without reliance—is this called *“non-abiding.”* From illusory abiding, one attains non-abiding—here, the work of esoteric cultivation is complete.

The sūtra further states: *“At that time, the youth and maiden, having expounded their own liberation, used the power of inconceivable roots of goodness to make Sudhana’s body soft and radiant.”* The commentary explains: *“Softness”* refers to the state where, through the interdependence of heart-mind and breath, the entire body becomes supple and pliant. Bai Ziqing said: *“After you practice for two or three days, heaven and earth, sun and moon will become soft as silk.”* This is the true effect.

The radiance refers to the effervescence of primordial yang’s luminous *qi* upon the skin, manifesting externally. *The Yellow Court Scripture* states: *“The body generates radiant splendor, its qi fragrant as orchids.”* Master Zhongli Quan said: *“Jade-like nectar flows and glistens, giving rise to luminosity.”* Both express the same meaning. This is the sign of the fiftieth visitation, deeply resonant with the esoteric Daoist tradition. Yet all previous commentators on the *Avataṃsaka Sūtra* have spoken only of principle, interpreting the youth and maiden as symbols of *samādhi* and *prajñā*. But for those still in the causal stage—ordinary beings without *samādhi* or *prajñā*—how should they begin their practice? The wondrous gateway of the Flower Adornment City exists within every person. Once the masters point out the mysterious pass, one naturally understands. Such profound and subtle manifestations are not easily discussed with outsiders. For this reason, over the past twenty years, I have never revealed this, fearing it might invite slander. Now, for my brother’s sake, I speak of it—perhaps you may glimpse another heaven and earth, the sun and moon within the gourd, the liberation of illusory abiding, and the truly inconceivable spiritual efficacy.

---

Your letter states: *“The immortals value longevity, while Buddhists value non-arising.”* Know that “non-arising” means not clinging to the appearance of arising, not that one becomes like withered wood or cold ashes, utterly devoid of vitality. If one were truly like withered wood or cold ashes, one would fall into the nihilistic heterodoxy, far from the Buddha’s true intent of neither arising nor ceasing. Laozi said: *“That by which heaven and earth endure so long is their non-self-arising; thus they attain long life.”* “Non-self-arising” means not clinging to arising—true arising without arising. *The Song of Enlightenment by Yongjia* says: *“Who is without thought? Who is without arising? Truly, without arising, there is nothing that does not arise.”* This means that if one realizes the principle of non-arising, one is also without death—thus, without arising yet nothing unarisen. In this light, Laozi’s “long life” does not fall into eternalism, nor does the Buddha’s “non-arising” fall into annihilationism. Without arising yet arising—this is the Buddha; arising yet without arising—this is the immortal. How can one rigidly divide them and rank their superiority? Understanding this, one knows there is no immortal who is not a Buddha, no Buddha who is not an immortal. True non-arising is true long life; true long life is wondrous accord with true non-arising. At this point, the barriers between the Daoist and Buddhist traditions may be entirely dismantled.

Nowadays, followers of the Buddha, upon hearing of longevity, dismiss it as heterodoxy, contrary to the Buddha’s original intent. They do not realize that the Buddha, for those attached to the vital essence and whose emotional views remain unbroken, teaches non-arising. But if one’s emotional views are already shattered, it is precisely then that one should be taught longevity. The *Lotus Sūtra* reveals the provisional to manifest the real; the *Avataṃsaka Sūtra* exhausts all emotional measures—both reveal the secret of the freely commanded life. In the final teaching of *Nirvāṇa*, entering great *nirvāṇa* means neither aging nor dying, perfectly in harmony with the Yellow and Lao of the East. How can one rigidly adhere to one side, assigning non-arising to Buddhism and longevity to Daoism, exalting non-arising while disparaging longevity? Know that non-arising and longevity are merely different approaches to cultivation and subjugation.

---

While the *Śūraṅgama* and *Avataṃsaka* sūtras already interweave the paths of immortals and Buddhas, the most wondrous of all is the *Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra*. Mahākāśyapa asked the Buddha: *“How does one attain long life, an indestructible vajra-body, and through what causes and conditions does one gain great, unshakable power?”*—this is openly inquiring about longevity.
