The *Four Marks Chapter* states: *“It is like a potter who, having made a vessel, eventually breaks it. Liberation is not like this. True liberation is neither arising nor ceasing; therefore, liberation is the Tathāgata. The Tathāgata is also thus: neither arising nor ceasing, neither aging nor dying, neither breaking nor decaying, not a conditioned dharma. For this reason, it is called the Tathāgata. Entering great *nirvāṇa*, neither aging nor dying—what does this mean? Aging is called change: hair turning white, skin wrinkling, body decaying, life ending. Such things do not exist in liberation; because they are absent, it is called liberation. The Tathāgata also has no conditioned dharmas like white hair or wrinkled skin; therefore, the Tathāgata is without aging. Without aging, there is no death. Furthermore, liberation is called freedom from illness. What is illness? The four hundred and four diseases, along with other external harms that injure the body—these do not exist in liberation; thus, it is called liberation. Without illness, this is true liberation. True liberation is the Tathāgata. The Tathāgata is without illness; therefore, the Dharma-body is also without illness. Such freedom from illness is the Tathāgata. Death is called the decay of the body and the end of life; where there is no death, this is ambrosia. Ambrosia is true liberation. True liberation is the Tathāgata. The Tathāgata possesses such merits—how can one say the Tathāgata is impermanent? If one claims impermanence, this is impossible. How can the vajra-body be impermanent? Therefore, the Tathāgata is not said to have a life’s end.”*

In this passage, the Tathāgata extensively demonstrates that those who attain true liberation are neither arising nor ceasing, neither breaking nor decaying, neither aging nor dying, and are free from the unsightly marks of white hair and wrinkled skin. Free from illness, this is no different from the immortals’ long life—one might say the immortal and the Buddha are of one breath, like water and milk perfectly blended. Yet how is it that today’s Buddhists, puffed up with self-importance, look down upon the immortal tradition as heterodoxy, dismissing it as one of the seven destinies? They themselves cannot escape illness, nor can they avoid the changes of white hair and wrinkled skin—no different from ordinary people. What, then, is the meaning of great *nirvāṇa*? What is true liberation? The wonder of ambrosia need not even be mentioned.

One must know that after the World-Honored One’s passing, those who grasped the profound purport of *mahāparinirvāṇa*—of neither aging nor dying—were found in the Mystery Tradition. Thus Wang Wenzhi, after broadly studying the Buddha’s teachings, at over eighty years of age suddenly turned to the Dao and followed immortals in their wanderings.

---

**Appendix III: An Entry from the Diary of Elder Li Tingguang**

Master Songyao said: “Mr. Wang Dongting propagated the Dao in Shanghai for decades yet could not attain the Way himself, his years having already declined into old age. When Master Hanxu arrived, he taught him the method of *tou-tai duo-she* (rebirth through seizing a womb). At the time of Mr. Dongting’s passing, he instructed him (referring to Xu Songyao) to seek him out at a certain time and place (referring to Wang Dongting). However, as war was imminent, he (Xu Songyao) was unable to go. I believe that as long as one does not forget their ‘original true nature,’ *tou-tai duo-she* remains possible.”

*(This diary entry was provided by Mr. Lin Feng of Shanghai. Mr. Li Tingguang once studied under Xu Songyao, also known as Haiyinzi. In the mid-20th century, Li Tingguang and six others—Jiang Weiqiao, Hu Meicheng, Lu Zidong, Chu Xiangjiang, Gu Boshu, and Lu Huaidao—formed the ‘Seven Gentlemen’s Tea Gathering for Nurturing Life,’ exploring Daoist scholarship. It is said that Li Hanxu, the founding patriarch of the Western Lineage, personally came to Shanghai to transmit the *tou-tai duo-she* method to Ti Zhen Shanren Wang Dongting. According to *A Brief Biography of the Perfected Li Hanxu* by Li Daoshan of the Qing, Li Hanxu ascended in the year *bingchen* of the Xianfeng era (1856). Yet he manifested again in the world no later than the mid-20th century to transmit the teaching to Wang Dongting, more than sixty or seventy years after his passing. Mr. Lin Feng commented on this passage: ‘Upon first reading this, I was truly startled.’ How could I not feel the same! This also demonstrates the extraordinary efficacy of the ancient transmission of inner alchemy, and the truth of self-mastery and rebirth of life is not false. Daoist scholar Chen Yingning (1880–1969) once remarked: ‘Whether *tou-tai* is truly reliable—rather than being troubled by the inability to verify it with facts, one can only believe it to be extraordinary.’ This case is no different. Whether it is true or not, I do not know. It is merely appended here as documentary material, left for scientific researchers to investigate and verify! Furthermore, the method of *tou-tai duo-she* comprises four types: *tou-tai* (rebirth), *duo-she* (seizing a body), *jie-shi* (borrowing a corpse), and *zhuan-shi* (transmigration)—collectively known as the ‘Four Fruits.’”)*

*—Gan Keqi’s note*

---

**Appendix IV: Excerpt from Mr. Hu Meicheng’s *Postscript to the Exegesis of Southern Lineage Alchemical Secrets***

“In the early 20th century, I made three journeys to Suzhou and personally visited Xu Songyao, the renowned Daoist scholar of Suzhou, Shanghai, and Hangzhou, known as Master Xuanjing. A graduate of Tsinghua University, Master Xu devoted his life to Daoist studies. In his later years, his disciples numbered in the thousands, and his *Collected Writings on Heavenly Joy* circulated widely. However, he avoided discussing the teachings of the Yin-Yang Lineage.”

“The inner alchemical practice of Daoism, whether in solitary or dual cultivation, hinges upon the critical stage of *huo-zi yang-sheng* (the living child’s arousal) and the gathering of the medicine. Yet many Daoist texts do not speak of this openly—it remains an untransmitted secret. The *huo-zi* moment has three types: the true *zi* hour, the proper *zi* hour, and the false *zi* hour. When the living child’s yang arises, one ignites the fire and gathers the medicine. The medicine itself varies in maturity, distinguished as one yang, two yangs, or three yangs. The medicine is called the ‘true seed,’ hence Zhang Ziyang’s *Awakening to Reality* verse: ‘If the cauldron lacks the true seed, do not waste the furnace’s fire on an empty pot.’ Without receiving the true transmission, many find it difficult to recognize the authentic phenomenon of *huo-zi yang-sheng* when gathering the medicine. For instance, Daoist scholar Xu Songyao’s *Collected Writings on Heavenly Joy* states that when the pure yang *qi* stirs during quiet cultivation, the body may experience numbness, tingling, or twitching, and with each twitch, one circulates a minor celestial orbit, gradually gathering and accumulating. Alas! Numbness, lightness, heaviness, and the like are common ‘eight sensations’ in cultivation. To mistake these eight sensations for the *huo-zi yang-sheng* and the gathering of medicine is entirely mistaken. …If one cultivates quiet practice and mistakes the eight sensations for the arousal of yang, then rousing the yang becomes harmful, allowing the original *qi* to leak away and all prior efforts to be wasted—truly a pity.”

*(This postscript by Mr. Hu Meicheng was provided by Mr. Lin Feng of Shanghai. Mr. Hu made three journeys to Suzhou to personally visit Xu Songyao and inquire about the teachings of the Yin-Yang Lineage, only to be told that Songyao ‘avoided discussing it.’ This avoidance was not due to ignorance of the Yin-Yang Lineage’s teachings but rather an unwillingness to speak of them, likely owing to unspoken difficulties. Consider Haiyin’s reply in *Answers to Ten Questions from Mr. Tang Muxuan*: when asked whether the *Seventeen Daoist Texts* were orthodox or heterodox, he said, ‘Having roamed the Dragon Treasury, one naturally distinguishes at a glance.’ Among the *Seventeen Daoist Texts* are included *The Heart Seal of the Mysterious Subtlety* and *The Alchemical Secrets of the Three Peaks*, both renowned works of the Yin-Yang Lineage. Since he claimed to ‘distinguish at a glance’ after perusing the Dragon Treasury, improper transmission would cause grave harm—hence his reticence.)*

Moreover, it is commonly held that the Western Lineage is a dual-cultivation school of Yin and Yang. According to my understanding, the Western Lineage divides into two major transmission systems: one advocates solitary cultivation, the other dual cultivation. Yet the solitary-cultivation school is not without profound mastery of Yin-Yang studies, while the dual-cultivation school must also grasp the essence of solitary practice. Given the differences in time, place, and external conditions, each follows its own path to realization, though all ultimately converge. Those lacking the necessary external conditions keep their insights deeply concealed, remaining reticent to avoid unnecessary interference. As the *Classic of Purity* states: “If one can abide in constant purity, Heaven and Earth all return.” If the essence of Heaven and Earth can be drawn in, how could the human element not be gathered as well?

In *The Precious Raft of Dual Cultivation for the Female Ancestor of the Mud-Pill Lineage*, compiled by Min Yide of the Qing in *Hidden Books of the Ancient Book Concealment Tower*, it is written: “Solitary cultivation is not the supreme Dao; of like kind, each naturally requires the other. Those who attain a body beyond the body can, through forgetfulness of form, accomplish all things.” It further states: “The human element pervades the great thousand worlds; the Three Elements are mastered by one heart. It is nothing beyond a heart serene and empty, nothing beyond a body free of obstruction. In movement and stillness, one harmonizes with the true constant; the self, without origin, naturally merges.” This teaching opens the eye of wisdom.

The Three Elements—Heaven, Earth, and Human—are such that “the human element pervades the great thousand worlds,” not confined to the crucible of the other household. The function of the Three Elements is entirely governed by the mastery of one heart. In essence, the method lies in “a heart serene and empty” and “a body free of obstruction,” which is to say, “forgetting both body and heart, entering the great samadhi of true emptiness”—this is none other than the principle that “if one can abide in constant purity, Heaven and Earth all return.” If one can “forget form” and attain the state of “a body beyond the body,” then “all things can be accomplished.” Solitary is not merely solitary, dual not merely dual; “of like kind, each naturally requires the other.” As the *Cantong Qi* says: “Like a lodestone drawing iron, though separated by barriers, they communicate in secret.”

Thus, within solitary cultivation there is no absence of the principle of dual cultivation, and within dual cultivation there is also the work of purity. True cultivators may well integrate this pure method into dual practice, cultivating together with another, “roaming together in the boundless wilds,” and both will surely benefit, achieving the feat of husband and wife ascending as immortals! Though the dual-cultivation school possesses additional techniques such as “forging the sword” and “regulating the crucible,” with their own subtle methods, these are not as stable and free of pitfalls as the aforementioned approach, which anyone can verify without the need for additional precepts or constraints. Is this not what is meant by “its meaning most profound yet its traces most evident”?

Mr. Hu Meicheng further criticized the error of mistaking “tingling, numbness, and throbbing” for the arising of Yang and the production of medicine. The secret meaning of “tingling, numbness, and throbbing” may be found in detail in the *Collection of Celestial Joy*. Discerning scholars will surely understand what is indicated; I need not elaborate further.

Wei Yao, a fellow disciple of Haiyin, states in *The True Transmission of the Great Dao*: “Since ancient times, those who write books and establish teachings have all addressed the ills of their time.” The critiques of Haiyin and Meicheng are likewise corrective words aimed at contemporary errors. Take, for example, *The Immortal Lineage of Wu-Liu*, which emphasizes the stirring of the external kidneys as a sign of Yang arising. Those who do not comprehend the wondrous workings of nature cling to appearances and forms, failing to reach the state of “attaining emptiness” before vainly seeking the arising of Yang, even falling into attachment to sensual forms—how then can they speak of “abiding in constant purity”?

Thus, Haiyin wrote his books to correct the ills of his time, merely designating “softness, numbness, and tingling” as signs of Yang arising, so as not to lead beginners into attachment to form. If, within “attaining utmost emptiness and maintaining profound stillness,” one experiences “softness, numbness, and tingling,” progressing to “softness and bliss,” then the arising of Yang and the production of medicine occur naturally, and the source of medicine is as clear as pure water. What Mr. Meicheng criticized was indeed the error of mistaking the “eight sensations” for the arising of Yang and the failure to recognize the true signs of Yang arising.

The eight sensations are merely phenomena of the initial stage of entering stillness, signs of the first circulation of qi and blood and the initial quieting of the mind—far from reaching the level of “Yang arising and medicine producing.” With Mr. Meicheng’s vast knowledge, he naturally understood Haiyin’s intentions. Therefore, while Mr. Hu Meicheng’s critique is valid, the teachings of Haiyin also contain profound principles.

—Noted by Sheng Keqi

**Appendix V: Master Tian Chengyang’s Annotations on "Benefits of Daoist Practice" from *Secrets of Immortal Learning* Compiled by Haiyinzi**

Haiyinzi was a master of the Western School. His practice focused on external cultivation, fundamentally distinct from the Wu-Liu School’s method of guarding the lower dantian. What, then, is this "external cultivation"?

Zhang Yishang, in his annotations to *Casual Discourses on Immortal Dao*, provides a detailed account, which we excerpt below:

*"The Western School transmits an exceptional Heavenly Origin Elixir Method, wherein the spirit is stabilized and the breath regulated at the point one *cun* outside the nose, where the two bodies intersect. When breath is present, the spirit rests in the void beyond the nose; when breath ceases, the spirit enters samādhi in that same void. This practice begins with this method and culminates in it."*

*(Note: This annotation was provided by Mr. Zhang Tao of Tianmen, Hubei. Mr. Zhang Yishang, a native of Zhong County, Sichuan, possessed profound scholarship in both Buddhist and Daoist traditions.)*

From the annotations in *Casual Discourses on Immortal Dao*, it is evident that Master Zhang possessed considerable knowledge of the Western School’s elixir methods, striking at the very essence of the practice in a single phrase—truly a work that "paints the dragon and dots the eyes." Moreover, his designation of this method as the "exceptional Heavenly Origin Elixir Method" reveals his profound admiration. However, classifying it as a "separate transmission of the Western School" may not be entirely appropriate.

The Western School’s elixir studies are generally categorized under the yin-yang methods of the Human Origin Elixir tradition. Thus, the elder master, proceeding from this premise, labeled the Western School’s pure cultivation as a "separate transmission." Whether the Western School’s elixir system belongs to the yin-yang tradition or the pure cultivation tradition—and which branch may be considered the orthodox transmission—was briefly addressed in my annotations to the excerpt from Master Hu Meicheng’s *Postscript to the Exegesis of Southern School Elixir Formulas*, and I shall not elaborate further here.

*—Inscribed by Sheng Keqi*

**Appendix VI: The Origins of Printing *The Celestial Music Collection***

Works on the esoteric arts abound like cattle filling a barn—many have I perused. Yet most conceal the mother in the child, veil the image in metaphor, and though readable, remain hard to grasp. Inevitably, one gropes like a blind man touching an elephant, misguessing and misconstruing, left only with a sense of gazing at the ocean and sighing in awe.

Last autumn, in the year *guichou*, I sought the Way from the Elder of Hidden Valley. He graciously revealed the wondrous discourse on esoteric practice, imparting the essential subtleties of harmonizing heart and breath, and lent me *The Celestial Music Collection*. A cursory reading of but a few chapters sufficed to open my eyes and illumine my mind. Only then did I realize that the elixir formulas transmitted by the sages of old indeed had worthy successors.

*The Celestial Music Collection* was composed by Master Xuanjing (Haiyin). Its contents are vast—reportedly spanning over one hundred scrolls in eight volumes. The copy I obtained comprises but a tenth of the whole. Yet even this partial glimpse reveals the culmination of the elixir formulas of all past sages. It dissects what earlier alchemical texts left unexamined, stripping away the skin to reveal the flesh, with every word guiding one toward sagehood. The arcane purports of the *Can Tong Qi*, *Wu Zhen Pian*, *Yin Fu Jing*, and *Dao De Jing* are laid bare without reservation. Every elixir formula and experiential insight is expounded in exhaustive detail—truly the great compendium of Daoist learning, the compass of elixir classics, and the key to the esoteric arts.

My fellow cultivator, Xueyangzi—though my senior in the lineage—is also my guide across the ford. The harmony of heart and breath, had he not first illuminated the path, how could I have grasped it so profoundly or embraced it so steadfastly? Bound by the fellowship of immortals, we resonate in voice and seek in kindred *qi*. All that we attain, we refine through mutual exchange, mutually enlightening one another as we advance together.

I lament that fine books are hard to obtain yet easily lost, while lesser scholars cling to the false and stray from the real. *The Celestial Music Collection* resounds like celestial music in the void, suffusing the spirit and nurturing nature. Yet how many lovers of the Way will ever have the chance to read it?

Mindful of the deep bonds with my immortal brethren—Yunzhongzi, Qiqiaoxing, and others—and unwilling to hoard such treasures alone, I resolved to commission the printing of several copies to share with kindred spirits, that we might ascend the cloud-path together. Yet, burdened by worldly affairs and myriad obstructions, I had already pledged to oversee the *Immortal Dao Monthly*—now this vow to print *The Celestial Music* weighs upon me as well. Torn between the two, I can but sigh in helplessness.

I consulted Xueyang, who, through the intercession of Tiyang, readily agreed without hesitation. Undaunted by the labor, he undertook to begin anew, and we settled on printing twenty copies. Such a noble-minded seeker of the Way, so generous in aiding the Dao, fills me with profound admiration and boundless gratitude.

Thus, I have prefaced this edition with a table of contents for ease of reference and briefly recounted its origins.

**Tianlezi’s Inscribed Poems:**

**I**

**I**
Who knows the move within the boundless void?
A child of tiger’s den explores the dark and still.
The true midst Heaven and Earth—how vast, how wide!
Yin and yang’s limits: but a mote of dust.
Heart and breath entwined birth the mystic aperture;
From murky cosmos, cull the jade-like *zhi*.
The *Celestial Music* reveals its subtlest wonders,
Stark and bare, the truth laid bare as *tathatā*.

**II**
As if immortal strains resound across the sky,
One drifts amid a blaze of heavenly blossoms.
Each verse marks the marrow of the mystic spine;
Each chapter mirrors the Buddha’s voice and face.
Our homeland lies in the realm of *wuheyou*;
Our visage belongs to the Lord of Vague Forms.
From fine dust to the coarse Three Realms,
Who but I dares laugh in the spring breeze?

**III**
A body beyond bodies, a grandfather beyond grandsons,
The ear bears the colossal staff that pierces heaven.
Have you seen the *Sea-Print*’s wink, O Lord?
I dare exhaust the craftsman’s artifice of heaven.
Thus I entrust the *Golden Lad* to carve anew,
And bid the *Jade Maiden* hasten its completion.
The silk thread never slips—fit for angling;
Once the golden toad is hooked, I’ll seek the *Jade Palace*.

**IV**
*Qiangu* borrowed *The Celestial Music* to transcribe;
The Innocent One then entrusted it to *Tiyang*.
Eight-tenths of the work remained unfinished,
Yet one corner reflected the whole, all was complete.
Henceforth, read by starlight and moonlight,
Ever revering each breath, pursuing with the heart.
The elixir that extends life and preserves the true—
May all the world partake of it together.

**V**
The book remains, its author gone—deep regret!
How could I receive the *Voice of the Tide* in person?
After *Dongting*, the former master’s line continues;
Since *Xiyue*, I have taken up the mantle.
I still recall *Qiangu* with longing,
And ever remember the *Little Innocent One*.
The world’s affairs shift, human hearts are treacherous—
One must tread with care, as on thin ice.

*Haiyin Shanren* Xu Songyao
